course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At VU Amsterdam, having a strong command of the language of your study programme is crucial to your academic success. Therefore, all first-year Bachelor students must take a Dutch or English language proficiency test at the beginning of their studies. The required test depends on the language of instruction for your Bachelor's programme.
See also: Language Proficiency Test - Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (vu.nl)", "Course Content
The test consists of multiplechoice and fill-in-the-blank questions on the following topics:
Grammar
Spelling and punctuation
Structuring
Vocabulary/usage
Phrasing
Reading comprehension
Pronunciation
Classroom English", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The language proficiency test will take place in September in the DigiTenT at the VU.", "Method of Assessment
The language proficiency test is a digital test consisting of 200 closed questions.", "Additional Information
The VU English Language Test is linked to a first-year course. The final grade for this course is awarded only after passing the English Language Test. Students who do not obtain a satisfactory result for the test have to take the refresher course offered by the Taalloket.
For more information on the VU English Language Test, please see also: Language Proficiency Test - Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (vu.nl)", "Custom Course Registration
You do not need to register for the test. The Educational Office of your faculty will ensure your registration for the language proficiency test. Once registered, you can find the test’s date and time on your personal timetable. If you have not been registered by 8 September, please contact the student desk. You can also check the timetable of your programme for the test schedule.
Ensure you know your VUnet ID and corresponding password, as you will need these details to log in to the language test. Tip: change your password to something you can easily remember."]

course_name: Objects in Context. An Interdisciplinary Perspective on the Ancient World
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Ancient Studies
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
A distinct feature of Ancient Studies is the combined use of written and material sources. In this course the focus is on material culture, and how this can be used as a source of information about the past. You will familiarize yourself with some of the main categories of objects such as statues, reliefs, coins and utensils as well as with complex assemblages that are part of the sacred, domestic and funerary domain. An important issue is how we evaluate objects as sources of historical information about the past. What are the possibilities and limitations? What types of questions can we ask? For this we take a closer look at the historical context of material sources: we explore why material culture was created by people in the past, and how this affects our image of antiquity. Special attention will be paid to confronting material and literary information, and to those cases where they seem to contradict each other.
At the end of this course, you can:
evaluate various categories of objects as sources of historical information about the past
explain basic theories regarding the use of objects as historical source
apply these insights to an actual object
find relevant scholarship and primary sources
write a brief annotated academic text", "Course Content
In this course you will familiarize yourself with some basic theories regarding the use of material sources to generate information about the past. In addition to this, you will perform your own research on selected objects from the archaeological collection of the Allard Pierson. Doing so, you will get acquainted with the university library and acquire basic academic skills such as how to draft an academic text, how to find relevant scholarship and primary sources, how to provide adequate annotation and how to draw up a bibliography.
Together with ‘Historical Sources’ in period 3, this course lays the foundation for the interdisciplinary approach that characterizes Ancient Studies. You learn how to use and evaluate objects as sources of information about the past, and to combine and confront these with data from written evidence. You pursue this approach and method in the rest of your study program.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars (3 x 2hrs p/w)", "Method of Assessment
Multiple choice exam (40%)
Set-up for writing assignment (completed/not-completed)
Writing assignment (60%)
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills for Ancient Studies students. Students will be introduced into the rules of setting up an academic bibliography and reference system and train their writing skills.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed.
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note: This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam"]

course_name: The Classical Canon I: The Heritage of Antiquity
course_programmes: Hide full list (8); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This first canon module (followed up by a module in year 2 for regular students, but also set up as ‘stand alone’ elective) gives an introduction to the texts, items, places and monuments that belong to the 'Classical' canon, or have once belonged to it. After a general introduction, it offers broad outlines of the contents, contexts and uses of canonical works, persons and events, such as the Bible, the Gilgamesh epos, Homer, Virgil, ancient tragedians and lyricists, the Athenian Akropolis, the Ara Pacis, the battle of Thermopylai etc. Examples will be taken from literature, archaeology, history, history of art and urban studies, or regard so-called lieux de mémoire. They will be ordered thematically in combinations of several items. A lecture is devoted a single theme or a category of canonical works, persons or events, suggesting links and connections between them. The examples will normally be taken from the ancient world, but they will be viewed in the perspective of the roles they have played in later times, and of their roles in the formation of later canons. Reception of canonical items and their continuous presence through time are an important focus of the module.
Acquiring basic knowledge about the (various) contents, cultural contexts, causes and uses of (the) classical canon(s);
Being able to reproduce an overview of the main constituents of the present day ‘classical canon’ from the Ancient Near East to Late Antiquity
Being able to reproduce a basic chronology; to distinguish various ‘genres’/disciplines; an to generally contextualise various canons and their functions, and canonical items within that
Being able to switch between various ‘genres’/disciplines/artistic media/periods/cultural areas
Being able to identify specific and more general parts of the canon", "Course Content
This course prepares for the module ‘Canon II’ on modern theory concerning canons and canonicity, but can also be taken as a separate (elective) module. Besides reading texts relevant to the case studies, students will have to present a case study in a group presentation.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures/seminars, 2 x 2 hours
The first half of the course (weeks 2-4) consists of lectures; the second half (weeks 5-7) consists of a lecture and a seminar (mainly for the group presentations) each week. Presence for the seminars is required.", "Method of Assessment
Oral presentation of a group project (40% of the final grade). Students conduct a small research project on a canonical item (not discussed in class) and its meaning through time. The results of the project are presented orally to the other students during one of the seminars.
Written exam in week 8 , based on the contents of the readings and the case studies presented in the lectures and the seminars (60% of the final grade).
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA programme Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen). Students train their presentation skills.
Resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Literature
A selection of articles and book chapters which are freely available online (Canvas) or through the library. Students prepare for the sessions by reading an article/chapter of secondary literature and/or (in some of the seminars) by watching recorded materials. Some of the reading/viewing will be discussed in class, other texts serve as a background useful to better understand lectures, or offer additional information.", "Additional Information Target Audience
First year students --> Bachelor's in Ancient Studies and elective students.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed. Other students can register for this course via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]

course_name: A Cultural History of the Ancient World 1: The Near East and the Greek World
course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After succesfully completing this course you
have a basic knowledge and understanding of the main cultural and historical developments in the Near East and the Mediterranean from the Neolithic until the Hellenistic period
are able to place these developments in time and space
have an insight in how the developments in different parts of the Mediterranean and Near East were interrelated
know and can apply the essential terms, notions, concepts and stylistic characteristics current in contemporary scholarship in this field
can reflect on the interplay between material culture and historical and cultural developments
have been introduced to dealing with cultural-historical problems from an interdisciplinary angle, using archaeological, textual and historical sources", "Course Content
This course offers you an overview of the major historical and cultural developments in the Mediterranean and the Near East from the Neolithic to the Hellenistic period (ca. 10,000 to 300 BCE). The overview is presented according to major historical developments and a selection of objects, buildings and find places. Recurring themes are the emergence and development of states and political systems, social and political complexity, cultural identity and interconnectivity. Aside from the lectures, you work on assignments for the seminars (once every two weeks) that help you to further explore specific topics, to relate theory to practice, and to work with written sources and original (archaeological) materials from the collections of the VU University Library and the Allard Pierson.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (twice a week) and seminars (once every two weeks).", "Method of Assessment
Mid term exam (10%), final exam (75%) and assignments linked to the seminars (15%). You have passed this course with a total score of 5.5 or higher.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA programmes. Archaeology, Classics (GLTC) and Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen). Its students will be specifically trained in communicating with a wider, non-specialist audience in their museum assignments.", "Literature
De Blois, L. & R. J. van der Spek 2019: An Introduction to the Ancient World (3rd revised edition), Taylor & Francis, Abingdon.
J. M. Barringer, The Art and Archaeology of Ancient Greece, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2014.
Additional study materials on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
First-year ACASA students of Classics, Archaeology, and Ancient Studies.
This course can also be followed as an elective, as part of a minor or an exchange program.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed. Other students can register for this course via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]

course_coordinator: prof. dr. R.B. ter Haar Romeny
course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; History
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course:
The student is able to apply the most important social/anthropological theories and historical concepts with regard to cultural interaction, acculturation and identity;
The student recognizes the problems related to periodizations and generalizations in history and is acquainted with the most important discussions about the relation between culture, identity, and power;
The student is acquainted with the most important viewpoints in general (cultural-historical) discussions about East/West, Hellenism, and Orientalism;
The student has gained awareness of conflicting opinions in Anglophone scholarship and has learned to take a position in debates.", "Course Content
For a long time, Western scholars were mostly interested in the cultures of Classical Greece and Rome, regarding them as the twin cradles of Western civilization. However, in Egypt, the Levant and Mesopotamia, there were great civilizations whose roots stretched back much further into the past and whose fates became inextricably intertwined with those of the Greeks and Romans. This module is concerned with the interaction between the cultures of the Mediterranean and Western Asia. How did Greeks, Romans, Egyptians, Persians, and Jews interact? From the Greco-Persian Wars to the success of Oriental cults in the Roman Empire, the focus will be not only on the ongoing confrontations between “East” and “West”, but also on the intense flows and contacts between both regions. We will examine these historical contacts and confrontations from the perspectives of cultural history, anthropology, and contemporary theoretical thought. Through the interdisciplinary use of different sources and media, we will discuss the reciprocity of cultural contacts and the possibilities for scholars to analyse them from various perspectives.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
One lecture and one seminar per week.", "Method of Assessment
Written assignments (not graded)
Mid-term writing assignment (20 %)
Written exam (80 %)
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual. This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in the reading, understanding and processing of academic literature, and in writing skills (including setting up a bibliography).", "Entry Requirements
For this course knowledge of ancient history is required. Students must combine this course with A Cultural History of the Ancient World 1: The Near East and the Greek World or have followed another introductory course relating to Ancient History.", "Literature
A selection of articles and chapters, provided by the teachers.", "Additional Information Target Audience
First year students in Bachelor Oudheidwetenschappen. Second year students of Bachelor Geschiedenis", "Additional Information
The course is also offered as an elective.
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed. Other students can register for this course via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam.", "Recommended background knowledge
First year students in ACASA Bachelor in Oudheidwetenschappen. Second year students of UvA Bachelor in Geschiedenis (electives Ancient Religions and Ancient Cultures) and second year students of the VU Geschiedenis and History and International Studies BA Programmes."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The days of classical antiquity are irretrievably gone. So how can we know anything about this intriguing world? How do new and changed insights about Antiquity come about? In other words: how does research into the past work? The first-year module ‘Historical sources’ introduces all students of Classical philology, Archaeology and Ancient Studies to the process of research into the past, with a particular focus on the role of sources. For all knowledge of the past starts from the analysis of primary sources: relics of the past, whether surviving by accident or carefully transmitted.
At the end of this module, students are able to:
identify and execute the consecutive steps of the process of research into the past
identify various types of primary sources from the Ancient World, using the appropriate academic terms
discuss the typical features, potential and limitations of the types of historical sources studied in class
apply source criticism to historical sources
assess the value of different types of primary sources for different research questions, and to explain the advantages of combining multiple types of sources (multi-disciplinarity)", "Course Content
In this module, students are introduced to the whole spectrum of primary sources, the ways these have reached us, and the consequences of this process of survival for their potential and validity. The focus will lay on textual and iconographic sources from Classical Antiquity, such as historiographical texts, inscriptions, documents on papyrus and coins. What are their special features? What are their potential and limitations for research? We will not only look at texts and images, but also at the material forms in which they have reached us. You will learn to use these sources for research purposes: how to evaluate them critically and to analyze them so as to answer a specific research question.
Each source type requires specific analytical skills. These often represent a subdiscipline within the wider field of ancient studies. For most research questions it is essential, however, to use more than just one type of source. Various sources can complement and enrich our picture of the past, as will be shown throughout the module by means of interesting and interdisciplinary case studies. When visiting the historical location of one of these cases, you even will personally experience the added value of such an interdisciplinary approach.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
This course consists of lectures, seminars and group projects.", "Method of Assessment
Participation: assignments in preparation of and in class (not graded)
Written exam
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
First-year ACASA students of Classics, Archaeology, and Ancient Studies.
The course is also open to elective students who have participated in A Cultural History of the Ancient World 1 and 2, or who can demonstrate to have attained a comparable level, for instance by completing specific parts of the BA History.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed.
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note: This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam"]

course_name: A Cultural History of the Ancient World 2: The Hellenistic World, Italy and Rome
course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Upon completion of this course, students will:
Have a basic knowledge and understanding of the main cultural and historical developments in Italy and the wider Mediterranean world in the period between ca. 1100 BCE and CE 400
Be able to place these developments in time and space
Have a firm grasp of the chronological framework of this period
Know and can apply the essential terms, notions, concepts and stylistic characteristics current in contemporary scholarship in this field
Have experience in tackling cultural-historical problems from an interdisciplinary angle, using archaeological, textual and art historical sources
Recognize a core group of items (objects and events) from images or basic descriptions, and describe their basic parameters (like date, maker(s) or protagonist, location etc.)
Be trained in processing and presenting academic information in an oral format (spoken presentations) to an audience of their peers and non-specialists", "Course Content
This course offers an overview of the major historical and cultural developments in Italy and the Roman world between ca. 1100 BCE and CE 500, and traces the intensifying interaction of Rome with the wider Hellenistic and Mediterranean world. Recurring themes are (1) the emergence and development of states and political systems, in particular the Etruscan city-states, the Roman republic and the Roman empire; (2) how developments in different parts of the Mediterranean were interrelated; and (3) the interplay between material culture and mental concepts in these developments. In addition to the lectures, you work on assignments during the seminars that help you to further explore specific topics, to relate theory to practice, and to work with written sources (in translation) and original archaeological materials from the collection of the Allard Pierson.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures twice a week (2x2 hours/week); seminar once every two weeks (2 hours).
Total number of contact hours: 12x2 for lectures; 3x2 for seminars. Average number of contact hours per week: 5 hours.
Schedule will be published on rooster.uva.nl", "Method of Assessment
Two seminar assignments (individual written work) and one group assignment (museum presentations) (together 25%);
Midterm written exam in week 3 (30%);
Final written exam in week 7 (45%).
To pass the course, all assignments have to be completed.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA programmes Archaeology, Classics (GLTC) and Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen). Its students will be specifically trained in communicating with a wider, non-specialist audience in their museum assignment.
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Literature
You're expected to buy the following handbooks:
De Blois, L. & R. J. van der Spek 2019: An Introduction to the Ancient World (3rd revised edition), Taylor & Francis, Abingdon. ISBN 9780815372417 €44,99
Steven L. Tuck, A History of Roman Art, (Wiley Blackwell), Oxford 2021. ISBN 9781119653288 €60,99", "Additional Information Target Audience
First-year ACASA students of Classics, Archaeology, and Ancient Studies. The course can also be followed as an elective, as part of a minor or in an exchange program.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed. Other students can register for this course via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]

course_name: Archaeology of Prehistoric and Roman Europe
course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After following this course the student
Has a general knowledge and understanding of the main cultural and historical developments of NW Europe between c. 5000 BC and AD 450
Has an understanding of the archaeological datasets, research questions and approaches that characterize the archaeology of NW Europe in the respective period
Can relate habitational patterns of the past to physical-geographical maps of NW European landscapes of the respective periods
Has knowledge of supra-regional connections and networks within Europe
Understands major cultural processes and the contribution of social and historical sciences and archaeology in the study of these processes
Has the skills to present a scientific topic to fellow students", "Course Content
This course is a students’ first encounter with the archaeology of the Neolithic, Bronze Age, Iron Age and Roman period. Themes such as material culture, habitation, burial ritual and land use are treated for each of the respective periods, as well as theories and concepts that are used to interpret the archaeological data. Most attention will be devoted to Northwestern Europe, specifically the Low Countries, contextualised within broad European trends.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course consists of 6 lectures and 6 seminars, plus 2 meetings assigned for training oral presentations. Broad cultural processes of the various periods are presented during the lectures. Seminars often take the form of question and answer sessions and will treat concrete case studies as well as key publications. One excursion to a major Roman site or museum is part of the course.", "Method of Assessment
Written examination at the end of the course (graded).
Presentations with handout (completed/non-completed).
For regulations concerning resitting these exams/assessments see the course manual.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Archaeology programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in oral presentations.", "Literature

first year bachelor students of Archaeology
students who wish to take the course as an elective", "Additional Information

course_name: Elementary Akkadian and A History of Ancient Mesopotamian Literature 1
course_programmes: Hide full list (8); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successful completion of this course, students:
Will know the basic grammar and vocabulary of Akkadian in the dialect of the classical Old Babylonian period (ca. 19th-17th centuries BCE).
Will have learnt how the cuneiform writing-system works and will be able to read and translate isolated sentences from Akkadian into English.
Will have gained insight into the rich textual history of ancient Mesopotamia.", "Course Content
This course is designed to teach students with no prior knowledge of Semitic languages to read Akkadian. First attested around 2300 BCE and last used in the first century CE, Akkadian has a tremendously rich history. It was written on clay tablets, using a script we call ‘cuneiform’ (from Latin cuneus meaning ‘wedge-shaped’). Cuneiform tablets survive not only from Mesopotamia (present-day Iraq) but also from Syria, Turkey and Egypt and they tell us about all imaginable aspects of human life in ancient times: how cities and states were organized, how great battles were fought and won, which laws governed societies, people's beliefs about gods and even what kind of songs they listened to or how they cooked their meals. Throughout this course you will learn a basic repertoire of cuneiform signs so that by the end, you will be able to decipher and read some of these ancient texts yourself!
Time permitting, students will have a guided tour of the VU special collections, during which they will have the opportunity to engage with actual ancient cuneiform tablets.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars (twice a week).", "Method of Assessment
Participation (40%)
Participation will be assessed based on your presence in class and your preparation. This means contributing to in-class analyses and translations of texts. If a student has an excused absence (for documented illness, any absence approved by a dean, religious observance), the student can receive full credit by submitting the homework assignment. Students who attend class, participate by asking and answering questions, and do the assigned reading and exercises have historically done well in this course, even if its subject matter is unfamiliar.
Written examination (60%)
Students will be tested on their command of the grammar, signs and vocabulary as taught in the course. To this end, they will be expected to transliterate, transcribe, analyze and translate short sentences and passages that reflect the level of knowledge acquired by the end of the course.
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Literature
For this course you will need three items: a grammar book, a sign-lexicon and a dictionary. If you cannot obtain them yourself, the teacher will provide you with pdf files of the necessary literature:
Course textbook: Richard Caplice, Introduction to Akkadian (2002, 4th edition).
Sign list: Rykle Borger, Mesopotamisches Zeichenlexikon (last edition 2010) or Rene Labat, Manuel d’épigraphie akkadienne (last edition 1976).
Akkadian-English dictionary: CDA: A Concise Dictionary of Akkadian, 2nd edition 2000, edited by Jeremy Black, Andrew George and Nicholas Postgate.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA students of Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen), who specialise in Ancient Near Eastern Studies;
Students of the minor Ancient Near Eastern Languages and Cultures (see https://minor.vu.nl/en);
Students who wish to choose the course as an elective.
This course is a prerequisite for Elementary Akkadian and A History of Ancient Mesopotamian Literature 2", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed. Other students can register for this course via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam"]

course_programmes: Hide full list (8); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After the successful completion of this course, the student will have:
Gained knowledge of the various ways in which archaeological research is embedded in and disseminated across contemporary society
Developed insight in the characteristics (possibilities and limitations) of different media of presenting archaeological information (academic books, popular books, websites, apps, games)
An awareness of the different ‘consumer groups’ of archaeological information (general public; education; local and national governments etc) and their particular interests and sensitivities
A basic knowledge of the organizational structure of current Dutch archaeology
Acquired basic knowledge of the basic concepts of archaeological heritage management
A basic understanding of the main ethical issues in archaeological research
Acquired an awareness of the ideological and political dimensions in archaeological research
Have become aware of the political position of archaeologists as well as a critical attitude towards the profession of archaeology", "Course Content
This course aims to provide the basis for a critical assessment of the role of archaeology in contemporary society. Archaeological knowledge about the past is highly subject to manipulation in the present. In this course we will discuss how archaeological questions and research strategies are influenced by modern ideological, political and ethical concerns. The course revolves around four themes: (1) archaeology and politics, (2) landscape and heritage, (3) archaeology and its national infrastructure, (4) public archaeology. Each of these four themes will be explored by several case studies on the basis of which more general discussion will be held.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course will offer two seminars each week of two hours. Individual online or home study precedes each class, in which the topics are subsequently discussed. Of all the four themes offered, the conceptual frames and (inter)national case studies will be treated, and there is a returning structure for each theme: a historiography of the topic, a case study and discussion. Study methods include web classes, powerpoint presentations, reflections and discussions.", "Method of Assessment
Written reflections per theme
Participation in the seminar discussions (completed/non-completed)
Written examination at the end of the course
For regulations concerning resitting these assessments see the course manual.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Archaeology programme. Its students will be specifically trained and tested in reflection and argumentation skills.", "Literature
Articles and web classes as well as the assignments will be accessible through Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is available to 1st year students of archaeology. It is also part of the orientation and specialisation Archaeology within Ancient Studies. Furthermore, it can serve as an elective for students in Ancient Studies and Greek and Latin language and culture, and students of other disciplines like history or ACW. The course is part of the Minor Public Presentation of the Past.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration

course_programmes: Hide full list (8); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The course objectives are the following:
Getting acquainted with the content, contexts, causes and functions of cultural history from the age of Constantine to the present from the perspective of the reception of antiquity
Being able to reproduce an overview of the most important characteristics of post-Classical cultural periods
Being able to broadly reproduce chronology; to distinguish between various genres/disciplines; to contextualize aspects of post-Classical cultural history globally
Being able to indicate how the thematic fields selected for this module have developed through the course of history", "Course Content
It may sound strange at first, but the Classical world of the ancient Near East, Greece and Rome did not end with Antiquity. On the contrary, its cultural impact affected the post-Classical world deeply and continually, and more often cultural identities have been forged on the authority of Classical precedent. In Western culture, the rebirth of Classical culture was proudly claimed by all who sought to establish their authority or legitimize power, from the Carolingian Empire to papal Rome, and from the Ancien Régime to the Third Reich. In this module, we will follow two tracks simultaneously. On the one hand, the cultural history of the West will be thematized on the basis of standard periodization, which ranges from Late Antiquity to Modernism and Postmodernism. How has the Classical heritage been tended, interpreted, appropriated or rejected through the centuries? On the other hand, a number of thematic sessions will explore specific topics from a diachronic perspective. In general, these will be discussed using a case study in which various elements play a role: texts as well as material sources (e.g. visual art, architecture). Special attention will be devoted to cultural contacts and the conceptualization of various aspects, such as politics, religion and ethnicity. Finally, students will learn to engage with new digital media through the creation of video essays.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course will consist of seven lectures, about seven seminars and one excursion, spread over a period of seven weeks. Students are expected to participate in all seminars and the excursion.", "Method of Assessment
Assessment will take place through a video essay (group assignment, 50% of final mark) and a written exam (individually, 50% of final mark). There are also two ungraded assessments: a digital quiz (pass/fail) and an excursion assignment (pass/fail).
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in communicating with a wider, non-specialist audience (through video-essays).
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the course manual.", "Entry Requirements
No prior knowledge is required.", "Literature
Grafton, Most & Settis (eds.), The Classical Tradition (2010)
Matthews, DeWitt Platt & Noble, Experience Humanities (8th rev. ed.; 2014)
Various selected book chapters, articles and primary sources", "Additional Information Target Audience
The course is part of the 1st year BA program of Ancient Studies.
The course is part of the minor Highlights of the Ancient World.
The course is open as an elective to all students with an interest in Classical culture, even if they are not part of a Humanities programme.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed. Other students can register for this course via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam.", "Recommended background knowledge
Although students will benefit from some general knowledge of Classical culture, there are no entry requirements for this course."]

course_name: Elementary Akkadian and A History of Ancient Mesopotamian Literature 2
course_programmes: Hide full list (8); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successful completion of this course, students:
Will have gained insights into the literature of ancient Mesopotamia through an in-depth exploration of one of its main languages.
Will know how to use basic research tools such as syllabaries and sign lists.
Will have a good grasp of the fundamentals of the phonology, morphology, and grammar of Akkadian, with emphasis on the dialect of the classical Old Babylonian period (ca. 19th-17th centuries BCE).", "Course Content
This course picks up where Elementary Akkadian 1 left off. Students will deepen their knowledge of the cuneiform writing system and continue to develop their grasp of Akkadian grammar and vocabulary. Readings from Mesopotamian texts in the original language and script will include, among others, selections from the Laws of Hammurabi. As a part of this course, students will have a guided tour with the teacher at the Rijksmuseum van Oudheden in Leiden, during which they will have the opportunity to engage with actual ancient cuneiform tablets.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars (twice a week).", "Method of Assessment
Participation (40%)
Participation will be assessed based on your presence in class and your preparation. This means contributing to in-class analyses and translations of texts. If a student has an excused absence (for documented illness, religious observance), the student can receive full credit by submitting the homework assignment within a deadline set by the instructor. Students who attend class, participate by asking and answering questions, and do the assigned reading and exercising generally do well in this course, even if its subject matter is unfamiliar.
Written examination (60%)
Students will be tested on their command of the grammar, signs and vocabulary as taught in the course. To this end, they will be expected to transliterate, transcribe, analyze and translate short sentences and passages from the Laws of Hammurabi.
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Literature
For this course you will need three items: a grammar book, a sign list and a dictionary.
Course textbook: Richard Caplice, Introduction to Akkadian (2002, 4th edition).
Sign list: Rykle Borger, Mesopotamisches Zeichenlexikon (last edition 2010) or Rene Labat, Manuel d’épigraphie akkadienne (last edition 1976).
Akkadian-English Dictionary: CDA: A Concise Dictionary of Akkadian, 2nd edition 2000, edited by Jeremy Black, Andrew George and Nicholas Postgate).", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA students of Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen), who specialise in Ancient Near Eastern Studies;
Students of the minor Ancient Near Eastern Languages and Cultures (see https://minor.vu.nl/en);
Students who wish to choose the course as an elective and meet the requirements specified above", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration

Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; History
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By the end of this course, students will be able to:
Situate this subject in different historical, cultural, and political contexts, including comparative and diachronic perspectives
Process, evaluate, and critically analyze the relevant ancient sources and academic literature in English (and other languages of which the student has sufficient knowledge)
Present information from different sources with their analyses and lead peer discussion on their chosen topic", "Course Content
Subject: Conspiracies and Assassinations in the Ancient Mediterranean World
Being a ruler or powerful political figure was a dangerous life in the ancient Mediterranean. They were at risk of becoming victims of political machinations, professional jealousies, or civil disruptions, sometimes with fatal results. We will analyze several cases of conspiracies and successful assassinations from Mesopotamia, Greece, and the Roman Empire to answer the following questions: what do these events tell us about what different communities considered a “good” or “bad” leader? How did these events disrupt politics and society? What were the differing attitudes towards the death of rulers? And, finally, what were the measures those in power took to prevent themselves from being violently ousted?", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar", "Method of Assessment
45% Group presentation and leading discussion
50% Written assignments
5% Attendance and participation
There is no exam or final paper for this course.
Seminar participation is obligatory; students are permitted maximum two absences.", "Literature
All course materials will be made available on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Target audience:
BA2 History students who have chosen the Antiquity track.
BA1 students of Ancient Studies (ACASA), for whom it serves as an orientation course to the Ancient History track.
The course can also be taken as an elective by other students, but see the entrance requirements.", "Recommended background knowledge
Politics and International Relations in Antiquity"]

course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of this course is to acquire a critical knowledge of ancient philosophy. After completing this course successfully, you will:
(1) be able to describe in your own terms the development of ancient philosophy,
(2) have a general knowledge of important schools, thinkers, their theories, and of (ancient) philosophical key terms, and
(3) have trained in analysing and discussing primary philosophical sources (which you will read in translation).", "Course Content
This course covers Greek and Roman philosophy from the 6th century BCE to the 7th century CE, and aims at providing a thematic introduction to the thought of the presocratics, the sophists, Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, Hellenistic and Roman philosophy, and late ancient Neoplatonism and patristic thought. The main themes to be discussed are philosophy of nature, epistemology, ontology, and ethics and politics. These themes will be discussed with the use of primary philosophical sources.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lecture: 4 x 3 hours per week", "Method of Assessment
Formative assessment: reading questions.
Summative assessment: online and in class discussions; written exam. The final grade is determined for 20% by the discussions, for 80% by the exam. A pass (5.5. or more) for both the discussions and the exam are needed to complete the course.
The resit regulations regarding these assignments are specified in the study manual.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Classics and Ancient Studies programmes. Its students will be specifically trained and tested in discussion skills.", "Literature
Literature (primary sources) will be made available via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is part of the first year of the bachelors Classics and Ancient Studies, but is also accessible to other students. No prior knowledge is required.", "Additional Information

Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Ancient Studies
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Around the Mediterranean, people from many different cultures and three different continents interacted with each other like (in Plato's words) "frogs around a pond". Cultural contacts are a main theme in the BA programme Ancient Studies. In this course, we try to understand these contacts and the Mediterranean interconnectedness or ‘connectivity’ resulting from it. What forms of contact were there? How far did they extend? What traces did they leave in the historical and material sources? What were the driving factors? What was their effect?
After completing this course, you are able to
identify and summarize the essential viewpoints dealt with in a number of (inter)disciplinary studies in the field of cultural contact and connectivity
reflect on these viewpoints and position yourself in the debate, and develop your own arguments on synchronous and diachronous cultural interactions
formulate research questions from an interdisciplinary approach and select the appropriate research strategies for solving these questions
combine textual and material sources and critically evaluate their respective contributions to research questions
report on your research findings in writing in a consistent, clear and concise manner", "Course Content
In this course, we will discuss and reflect on a selection of cases, which document various interactions within the Mediterranean or between inhabitants of the Mediterranean world and Europe from the Bronze age to late antiquity: e.g. Bronze Age trade networks; sanctuaries as Panhellenic meeting points; travel in the Roman world. Next to cases studies, we focus on various theoretical angles and discuss how the academic debate about cultural contacts has developed over the last 50 years.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The sessions will combine introductory lectures by the lecturers with student-led discussions of the literature and assignments to train research skills, which include both in-class exercises and formal assignments.", "Method of Assessment
Participation (includes active participation in discussions in class + submission of formative assignments; pass/fail)
In week 39 students produce a theoretical introduction based on the literature discussed in weeks 37-39 (pass/fail)
Academic paper of ca. 2500 words: 100% of final grade
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in formulating research questions and writing skills.
A student passes when all assignments are completed, the paper has a grade of 5,5 or higher, and the total grade (determined by exam and paper) is 5,5 or higher. The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Reader (in CANVAS).", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA-students Oudheidwetenschappen / Ancient Studies", "Additional Information
Max. 40 participants.

Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam.", "Recommended background knowledge
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in formulating research questions and writing skills.
A student passes when all assignments are completed, the paper has a grade of 5,5 or higher, and the total grade (determined by exam and paper) is 5,5 or higher. The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successfully completing this course, all students
Are able to apply basic concepts and theories from the philosophy of science to the humanities in general and to their own specific discipline, and to use them in critically assessing studies relevant to their own disciplines
Have acquired an overview of the historical development and the most important theoretical approaches of the humanities and of their own specific disciplines
Are able to evaluate the limitations and possibilities of specific disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches in relation to research questions within their own disciplines
Are able to analyze philosophical and theoretical texts relevant to their own discipline, and to relate the concepts involved to their own disciplines
Have practiced discussing philosophical and theoretical concepts during the seminars. They are able to evaluate research papers related to their own discipline from a theoretical/methodological point of view and to form an opinion/take a position in discussions about this among peers.
Have practiced academic writing skills and processing feedback while completing the weekly seminar assignments and leading up to the final assignment. They can reflect critically in writing on the research papers they have read and processed.
GLTC-students (and Ancient Studies students specializing in either Latin or Greek) have gained practical experience with codicology, paleography, text-criticism and literary criticism and are able to reflect critically on methods and theoretical viewpoints in these domains.", "Course Content
Modern academic disciplines are shaped and structured by philosophical concepts and doctrines. This course provides an overview of the history of philosophical thoughts and of philosophical debates about methodology, and their relevance to discussions of methodology, interdisciplinarity, and resource use in philology, cultural history, and archeology of antiquity.
The general theoretical and methodological issues that form the basis of the historical development of science and humanities will be related to the study of the past through texts and material culture. Disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches will be discussed, with special attention to both limitations and possibilities.
This course consists of one lecture and one seminar per week. The lectures are taught by a lecturer of the Department of Philosophy, on the base of a handbook. The seminars are taught by a lecturer from ACASA, and devoted to the discussion of a selection of key themes and relevant articles. Students will be trained in the close reading of philosophical texts that are crucial to the way their (inter)discipline organizes, produces, and structures knowledge.
Students in the programmes of GLTC and Ancient Studies students specializing in either Latin or Greek follow a different seminar, in which the historical developments of the humanities disciplines are more specifically connected to the field of classics. They will focus on (and practice) paleography, text criticism and literary theory.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Weekly lectures (2 hours/week); weekly seminars (2 hours/week)", "Method of Assessment
There will be a written exam for all students based on the handbook and the lectures. (50% of final grade)
In the seminars, the students will work in groups towards a written essay/final assignment (50% of final grade), which is prepared for by means of weekly partial assignments.
The resit regulations will be specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Gerard de Vries & Michiel Leezenberg, History and Philosophy of the Humanities: An Introduction. Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press, 2018. (paperback ISBN: 9789462987630 ; also available as e-book)
Additional literature will be made available during the course", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is for second year BA students of Archaeology (ARCH), Classics (GLTC), and Ancient Studies (OHW).", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (8); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successfully completing the course, students:
have mastered the main characteristics of the religions of the ancient Middle-East (Mesopotamia and the Levant) and of the ancient Greek and Roman worlds;
have a basic knowledge of the deities, religious life, rituals, and customs in said regions, as well as of their possible interconnections;
can recognize various theoretical approaches towards religion in the scholarly literature and apply these;
are familiar with the material and written sources and their problems;
have insights into the embeddedness of religion in the ancient societies under consideration.", "Course Content
This course treats the main characteristics of, and approaches to, religion in the ancient Middle-East and the Greek and Roman worlds. The lectures give an overview of the deities, religious life, rituals, and customs in each of these regions, with attention for possible interconnections. In discussing the various theoretical approaches towards religion, students will learn the - often implicit - theoretical assumptions in the scholarly literature, and gain insight into the coherence between religious changes and societal developments.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures.", "Method of Assessment
Written exam (graded on a scale of 1-10). Students pass with a score of 5.5 or higher.", "Literature
The mandatory literature will be announced on CANVAS.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year students of Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen)
Students of the --> Minor in Highlights of the Ancient World
Students of the minor Ancient Near Eastern Languages and Culture
Students from other disciplines who wish to take the course as an elective; especially suitable for Religion and Humanities students. note that a basic knowledge of the ancient world is expected.", "Additional Information
Please note that this is an intensive course. With 3-hour classes in the afternoon, you should be able to dedicate all remaining time to reading the mandatory literature and work on trial questions. N.B. When the text in the study guide is different from that of the course manual, the course manual is valid.
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration

Please note:

This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam", "Explanation Canvas
All communication about the course takes place via Canvas.", "Recommended background knowledge
There are no formal entry requirements, but a basic knowledge of the history and material culture of the Ancient World and its cultures is expected. Recommended literature in case of deficiencies:
(Ancient Middle-East) - Blois, L. de & R.J. van der Spek, 2019, An Introduction to the Ancient World, 3rd edition, London/New York. Chapters 1-7 (excluding Egypt)
(Greek world) - Barringer, J.M. 2015, The Art and Archaeology of Ancient Greece, Cambridge. Chapters 3-4.

course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In this course you will learn to study material and immaterial culture in an integrated way. Attention is paid to material / (cultural) historical, textual and Nachleben- and heritage-related aspects. You visit sites, monuments and museums that are linked to the central theme(s) of the excursion. In this way you obtain a deeper understanding of the long, diachronic lines of cultural history as well as of its synchronous cross-links.", "Course Content
You take introductory lectures on material, (cultural-) historical, textual, and Nachleben- and heritage-related aspects of the excursion destination. In addition, you attend subject-specific seminars (either materially or textually focused), which will further prepare you on aspects of the excursion destination (e.g., use of sources, specific themes, or aspects of the subject literature) and on writing an individual paper or a contribution to the travel guide on a topic related to the excursion destination. During the excursion you will give a presentation based on your paper at a specific site or museum, attempting to address as many of the above aspects as possible in an integrated manner (i.e., material and textual).", "Additional Information Teaching Methods

preliminary presentation ('pitch') during preparatory courses (completed/not completed)

course_name: Past and Present: Critical Approaches to Antiquity and Archaeological Heritage
course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successful completion of this course, you will:
Have broadened your knowledge of antiquity and heritage
Have acquired basic knowledge of the theoretical foundations of the field of heritage studies and its relation to antiquity and archaeology
Have gained a basic knowledge of the practice and structure of heritage management, both nationally (the Netherlands) and internationally
Understand the ideological, political, social and economic values related to the heritage of antiquity and their interaction
Be able to develop a theoretical and practical heritage plan for (tangible or intangible) remains from the past", "Course Content
In this course you are made familiar with the main academic, political and public debates regarding heritage studies and practice. Emphasis will be on the identification of different heritage categories (tangible and intangible) and above all heritage paradigms, from protectionist and conservationist traditions to developmental approaches focusing on the contribution of heritage to socioeconomic and spatial development. In particular, we will explore in this course how these categories and paradigms have relevance for the study of antiquity and archaeology. Central concepts which will be addressed are: heritage, landscape, value, authenticity, appropriation, public participation, conflict, tourism. These will be illustrated and explained through a series of case studies in seminar classes. Particular attention will be paid to the specific role of archaeological heritage in the broader heritage discourse and frameworks.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
In the first two weeks, there are four classes on a specific theme on a theoretical and practical level. For each class, there will be compulsory reading made available through the Canvas site. Each class will consist of a lecture (ca 1 hr) followed by group discussions.
In the third week, there will be no class, but you are supposed to work on the assignment: make an application document for a topic on the ACASA Heritage List.
In the fourth-seventh week the first classes of the week will be regular classes on a specific theme, with assigned compulsory reading. The second classes will be devoted to pitches for the ACASA Heritage List. At the end of these classes, we will vote which topics should be on the ACASA Heritage List. The final vote for the definitive ACASA Heritage List will be done in the last class, followed by discussion.", "Method of Assessment
The compulsory literature will be assessed by a weekly exam question that you will have to submit through the canvas page (completed/ non-completed).
Each student will work out a specific case-study for the ACASA Heritage List. In a pitch of 5-7 minutes, you will present your case (graded). Moreover, you will be asked to react to pitches of your fellow students (non-graded). In case of a student failing this part of the course, an additional extended paper on a different topic will need to be submitted.
In every class, there will be discussion and the final class will be a discussion class. The participation in the discussion will be assessed (completed/ non-completed).
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA programmes Archaeology and Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen). In this course, students of these programmes will be specifically trained and tested in oral presentations (pitches) and in adapting their presentations to a non-specialist audience.
Attendance
It is highly recommended that you attend all discussion classes in order to pass the exam. Attendance is compulsory for the seminar classes in which pitches are presented. In case you miss a seminar, a full point is deducted from the final grade.
For regulations concerning resitting the exams/assignments see the course manual.
Hours to be spent
A total of 140 hours is expected to be spent on the course divided in the following manner:
Reading and studying compulsory literature: 10 hours per week = 60 hours
Attending classes: 3 hours a week: 18 hrs
Preparing Application Document: 20 hrs
Pitch and discussion preparation: 22 hrs
Preparing for participation in final discussion: 20 hrs", "Literature
Articles for the lecture classes will be made available through the CANVAS page", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA students in Archaeology
BA students in Ancient Studies
BA students in Cultural Heritage
BA students in Urban studies and Geography
BA students of the Saxion University of Applied Sciences who follow the preparatory minor ('Doorstroomminor') Archaeology", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html

course_name: The Classical Canon 2: The Sociology of Cultural Selection
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Ancient Studies
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Expanding your knowledge of diverse forms of the classical canon from Antiquity to the present day
Acquiring knowledge of diverse scholarly explanations of content, context, causes and functions of cultural selections concerning the formation of classical canons
Application of diverse models from the sociology of culture to specific historical contexts including the present
Identification of both general and specific processes of canon formation and shifts of canon
Critical reflection on significance and value of the concept ‘canon’ and related concepts such as ‘classics’, ‘classicism’, ‘renaissance’ from the perspective of cultural philosophy and sociology
Development of writing skills", "Course Content
The module The Classical Canon 2: The Sociology of Cultural Selection in Theory and Practice is a sequel of the 1st-year module The Classical Canon I: The Heritage of Antiquity. While in that first course the emphasis was on the question ‘of what does the canon consist?’, more abstract problems related to canons and their historical role and function now follow. In the course of this module our attention will be on the particular reasons, sociological and historical, why canons have come into existence, how they developed and evolved through time and which canons have been most influential and why. These aspects will be studied in two ways: on the one hand we browse chronologically through a series of decisive moments in canon formation, from antiquity to the present day; on the other hand we will present a representative selection of theoretical concepts – from philosophy, sociology and art history – that will enable you to gain insights into content and function of canons and the mechanisms of cultural selection. The course will lead us from Roman antiquity to the Middle Ages, the Renaissance, Winckelmann and the 18th and 19th centuries CE to the 'culture wars' of recent decades.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures/seminars (2 sessions of 2 hours per week; all sessions mandatory, as specified on Canvas).", "Method of Assessment
Different kinds of written assignment, including two short papers.
All assignments are mandatory. Grading is on a scale of 1 to 10. You will pass the course with a final grade of 5.5 or higher and a grade of 5.5 or higher for your paper(s). If your paper(s) - and hence your final grade - prove to be insufficient, there are two possible ways of remedying this. The first possibility is to use the feedback provided by the instructors and to improve your original essay; in this case, your final grade for the essay cannot be higher than 6. The second possibility is to write a new essay, on a new topic; in this case no maximum score is set for your second effort. The other assignments cannot be redone.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in writing skills.", "Entry Requirements
See under Target audience. A basis knowledge of Mediterranean antiquity is needed.", "Literature
Relevant literature via CANVAS.", "Additional Information Target Audience
2nd year students Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen).
The course is open as an elective, preferably but not exclusively for students who have completed the first year of a humanities programme. Elective students are asked to consult the coordinator prior to registration.", "Additional Information
The course is open as an elective, preferably but not exclusively for students who have completed the first year of a humanities programme. Elective students are asked to consult the coordinator prior to registration.
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration

This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam.", "Recommended background knowledge
See under Target audience. A basis knowledge of Mediterranean antiquity is needed."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Ancient Studies
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In this course students
Become familiar with creative writing as a discipline and an art form
Study examples of creative reception of the material and textual heritage of the ancient world, and reflect on their cultural-historical context
Learn how to read and write fiction, poetry, and/or (creative) non-fiction about topics related to the ancient world with a wider, non-specialist audience in mind, and identify how and where these audiences can be found", "Course Content
Students attend lectures on the general principles of reception theory as well as the forms and conventions of creative writing, and discuss examples of ways in which the heritage of the ancient world can be brought under the attention of a wider, non-specialist audience. In subsequent, intensive writing clinics, they develop their creative writing and revision skills, which they further practice in writing workshops. For their final assignment, they choose a reception topic (e.g. from the ACASA heritage list), reflect upon an appropriate form to engage a wider, non-specialist audience, and display creativity and originality in exploring that topic within their chosen form. They present their final assignment to their fellow students.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Students attend two lectures on the reception of the ancient world, on top of a general introduction into the art of creative writing. In the second and third week, students will attend writing clinics with plenary sessions and break-out sessions in peer-groups. In the fourth week, students finish and present their final assignments.", "Method of Assessment
Attendance of the lectures, clinics and presentations (conditions met/not met)
Participation in discussion and feedback in the writing clinics and peer-groups (conditions met/not met)
Final creative writing assignment (graded, 100%)
Presentation of creative writing assignment (conditions met/not met)
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in creative writing skills for a wider non-specialist audience. The resit regulations are specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Literature will be published on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA2 students of the Ancient Studies programme.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
