course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
De VU vindt het belangrijk dat je de taal van je opleiding goed beheerst. Daarom moeten alle eerstejaars bachelorstudenten verplicht een taaltoets Nederlands of Engels afleggen, afhankelijk van de voertaal van de opleiding die ze gaan volgen (Nederlandstalig of Engelstalig).
Zie ook: Alles over de taaltoets - Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (vu.nl)", "Course Content
De toets bestaat uit multiplechoicevragen en invulvragen over de volgende onderwerpen:
grammatica
spelling en interpunctie
structureren
woordkeus/woordenschat
formuleren", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
De taaltoets vindt plaats in de DigiTenT, in september.", "Method of Assessment
De taaltoets is een digitale toets met 200 vragen.", "Additional Information
De VU-Taaltoets is gekoppeld aan een eerstejaars vak. Het eindcijfer voor dit vak wordt pas toegekend als aan de Taaltoets is voldaan. De student die geen voldoende resultaat voor de VU taaltoets behaalt, volgt de ‘Bijspijkercursus Nederlands’ van het Taalloket.
Voor meer informatie over de taaltoets, zie: Alles over de taaltoets - Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (vu.nl)", "Custom Course Registration
Je hoeft je niet voor de toets aan te melden. Het onderwijsbureau van jouw faculteit tekent je in voor de taaltoets. Wanneer je bent ingetekend vind je op je persoonlijke rooster terug op welk moment je de toets maakt. Als je op 8 september nog niet bent ingetekend, neem dan contact op met de studentenbalie. In de tussentijd kun je in het rooster terugvinden op welk moment je de toets moet maken.
Het is belangrijk om je VUnet-ID en bijbehorend wachtwoord te kennen. Je kunt bij de taaltoets alleen inloggen met deze gegevens. Tip: verander je wachtwoord in iets dat je makkelijk kunt onthouden."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (8); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students who successfully complete this course will have a basic knowledge of and insight into:
The nature, aims and objectives of modern archaeology and its relationship with (ancient) history, anthropology and the sciences
The history of archaeology as an academic discipline, with attention for shifts in nature, aims and objectives and theoretical frameworks
The relationship between material culture and patterns in human behaviour and thinking, as well as current methods to study this relationship
The various theoretical perspectives involved in reconstructing past human behaviour and societies, with special attention for the role of anthropology and history
The role of archaeology and heritage in the contemporary world", "Course Content
This first level course offers students an introduction to key concepts and practical approaches in archaeology. Students will become acquainted with the nature, aims and research objectives of modern-day archaeology. They will also gain an insight into the history of archaeology as an academic discipline and its (evolving) relationship with (ancient) history, anthropology and the natural sciences. Students will be introduced to the various ways in which archaeologists use material culture to reconstruct the human past and past societies, with special attention being paid to the role of anthropological and historical approaches. The links between archaeological theory and practice will be further explored by the use of case studies drawn from a wide range of time periods and geographical regions. Finally, consideration will also be given to the politics of archaeology, and an introduction will be given to the opportunities and challenges that face archaeology and heritage in today’s world.
Depending on the general timetable and the availability of ongoing excavations a (non-mandatory) field trip may be organized.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (3 x 2 hours per week). Average number of contact hours per week: 6 hours. Course timetable to be published on rooster.uva.nl", "Method of Assessment
Two written examinations: a midterm in week 3 (40%) and a final exam in week 8 (60%).
A minimum score of 55% (or 5.5 on a scale of 10) on the final is needed to pass the course.
The resit regulations will be specified in the UvA study manual.", "Literature
For this course you are expected to buy a copy of:
Renfrew, C./Bahn, P./DeMarrais, E., 2024, Archaeology: Theories, Methods and Practice, Thames & Hudson, ninth edition. €48.95 ISBN 0500297096
In addition, a syllabus will be made available on Canvas, with guidelines on how to approach the handbook and with trial questions and points of discussion for each class.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Target audience:
First year students in Archaeology.
Second year students Ancient Studies with a specialization in Archaeology.
Also available to other students as an elective; no entry requirements.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed. Other students can register for this course via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]

course_name: A Cultural History of the Ancient World 1: The Near East and the Greek World
course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After succesfully completing this course you
have a basic knowledge and understanding of the main cultural and historical developments in the Near East and the Mediterranean from the Neolithic until the Hellenistic period
are able to place these developments in time and space
have an insight in how the developments in different parts of the Mediterranean and Near East were interrelated
know and can apply the essential terms, notions, concepts and stylistic characteristics current in contemporary scholarship in this field
can reflect on the interplay between material culture and historical and cultural developments
have been introduced to dealing with cultural-historical problems from an interdisciplinary angle, using archaeological, textual and historical sources", "Course Content
This course offers you an overview of the major historical and cultural developments in the Mediterranean and the Near East from the Neolithic to the Hellenistic period (ca. 10,000 to 300 BCE). The overview is presented according to major historical developments and a selection of objects, buildings and find places. Recurring themes are the emergence and development of states and political systems, social and political complexity, cultural identity and interconnectivity. Aside from the lectures, you work on assignments for the seminars (once every two weeks) that help you to further explore specific topics, to relate theory to practice, and to work with written sources and original (archaeological) materials from the collections of the VU University Library and the Allard Pierson.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students:
Have knowledge of the history, foundations and core concepts of environmental archaeology and ecological archaeology
Can explain geological and soil science processes which are formative to the physical landscape and to distinguish between natural and human causes of these changes
Are able to describe how different food economies are distinguished in archaeology and how those economies have affected the landscape
Are able to interpret sources, methods and techniques used by ecological archaeology to recognize the most important physical characteristics of animal and plant remains.", "Course Content
Environmental Archaeology studies the interaction between humans and their environment in the past. It focuses on the reconstruction of the environment in its broadest sense (landscape, flora, fauna and climate), and the changes therein and it uses the abiotic and biotic components found in geological sediments, soils and archaeological deposits as its source material. While the focus is on the relationship between human settlement and its environment, environmental archaeology always puts man as centre stage: it studies how the physical landscape put limits and constraints on human settlement, and, vice versa, how the natural environment was changed by human intervention and exploitation for food and natural sources. In this course you will be introduced to the methods and theories used in this field of archaeology and learn how to put them to use to answer questions on the interrelationship between humans and their environment.
In this course, four aspects of the interrelationship between humans and their environment will be discussed:
Natural and human-induced processes in the formation of the landscape;
Spatial imaging of the landscape: the use of maps;
Plants and animals in the landscape and their exploitation;
Humans in the landscape: environmental reconstruction and food economy.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
There will be 2 x 3 contact hours each week. Most of the classes have a practical component, for which attendance is mandatory.
Classes consist of interactive lectures which introduce the course topics, and practicals which are aimed at:
training you to use maps (topographic, soil, geomorphological, and archaeological prospection maps);
offering you a first introduction to the determination of ecological remains (analysis of plants and bones);
presenting a short natural landscape reference paper", "Method of Assessment
The students will be assessed by presentations (20%), contributions to practical assessments (AVV/NAV), and map exercises (20%). A final exam will conclude the course (60%).
The resit regulations will be specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Renfrew & Bahn - Archaeology, Theories, Methods and Practice, 6th edition or more recent:
chapter 4: When? Dating Methods and Chronology
chapter 6: What was the Environment. Environmental Archaeology
chapter 7: What did they eat? Subsistence and Diet
Additional study materials will be available via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
First year bachelor students of ACASA Archeology.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed. Other students can register for this course via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam.", "Explanation Canvas
Weekly overviews, discussion forums and assignments will be available via Canvas."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The days of classical antiquity are irretrievably gone. So how can we know anything about this intriguing world? How do new and changed insights about Antiquity come about? In other words: how does research into the past work? The first-year module ‘Historical sources’ introduces all students of Classical philology, Archaeology and Ancient Studies to the process of research into the past, with a particular focus on the role of sources. For all knowledge of the past starts from the analysis of primary sources: relics of the past, whether surviving by accident or carefully transmitted.
At the end of this module, students are able to:
identify and execute the consecutive steps of the process of research into the past
identify various types of primary sources from the Ancient World, using the appropriate academic terms
discuss the typical features, potential and limitations of the types of historical sources studied in class
apply source criticism to historical sources
assess the value of different types of primary sources for different research questions, and to explain the advantages of combining multiple types of sources (multi-disciplinarity)", "Course Content
In this module, students are introduced to the whole spectrum of primary sources, the ways these have reached us, and the consequences of this process of survival for their potential and validity. The focus will lay on textual and iconographic sources from Classical Antiquity, such as historiographical texts, inscriptions, documents on papyrus and coins. What are their special features? What are their potential and limitations for research? We will not only look at texts and images, but also at the material forms in which they have reached us. You will learn to use these sources for research purposes: how to evaluate them critically and to analyze them so as to answer a specific research question.
Each source type requires specific analytical skills. These often represent a subdiscipline within the wider field of ancient studies. For most research questions it is essential, however, to use more than just one type of source. Various sources can complement and enrich our picture of the past, as will be shown throughout the module by means of interesting and interdisciplinary case studies. When visiting the historical location of one of these cases, you even will personally experience the added value of such an interdisciplinary approach.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
This course consists of lectures, seminars and group projects.", "Method of Assessment
Participation: assignments in preparation of and in class (not graded)
Written exam
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
First-year ACASA students of Classics, Archaeology, and Ancient Studies.
The course is also open to elective students who have participated in A Cultural History of the Ancient World 1 and 2, or who can demonstrate to have attained a comparable level, for instance by completing specific parts of the BA History.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed.
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note: This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam"]

course_name: A Cultural History of the Ancient World 2: The Hellenistic World, Italy and Rome
course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Upon completion of this course, students will:
Have a basic knowledge and understanding of the main cultural and historical developments in Italy and the wider Mediterranean world in the period between ca. 1100 BCE and CE 400
Be able to place these developments in time and space
Have a firm grasp of the chronological framework of this period
Know and can apply the essential terms, notions, concepts and stylistic characteristics current in contemporary scholarship in this field
Have experience in tackling cultural-historical problems from an interdisciplinary angle, using archaeological, textual and art historical sources
Recognize a core group of items (objects and events) from images or basic descriptions, and describe their basic parameters (like date, maker(s) or protagonist, location etc.)
Be trained in processing and presenting academic information in an oral format (spoken presentations) to an audience of their peers and non-specialists", "Course Content
This course offers an overview of the major historical and cultural developments in Italy and the Roman world between ca. 1100 BCE and CE 500, and traces the intensifying interaction of Rome with the wider Hellenistic and Mediterranean world. Recurring themes are (1) the emergence and development of states and political systems, in particular the Etruscan city-states, the Roman republic and the Roman empire; (2) how developments in different parts of the Mediterranean were interrelated; and (3) the interplay between material culture and mental concepts in these developments. In addition to the lectures, you work on assignments during the seminars that help you to further explore specific topics, to relate theory to practice, and to work with written sources (in translation) and original archaeological materials from the collection of the Allard Pierson.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures twice a week (2x2 hours/week); seminar once every two weeks (2 hours).
Total number of contact hours: 12x2 for lectures; 3x2 for seminars. Average number of contact hours per week: 5 hours.
Schedule will be published on rooster.uva.nl", "Method of Assessment
Two seminar assignments (individual written work) and one group assignment (museum presentations) (together 25%);
Midterm written exam in week 3 (30%);
Final written exam in week 7 (45%).
To pass the course, all assignments have to be completed.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA programmes Archaeology, Classics (GLTC) and Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen). Its students will be specifically trained in communicating with a wider, non-specialist audience in their museum assignment.
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Literature

First-year ACASA students of Classics, Archaeology, and Ancient Studies. The course can also be followed as an elective, as part of a minor or in an exchange program.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed. Other students can register for this course via UvA https://glass.uva.nl

course_name: Archaeology of Prehistoric and Roman Europe

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After following this course the student
Has a general knowledge and understanding of the main cultural and historical developments of NW Europe between c. 5000 BC and AD 450
Has an understanding of the archaeological datasets, research questions and approaches that characterize the archaeology of NW Europe in the respective period
Can relate habitational patterns of the past to physical-geographical maps of NW European landscapes of the respective periods
Has knowledge of supra-regional connections and networks within Europe
Understands major cultural processes and the contribution of social and historical sciences and archaeology in the study of these processes
Has the skills to present a scientific topic to fellow students", "Course Content
This course is a students’ first encounter with the archaeology of the Neolithic, Bronze Age, Iron Age and Roman period. Themes such as material culture, habitation, burial ritual and land use are treated for each of the respective periods, as well as theories and concepts that are used to interpret the archaeological data. Most attention will be devoted to Northwestern Europe, specifically the Low Countries, contextualised within broad European trends.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course consists of 6 lectures and 6 seminars, plus 2 meetings assigned for training oral presentations. Broad cultural processes of the various periods are presented during the lectures. Seminars often take the form of question and answer sessions and will treat concrete case studies as well as key publications. One excursion to a major Roman site or museum is part of the course.", "Method of Assessment

course_programmes: Hide full list (8); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After the successful completion of this course, the student will have:
Gained knowledge of the various ways in which archaeological research is embedded in and disseminated across contemporary society
Developed insight in the characteristics (possibilities and limitations) of different media of presenting archaeological information (academic books, popular books, websites, apps, games)
An awareness of the different ‘consumer groups’ of archaeological information (general public; education; local and national governments etc) and their particular interests and sensitivities
A basic knowledge of the organizational structure of current Dutch archaeology
Acquired basic knowledge of the basic concepts of archaeological heritage management
A basic understanding of the main ethical issues in archaeological research
Acquired an awareness of the ideological and political dimensions in archaeological research
Have become aware of the political position of archaeologists as well as a critical attitude towards the profession of archaeology", "Course Content
This course aims to provide the basis for a critical assessment of the role of archaeology in contemporary society. Archaeological knowledge about the past is highly subject to manipulation in the present. In this course we will discuss how archaeological questions and research strategies are influenced by modern ideological, political and ethical concerns. The course revolves around four themes: (1) archaeology and politics, (2) landscape and heritage, (3) archaeology and its national infrastructure, (4) public archaeology. Each of these four themes will be explored by several case studies on the basis of which more general discussion will be held.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course will offer two seminars each week of two hours. Individual online or home study precedes each class, in which the topics are subsequently discussed. Of all the four themes offered, the conceptual frames and (inter)national case studies will be treated, and there is a returning structure for each theme: a historiography of the topic, a case study and discussion. Study methods include web classes, powerpoint presentations, reflections and discussions.", "Method of Assessment
Written reflections per theme
Participation in the seminar discussions (completed/non-completed)
Written examination at the end of the course
For regulations concerning resitting these assessments see the course manual.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Archaeology programme. Its students will be specifically trained and tested in reflection and argumentation skills.", "Literature
Articles and web classes as well as the assignments will be accessible through Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is available to 1st year students of archaeology. It is also part of the orientation and specialisation Archaeology within Ancient Studies. Furthermore, it can serve as an elective for students in Ancient Studies and Greek and Latin language and culture, and students of other disciplines like history or ACW. The course is part of the Minor Public Presentation of the Past.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration

course_name: Archaeology of Medieval Europe and the Early Modern World
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After this module you will
Have an overview of important themes in the archaeology of medieval and early modern Europe
Have knowledge of the major archaeological and historical developments in Northwestern Europe in these periods
Be able to place archaeological discoveries and interpretations into a wider historical framework
Be able to summarise and reflect critically on academic literature in a written essay", "Course Content
This module offers insights into the archaeology of North-Western Europe and European global interaction from the start of the Middle Ages to the Early Modern period. Archaeological features and finds, which are shaped by political, social and economic developments are central to this module. We will discuss the archaeology of wider socio-economic processes, such as state formation, Christianization, urbanization, and the growth of exchange networks. Mundane, every-day objects from excavations will play a key role in our discussions. Archaeological phenomena and historical processes are linked, and you will be encouraged to craft archaeological or ‘material histories’ which combine different sources of evidence to throw new light on the past.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (2 x 2 hours per week)", "Method of Assessment
Essay (graded, 40%)
Final exam (graded, 60%)
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Archaeology programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in reading, understanding and processing of academic literature and in writing skills (assignment with academic bibliography).", "Literature
All compulsary reading will be made available on CANVAS", "Additional Information Target Audience
First year students of archaeology.
Elective for students of Ancient History, or History.", "Additional Information
This module builds on the other first year archaeology modules.
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration

course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successful completion of this module, you will be able to
Apply the basic skills of archaeological field work and field recording methods
Identify archaeological features and structures, and show basic knowledge about their interpretation
Demonstrate a good understanding of the aims, methods and results of the archaeological fieldwork project
Write daily reports and a final report to record your understanding of these aims, methods and results
Inform the public about the excavation results
Understand the site's location in the landscape
Demonstrate personal skills in teamwork and collaboration
Understand the basics of the Dutch heritage regulations in archaeology (AMZ) and the quality system (KNA)", "Course Content
Excavation and practicals. Practicals and formal classes in Amsterdam provide information on the field school project and an introduction to the material culture of the Roman, Medieval and Modern periods. The module takes four weeks, of which minimally two will be spent in the field. In the field you will learn excavation techniques, such as levelling, and sectioning settlement features, such as post-holes, ditches, wells and pits. You will not only learn how to handle a shovel and trowel but also how to retrieve information from remains left in the ground. You will be introduced into digital data collection, but you will also learn to make accurate analogue scale drawings of features. Finds are processed during the fieldwork as much as possible. You will write daily reports, as is customary in most digs. The field school takes place on a location outside of Amsterdam, where you will stay during the week.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Formal classes and practicals in Amsterdam
Fieldwork on a location outside Amsterdam, with overnight stay, minimal two weeks", "Method of Assessment
Attendance of the practicals (P/NP) Daily reports (completed/non-completed) Commitment to fieldwork Further Assignments (completed/non-completed) In all four respects conditions must be met in order to pass this course.", "Literature
Literature will be made available via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
1st year students Archaeology
This course is also offered as a restricted choice elective for BA2 Ancient Studies students with specialisation Archaeology and for pre-Master’s programme Archaeology students (on the condition that there are enough places available).", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed.
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note: This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam"]

course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this module, students should
Have become acquainted with research topics in (proto-)historical urban archaeology
Have developed a broader vision on urban developments from the classical to the modern world
Be able to present an overview of the main characteristics of the urban fabric in different periods
Be able to evaluate research data from urban contexts in Europe
Be able to discuss the main problems in the interpretation of the urban archaeological record
Be able to form an opinion on hypotheses brought forward by other scholars", "Course Content
This module will examine cities across Europe from the Greek and Roman world to the Middle Ages and Amsterdam in the Dutch Golden Age. Cities have always been in the centre of social, cultural, and economic and political action. They were the places of innovation, transformation and cross-cultural contact. In every period and every region cities had specific traits, but they all share some basic characteristics. Evaluating these differences and similarities is an important goal of this course. What does a provincial Roman town share with a medieval or a Viking town? As archaeologists we are especially interested in the physical remains of urban settlements in the past, varying from palaces and temples or churches to urban housing of the poor or the activities of craftsmen. We will look at some phenomena recurring in all cities of pre-industrial societies. In this module we will study various approaches to urbanism, always combining archaeology with written evidence as much as possible. Cities are shaped by their society and at the same time they shape this society. Developments in urban environments therefore provide excellent images of past societies as a whole.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (2 hours per week) and seminars (2 hours per week)", "Method of Assessment
Contribution to seminars (pass/fail)
Assignment: oral presentation, as part of Academic Skills (graded, 50%)
Final exam (graded, 50%). This is a closed book exam on the literature discussed. A grade of minimal 5.5 is needed to pass this module.
For regulations concerning resitting these exams/assessments see the course manual.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Archaeology programme. Its students will be specifically trained and tested in formulating research questions and setting up a research outline.", "Literature
Course literature will be announced via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year bachelor students of archaeology;
Students from Saxion University of Applied Science who take the course as part of the preparatory minor Archaeology ('doorstroomminor');
Students who wish to take the course as an elective.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam", "Recommended background knowledge
This module builds on courses of the 1st year archaeology."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of this course is to synthesize a range of science-based methods that are applied to archaeological research. An introduction and basic instruction into the diverse methodology of Science in Archaeology will be presented.
After finishing this course, students will
have acquired specific knowledge of science methods and techniques that are used to answer archaeological research questions;
be able to critically reflect on the potential and limitations of these methods (application, added value, representativeness);
have gained insight into the position of science methods and techniques in archaeology and have acquired knowledge about the most important historical developments in science approaches in archaeology;
have gained practical skills in applying a number of science methods and techniques, in particular in the fields of palaeo-ecology, forensic anthropology and data science;
have learned to analyse datasets obtained using science methods and techniques, to apply appropriate techniques, to evaluate the results, draw conclusions from them and to present them.", "Course Content
In this course, the theoretical and technical basis of various science methods used in Archaeology will be treated, as well as their position within this discipline. Several case studies will show both the potential and the limitations of these methods. Furthermore, practical training will be offered through group and individual assignments. The data sets used during the practicals will come from current research projects at UvA and VU.
The course consists of the following modules:
introduction to science-based methods in archaeology
ecological archaeology (zooarchaeology and archaeobotany)
osteoarchaeology
isotopes and aDNA in archaeology
data analysis and statistics", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, practicals, and tutorials.
Contact hours: 6 hours per week (2h lecture + 2x 2h practicals)", "Method of Assessment
Assessment consists of practical assignments for the listed themes and a (digital) final exam. The resit regulations will be specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Renfrew, C. & P. Bahn 2020. Archaeology: Theories, Methods and Practice (8th Edition). Thames & Hudson. Chapters 6-9 and 11.
Drennan, R. 2009. Statistics for Archaeologists: A Common Sense Approach. Springer. https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-1-4419-0413-3. Chapters 1-6, 12 and 14.
Additional literature and web resources will be provided through Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA2 ACASA Archaeology.
Also available as elective to students in Ancient Studies, History and Anthropology.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam.", "Recommended background knowledge
Environmental Archaeology (BA1 Archaeology)
Material Sources (BA1 Archaeology)"]

course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
On completion of this course, you will have:
acquired a critical understanding of the specific contribution of archaeology and its subdisciplines (e.g. iconography, zooarchaeology, archaeobotany) to the study of ancient religions, in comparison to other disciplines in the humanities, such as theology, anthropology, ancient history and material culture studies;
learnt to apply theoretical notions and concepts related to the study of religion to an archaeological dataset;
gained more detailed knowledge of the most important cult places and the associated material culture, including animal bones and plant remains, in the Mediterranean and Northwest-Europe from c. 800 BC to 250 AD;
gained insight into the origin, development and level of organization of cult communities in the ancient world;
had practical experience of what is required for an academic paper that follows disciplinary conventions and a given stylesheet", "Course Content
This course is about the archaeology of cult places. We discuss a number of key cultic and ritual sites in the Mediterranean and Northwest-Europe in the period from c. 800 BC (the period of the rise of the Greek city-states) to 250 AD (the crisis of the Roman cities of the West). In the lectures various aspects of the materiality of ancient religions will be discussed. In the seminars the students will present case-studies in which these aspects are further explored.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Interactive lectures / seminars (two times 2 hrs per week).", "Method of Assessment
The examination for this course consists of one non-graded assignment and two graded components.
Assignment in week 1 (graded completed/not completed)
Written paper (80%)
To pass this course the assignment for week 1 should have been made and uploaded, while the grade for the written paper should be 5.5 or above. If the written paper is insufficient, you will get the chance to rewrite your essay (the highest grade possible will then be 6.5) or to write an entirely new paper on a different subject.", "Literature
There is no course book with this module. The literature will be announced and/or made available on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for 2nd year BA Archaeology students and for 2nd year BA Ancient Studies who follow the specialization Archaeology. Also students of the 'Doorstroom minor Archeologie' of the Saxion University of Applied Sciences and students of the premaster of Archaeology take this course.", "Additional Information
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Archaeology programme. In this course, students of the programme will be specifically trained and tested in writing skills.
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successfully completing this course, all students
Are able to apply basic concepts and theories from the philosophy of science to the humanities in general and to their own specific discipline, and to use them in critically assessing studies relevant to their own disciplines
Have acquired an overview of the historical development and the most important theoretical approaches of the humanities and of their own specific disciplines
Are able to evaluate the limitations and possibilities of specific disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches in relation to research questions within their own disciplines
Are able to analyze philosophical and theoretical texts relevant to their own discipline, and to relate the concepts involved to their own disciplines
Have practiced discussing philosophical and theoretical concepts during the seminars. They are able to evaluate research papers related to their own discipline from a theoretical/methodological point of view and to form an opinion/take a position in discussions about this among peers.
Have practiced academic writing skills and processing feedback while completing the weekly seminar assignments and leading up to the final assignment. They can reflect critically in writing on the research papers they have read and processed.
GLTC-students (and Ancient Studies students specializing in either Latin or Greek) have gained practical experience with codicology, paleography, text-criticism and literary criticism and are able to reflect critically on methods and theoretical viewpoints in these domains.", "Course Content
Modern academic disciplines are shaped and structured by philosophical concepts and doctrines. This course provides an overview of the history of philosophical thoughts and of philosophical debates about methodology, and their relevance to discussions of methodology, interdisciplinarity, and resource use in philology, cultural history, and archeology of antiquity.
The general theoretical and methodological issues that form the basis of the historical development of science and humanities will be related to the study of the past through texts and material culture. Disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches will be discussed, with special attention to both limitations and possibilities.
This course consists of one lecture and one seminar per week. The lectures are taught by a lecturer of the Department of Philosophy, on the base of a handbook. The seminars are taught by a lecturer from ACASA, and devoted to the discussion of a selection of key themes and relevant articles. Students will be trained in the close reading of philosophical texts that are crucial to the way their (inter)discipline organizes, produces, and structures knowledge.
Students in the programmes of GLTC and Ancient Studies students specializing in either Latin or Greek follow a different seminar, in which the historical developments of the humanities disciplines are more specifically connected to the field of classics. They will focus on (and practice) paleography, text criticism and literary theory.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Weekly lectures (2 hours/week); weekly seminars (2 hours/week)", "Method of Assessment
There will be a written exam for all students based on the handbook and the lectures. (50% of final grade)
In the seminars, the students will work in groups towards a written essay/final assignment (50% of final grade), which is prepared for by means of weekly partial assignments.
The resit regulations will be specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Gerard de Vries & Michiel Leezenberg, History and Philosophy of the Humanities: An Introduction. Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press, 2018. (paperback ISBN: 9789462987630 ; also available as e-book)
Additional literature will be made available during the course", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is for second year BA students of Archaeology (ARCH), Classics (GLTC), and Ancient Studies (OHW).", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Upon completing this course you will have
acquired general knowledge of digital and quantitative methods and techniques that are used to organise archaeological data and to answer archaeological research questions
come to understand the position of digital and quantitative methods and techniques in the archaeological theoretical debate, and learnt about the most important historical developments in digital archaeology
acquired practical skills in applying a number of specific methods and techniques for data collection, data management, analysis and visualisation (in particular databases, GIS and 3D modelling)", "Course Content
In this course, an overview is offered of the position and application of the most essential digital and quantitative methods and techniques in archaeology. Furthermore, students will acquire practical skills during training sessions with group and/or individual assignments. The practical training is based on data from ongoing research at UvA and VU.
Contents of course:
Introduction to and application of
database management and analysis, with emphasis on designing and understanding databases, querying and reporting
GIS, with emphasis on data collection, mapping and basic data analysis
3D modelling in archaeology and heritage", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and practicals four times a week.", "Method of Assessment

The resit regulations will be specified in the study manual.", "Literature

Ulguim, P. (2018). Models and metadata: The ethics of sharing bioarchaeological 3D models online. Archaeologies, 14(2), 189-228. Links to an external site.", "Additional Information Target Audience

course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In this course you will learn to study material and immaterial culture in an integrated way. Attention is paid to material / (cultural) historical, textual and Nachleben- and heritage-related aspects. You visit sites, monuments and museums that are linked to the central theme(s) of the excursion. In this way you obtain a deeper understanding of the long, diachronic lines of cultural history as well as of its synchronous cross-links.", "Course Content
You take introductory lectures on material, (cultural-) historical, textual, and Nachleben- and heritage-related aspects of the excursion destination. In addition, you attend subject-specific seminars (either materially or textually focused), which will further prepare you on aspects of the excursion destination (e.g., use of sources, specific themes, or aspects of the subject literature) and on writing an individual paper or a contribution to the travel guide on a topic related to the excursion destination. During the excursion you will give a presentation based on your paper at a specific site or museum, attempting to address as many of the above aspects as possible in an integrated manner (i.e., material and textual).", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars; excursion (approx. 1 week)", "Method of Assessment
preliminary presentation ('pitch') during preparatory courses (completed/not completed)
contribution to the excursion travel guide (complete/not completed)
on site presentation and discussion (50%)
reflection essay (final report) after excursion (50%)
A minimum of 5.5 must be obtained for each component to pass this module.
The resit regulations will be specified in the course manual.
Important: observe that the assessment procedure may change, pending on the destination and logistics of the excursion. If this is the case, it will be announced in the course manual on Canvas.", "Literature
Selected literature (textual and material sources, specialised literature), distributed via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
2nd year students of Archaeology, Ancient Studies and Classics.", "Additional Information
Students are expected to pay a personal contribution towards the expenses of the excursion of approximately 300 euros; further expenses are covered by a subsidy.
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
Students should register for this course through UvA GLASS during the course registration period for semester 1, even though the course is scheduled to be offered in semester 2. This early registration process is essential for effective course planning.

course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In this course you will:
Gain an understanding of the key historical developments in archaeological theory
Develop a critical understanding of issues and debates in contemporary archaeological theory
Develop the skills and knowledge to assess the value and relevance of theoretical frameworks used in archaeological practice
Discuss and reflect upon theoretical frameworks and historical developments within peer-led groups
Develop the ability to apply archaeological theory to one's own archaeological research", "Course Content
The aim of this course is to provide an intensive undergraduate level introduction to archaeological theory and interpretation. The course will review the historical development of archaeological theory and will explore and evaluate the major interpretative frameworks used by different schools of thought. In addition to attending lectures students will be asked to read and reflect upon theoretically-driven case studies in weekly seminars. It is expressly intended that the student will not only learn a range of theoretical approaches but will also learn how to select and apply archaeological theory to study archaeological materials and human behaviour.
Content will include the following:
Archaeology and culture history
Migrations and diffusion
Processual Archaeology
Post processual archaeology
Practice theory, habitus & agency
Biographical approaches to materials and landscapes
Colonialism and post-colonial archaeologies", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars and lectures, 2 x 2 hours per week", "Method of Assessment
Class Participation (completed/ non-completed);
Oral Presentations (completed/non-completed);
Essay Exam (graded).
This will be a formal closed book-examination about course material and literature.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Archaeology programme. Its students will be specifically trained and tested in more advanced discussion skills (such as chairing, moderating, mediating).
The resit regulations will be specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Key texts:
Johnson, M. 2010. Archaeological Theory, an introduction. Oxford, Blackwell Publishing.
Harris, O.J.T. and Cipolla, C.N. 2017. Archaeological Theory in the New Millennium: Introducing Current Perspective. London and New York, Routledge.
(Additional) literature will be made available on Canvas. Students need to have read the specified texts for class.", "Additional Information Target Audience

Students from Saxion University of Applied Sciences who take the preparatory minor ('doorstroomminor') Archaeology
ACASA students of Classics or Ancient Studies who wish to take the course as an elective and have completed the module What is Archaeology? (BA1 Archaeology)", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successful completion of this module, students will:
Have a basic knowledge concerning the making processes of objects;
Be able to recognize and date the most common ceramic groups from Mediterranean and northwest European contexts;
Have a basic insight into the methods of research;
Be able to formulate basic research questions regarding archaeological finds", "Course Content
Archaeology studies past societies on the basis of material remains found during excavations. In this module you will learn to recognize, describe and interpret archaeological ceramics. The module focuses on Mediterranean as well as the northwest European world, from prehistory to the middle ages and the early modern period. A part of the module is aimed at the interpretation of finds and the formulation of research questions regarding material culture. Case studies will elucidate the research questions. In another part of the module, you will handle archaeological material from the Allard Pierson Museum and ACASA excavations. You will learn to recognize the main ceramic categories, to use typo-chronological schemes and to date sherds. At the end of the module you will know how to analyse finds and be sufficiently well informed to apply these skills in practice.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (2 hours per week) and practicals (4 hours per week). Presence is mandatory.", "Method of Assessment
Four practical assignments (written lab reports) that must be completed to pass the course (graded and pass/fail), and a final practical handbook (graded) that integrates your reading and the methods introduced in the practical assignments. The grading of the final handbook pays attention to skills in document formatting that can be applied to the final thesis of the degree programme.", "Entry Requirements
Students should have participated in the Field School 1 course", "Literature
Parts from:
C. Orton & M. Hughes 2013: Pottery in Archaeology (second edition). Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.
P.M. Rice 2015: Pottery Analysis. A Sourcebook (second edition). Chicago: University of Chicago Press
D. Albero Santacreu 2014: Materiality, Techniques and Society in Pottery Production. De Gruyter Open Press.
For regulations concerning resitting practicals/resubmitting assignments, see the course manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year students of archaeology; students from Saxion University of Applied Science who take the course as part of the preparatory minor ('doorstroomminor') Archaeology; pre-Master students wishing to apply for MA Archaeology.", "Additional Information

This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam.", "Recommended background knowledge
The student is expected to be familiar with the following topics:
relative dating, seriation, typology and classification
artefact production sequences
general chronological frameworks for Mediterranean and northwest European contexts"]

course_name: Past and Present: Critical Approaches to Antiquity and Archaeological Heritage
course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successful completion of this course, you will:
Have broadened your knowledge of antiquity and heritage
Have acquired basic knowledge of the theoretical foundations of the field of heritage studies and its relation to antiquity and archaeology
Have gained a basic knowledge of the practice and structure of heritage management, both nationally (the Netherlands) and internationally
Understand the ideological, political, social and economic values related to the heritage of antiquity and their interaction
Be able to develop a theoretical and practical heritage plan for (tangible or intangible) remains from the past", "Course Content
In this course you are made familiar with the main academic, political and public debates regarding heritage studies and practice. Emphasis will be on the identification of different heritage categories (tangible and intangible) and above all heritage paradigms, from protectionist and conservationist traditions to developmental approaches focusing on the contribution of heritage to socioeconomic and spatial development. In particular, we will explore in this course how these categories and paradigms have relevance for the study of antiquity and archaeology. Central concepts which will be addressed are: heritage, landscape, value, authenticity, appropriation, public participation, conflict, tourism. These will be illustrated and explained through a series of case studies in seminar classes. Particular attention will be paid to the specific role of archaeological heritage in the broader heritage discourse and frameworks.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
In the first two weeks, there are four classes on a specific theme on a theoretical and practical level. For each class, there will be compulsory reading made available through the Canvas site. Each class will consist of a lecture (ca 1 hr) followed by group discussions.
In the third week, there will be no class, but you are supposed to work on the assignment: make an application document for a topic on the ACASA Heritage List.
In the fourth-seventh week the first classes of the week will be regular classes on a specific theme, with assigned compulsory reading. The second classes will be devoted to pitches for the ACASA Heritage List. At the end of these classes, we will vote which topics should be on the ACASA Heritage List. The final vote for the definitive ACASA Heritage List will be done in the last class, followed by discussion.", "Method of Assessment
The compulsory literature will be assessed by a weekly exam question that you will have to submit through the canvas page (completed/ non-completed).
Each student will work out a specific case-study for the ACASA Heritage List. In a pitch of 5-7 minutes, you will present your case (graded). Moreover, you will be asked to react to pitches of your fellow students (non-graded). In case of a student failing this part of the course, an additional extended paper on a different topic will need to be submitted.
In every class, there will be discussion and the final class will be a discussion class. The participation in the discussion will be assessed (completed/ non-completed).
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA programmes Archaeology and Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen). In this course, students of these programmes will be specifically trained and tested in oral presentations (pitches) and in adapting their presentations to a non-specialist audience.
Attendance
It is highly recommended that you attend all discussion classes in order to pass the exam. Attendance is compulsory for the seminar classes in which pitches are presented. In case you miss a seminar, a full point is deducted from the final grade.
For regulations concerning resitting the exams/assignments see the course manual.
Hours to be spent
A total of 140 hours is expected to be spent on the course divided in the following manner:
Reading and studying compulsory literature: 10 hours per week = 60 hours
Attending classes: 3 hours a week: 18 hrs
Preparing Application Document: 20 hrs
Pitch and discussion preparation: 22 hrs
Preparing for participation in final discussion: 20 hrs", "Literature
Articles for the lecture classes will be made available through the CANVAS page", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA students in Archaeology
BA students in Ancient Studies
BA students in Cultural Heritage
BA students in Urban studies and Geography
BA students of the Saxion University of Applied Sciences who follow the preparatory minor ('Doorstroomminor') Archaeology", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam.", "Explanation Canvas
Please consult Canvas before the teaching block starts."]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This course offers BA2 students of the Archaeology programme of ACASA an opportunity to get more familiar with archaeological fieldwork. A detailed description of learning objectives can be found on the Canvas site. The particulars will be determined on an individual basis, in consultation with the course coordinator and with the fieldwork director of your chosen project.
You are able to explain how (part of) the fieldwork contributes to answering the site-level research questions.
You are able to describe the fieldwork project in terms of its value to the public outreach.
You are able to hold a progress meeting about the part of the project in which you are working with your immediate supervisor.
You are able to write daily/trench reports and can argue the decisions made in the field.
You are familiar with the KNA protocols for desk research, field survey and excavation (soil and sediment). You are able to explain the difference between conducting archaeological fieldwork in Pleistocene and Holocene contexts", "Course Content
In this module you can participate in one of the interesting and exciting ACASA fieldwork projects. Further information about these projects and the possibilities they offer will be made available to the students on the Canvas page of the module. course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Als eindwerkstuk vormt de bachelorscriptie de laatste fase van de gecombineerde verwerving van de verschillende vaardigheden die studenten in staat stelt om zelfstandig een eenvoudig onderzoek op te zetten en uit te voeren. Het doel van het vak is om de studenten op een aantal deelaspecten daarbij te ondersteunen, en te laten reflecteren op kennis van, inzicht in en overzicht over de belangrijkste vraagstukken van hun eigen discipline, hun onderzoeksvaardigheden, oordeelsvorming en presentatievaardigheden, en hen de instrumenten te verschaffen om deze inzichten, kennis en vaardigheden waar nodig te verhogen, zodat ze het niveau bereiken dat nodig is voor een eventuele academische vervolgopleiding.", "Course Content
De bachelorscriptie vormt de afronding van de bacheloropleiding. Hierin laten studenten, aan de hand van een eindwerkstuk over een zelf gekozen onderwerp op het terrein van de Archeologie, zien dat zij onder begeleiding van een docent in staat zijn om zelfstandig een eenvoudig onderzoek op te zetten en uit te voeren. Door middel van dit eindwerkstuk worden de eindtermen van de opleiding op het gebied van kennis en inzicht in de eigen discipline, onderzoeksvaardigheden, oordeelsvorming en presentatie getoetst.
De bachelorscriptie is een individueel eindwerkstuk, dat inhoudelijk begeleid wordt door een individuele scriptiebegeleider. Daarnaast dienen studenten deel te nemen aan het Bachelorscriptiecolloquium.
Zie voor verdere informatie over scriptie en scriptietraject de beschrijving op de UvA Canvas site van het gemeenschappelijke Bachelorscriptiecolloquium voor ACASA Bachelorstudenten (vakcode 13802A035Y).", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Werkgroepbijeenkomsten in december (introductie) en in blok 4 en blok 5, met opdrachten. NB: de werkgroepbijeenkomsten hebben het karakter van een praktische oefening, en deelname is verplicht..
Individuele begeleiding.", "Method of Assessment
De bachelorscriptie wordt als schriftelijk eindwerkstuk op zichzelf beoordeeld op grond van een aantal parameters betreffende wetenschappelijkheid, vraagstelling, omgang met primaire bronnen, secundaire literatuur, helderheid, argumentatie, stijl en aard van presentatie, zelfstandigheid. Dit wordt afzonderlijk getoetst door twee docenten, die vervolgens samen tot een eindoordeel en cijfer komen.
In geval van een onvoldoende heeft de student recht op één herkansing door middel van revisie van eindwerkstuk. Als de beoordeling ook daarna onvoldoende is, zal de student een nieuwe scriptie moeten schrijven over een nieuw onderwerp.
Zowel de bachelorscriptie als de deelname aan het scriptiecolloquium moeten met een voldoende (of AVV) worden afgerond.", "Entry Requirements
Studenten moeten alle verplichte vakken van het eerste jaar en het tweede jaar hebben afgerond.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Derdejaars bachelorstudenten Archeologie. Alle ACASA bachelorstudenten die willen afstuderen dienen zich bij de UvA in te tekenen voor het algemene scriptievak ‘BA scriptie ACASA’ (vakcode 13802A035Y).
Dit vak Bachelor Thesis Archaeology (vakcode L_AABAARESCR) is alleen bestemd voor VU studenten en dient om de BA-scriptie Archeologie in te leveren zodat deze op plagiaat gecheckt kan worden. Je levert je scriptie in via Canvas. Zorg ervoor dat je bij de VU ingetekend bent op dit vak, zodat je toegang hebt tot de betreffende Canvasomgeving bij de VU. Intekenen op dit scriptievak kan het gehele jaar door.", "Explanation Canvas
Alle informatie over en opdrachten i.v.m. de bachelorscriptie worden bij elkaar gezet in één gezamenlijke Canvasomgeving voor studenten van de drie ACASA-bacheloropleidingen (Archeologie, GLTC en Oudheidwetenschappen), geheten "BA-scriptie ACASA-opleidingen" (vakcode 13802A035Y). De Canvas sites van de scriptiemodules van de afzonderlijke opleidingen worden alleen gebruikt voor het uploaden van de definitieve versie van de scriptie en een controle op plagiaat."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Archaeology
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
How to make the leap from an archaeological excavation to an academic publication of this fieldwork? In this course, you will learn how to process and analyse fieldwork data and write a report, compliant to academic standards. All your knowledge and skills you have acquired in the past two years of your study will come together in this project, the focus of which will lie on synthesis and collaboration. The writing of a basic fieldwork report is closely linked to archaeological practice in the present field of work, and will prepare you for a function as archaeological fieldwork professional.
You will be asked to write a plan for the research project (including research questions), to select and analyse field work data and write a report of your findings.", "Course Content
In this course, you will work as a team and publish part of an excavation. There will be two teams: one will be publishing a part of a Mediterranean excavation, and another one of an excavation in Northwestern Europe, according to your own specialization.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Each week, you will participate in two practical sessions of two hours each. Besides this, you will have to do a substantial part of the work outside of the classes. During the sessions, you will learn about the excavation sites and about general subjects which are relevant to the interpretation of fieldwork data (formation processes, methodology etc). Also, you will acquire processing and analystical skills you need for your project. The last few sessions will consist of presentations of your research and feedback of the teachers on your progress.", "Method of Assessment
Assignments (completed/non-completed), time management (completed/non-completed), report (graded). End grades are numerical (0-10). Resit regulations will be specified in the course manual.", "Literature
To be announced.", "Additional Information Target Audience
