course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
During this course and after completing it, students will:
develop a familiarity with the history of Latin America since the late eighteenth century.
acquire knowledge from (and critically assess) academic literature.
be able to recognize historiographical debates in the field.
apply historical knowledge acquired in previous courses to further examine the peculiarities of Latin American history in a global context.
understand and discuss primary sources (translated into English, in case of written sources) in their historical context.
use their historical knowledge to understand and take a critical stance in contemporary discussions in and about Latin America.
be able to effectively communicate their ideas in oral form.
further develop their academic writing skills, by preparing a final paper based on a critical historiographic survey", "Course Content
This course offers students an introduction to the history of modern Latin America. Starting with the period of revolutions that swept through the region in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, it discusses the main political, social, and economic developments that shaped its history in the last two centuries. Avoiding a juxtaposition of national cases and events, the course develops a global and transnational perspective that focuses on several crucial aspects, including the processes of state-building and economic transformation, the consequences of internal and international migrations and displacements, the development of nationalist and populist ideologies, the recurrence of military dictatorships, and the victories and defeats of revolutionary movements. Moreover, it pays particular attention to the relationship between Latin America and other regions of the world, in particular Western Europe and the United States.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Two sessions per week. Students should come to the meetings prepared to actively discuss the readings.", "Method of Assessment
Participation in class + assignments about primary sources + final research paper", "Literature
Chasteen, John C. Born in Blood & Fire: A Concise History of Latin America. Fourth edition. New York: W.W. Norton & Company, 2016.
Students will also read a selection of book chapters, articles, and primary sources that will be available via the VU Library and/or in Canvas.
Additionally, students will be encouraged to discuss a selection of Latin American films, music, art, and literature.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA2 students History and International Studies and Geschiedenis.
The course is open as an elective course for VU-students and exchange students."]

course_name: The Middle East in Contemporary History
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students can:
demonstrate historical-political trajectories that constitute contemporary Middle East,
analytically debate Orientalism and engage with misrepresentations of the Middle East through works of revolutionary/social justice-oriented thinkers from Nazik Al-Abid, Abdul Rahman Al-Kawakibi to Edward Said and from the Middle East.
define the notion of Empire as a mode of persistent domination that remains in effect in the Middle East.", "Course Content
In the midst of what ICJ called a plausible genocide in Gaza, some in the Global North said, 'the situation in the Middle East should not divide us'; however, the question remains: what and where is this Middle East? This course addresses these questions by diving into the Middle East's historiographies, histories and memories to open up its political-historical construction. The course discusses how past and present influence the armed conflicts in the Middle East and how historiographies have shaped the dominant imagination of the Global North about the peoples of the Middle East.
This course unpacks the notion of Empire and Dispossession through revolutionary thinkers whose criticism of colonialism shaped colonial struggles against French and British mandates in the Middle East and their legacy have enabled resistance against Middle Eastern authoritarian regimes and also Israel as the ongoing colonial settler project. Furthermore, it shows Empire is mode of persistent domination that impacts of decolonized nations through cultural framing, Racialisations and border regimes.
This course engages with Middle Eastern thinkers such as Nazik Al-Abid, Abdul Rahman Al-Kawakibi to Edward Said to introduce Orientalism and Islamophobic framing of Muslims and peoples of the contemporary Middle East. The course also discusses Racism and Aryanism within the Middle East (the case of Iran), and it ends by engaging the cultural politics of images, visuals, aesthetics and objects in and from the Middle East.
This course operates through academic dialogues that begin from the point of view of dispossessed and colonised peoples such as Palestinians and engages with literature that radically criticised and dismantled perspectives of the Dominant.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
This course partially uses the flipping classroom method, which means students receive content in advance and discuss it in class during group discussions or in conversations with the teacher. Attendance is mandatory, and students missing two lectures will be given extra assignments and tasks to compensate for their absence. Students missing three lectures will not be allowed to finish the course.", "Method of Assessment
Students will deliver three assignments: 10% (a freestyle essay on historical visual representations of the Middle East), 45% (an essay introducing one of the key revolutionary critical and social justice-oriented thinkers of the Middle East), and 45% (a final paper/essay or an open book exam). The overall word count of assessments (min 4000 words and max 5000 words)", "Literature
Please refer to the course manual", "Recommended background knowledge
Students are recommended to familiarise themselves with news outlets such as Aljazeera International, the map of the Middle East and sectarian differences in Islam."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In the course of their study of Themes in Political History, students will:
develop a familiarity with major topics in modern political history,
develop their ability to identify and evaluate contemporary cultural and/or media mobilisations of topics in political history,
acquire knowledge from and critically assess academic literature,
be able to build their own research topic on a theme in political history,
be able to formulate arguments in written form,
be able to effectively communicate their ideas in oral form.", "Course Content
This course offers students an introduction to ‘big’ themes in modern political history that might include violence, (in)equality, citizenship, freedom and responsibility, ideologies or social movements. The course explores the themes through historical case studies from Europe, Asia and Oceania to underline the global and transnational connections as well as specificities of political histories. Each topic is examined at three levels: first, historical actors’ understandings of the politics of their own actions; second, how scholars have explained ‘the political’ in these histories; and third, how the past is mobilised in the present for contemporary political purposes. We therefore examine primary sources, historiography and contemporary representations and debates around each major theme. The course encourages students to critically evaluate the political as a category of historical action, as well as an approach to the past, and a way of understanding its relevance to the present.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
1 lecture and 1 seminar per module, plus class discussions and presentations. Students must be prepared to actively discuss the work they prepared for class.", "Method of Assessment
Class participation (10%), module assignments (50%), final essay (40%).", "Literature
A selection of book chapters, articles, and primary sources will be made available via the VU Library and/or in Canvas.", "Additional Information
BA2 students History and International Studies and Geschiedenis.
The course is also open as an elective course for VU-students and Exchange Students."]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After finishing this course, the student:
knows written and oral elementary Arabic language utterances and can understand and use them; (knowledge, insight and skill);
is able to recognize, understand and use written and oral language utterances in Arabic (knowledge, insight and skill);
is able to apply these elementary grammatical constructions of those lessons in Arabic;
is able to have a simple elementary conversation in standard Arabic and to present him/herself;
is be able to understand and to translate a short Arabic text.", "Course Content
During Arabic I, the students will study: the alphabet, elementary spelling (short and long vowels, shadda), the article, spelling of the hamza, spelling of the alif (alif al-madda and al-maqṣūra), gender, cases, the personal pronoun, suffixes of the person, the adjective, the nisba noun, the interrogative pronouns, the particles of jarr, the concept “to have”. In addition, simple reading texts are regularly distributed in the lessons to prepare at home and to read together in class. In class, Arabic is used as the language of instruction as much as possible. In addition, short dialogue exercises are offered.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars.
For complete language acquisition, the student must be exposed to all elements of the language, including: reading, writing, listening and speaking. This is crucial to gaining an overall competency and fluency in Arabic. In each course, a dictation will be done. This exercise is precious and essential at the beginning of the language learning.", "Method of Assessment
Homework will be given for each next course and must be send to the teacher before the course. Seriousness, rigour and attendance result in a bonus for the student in his global average at the end of the period.
Assessments consist of:
Assignment (25%)
Oral exam (25%)
Final exam of 3 hours consisting of oral and written expression and comprehension (50%)
Oral participation and homework (bonus)", "Literature
There is no book to purchase for this module. All teaching material will be provided by the teacher.", "Additional Information Target Audience
The course is part of the Bachelor Theology and Religious Studies: track Islam, and of the Minor Arabic and Sources of Islam.", "Additional Information
After three absences without justification, the student willautomatically fail the final exam and will have to take the resit to complete this course.", "Custom Course Registration
You can only register for this course if you are enrolled in the minor Arabic and Sources of Islam, or if you are taking the Islam track (part of the bachelor of Theology and Religious Studies), the Free Choice track (part of the bachelor of Theology and Religious Studies) or the History and International Studies track (part of the bachelor History).", "Recommended background knowledge
This course is designed for students without prior knowledge of Arabic. We will start from the level 0, so there is no need for a specific background knowledge."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (8)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The end goal of Elementary Latin 1 and 2 is to translate and read relatively simple Latin historical sources from ancient to postclassical times. At the end of Elementary 1, students:
Have a basic Latin vocabulary and understanding of elementary morphology and syntax
Are able to use instruments such as dictionaries/glossaries, annotations, grammars/overviews of morphology and syntax
Are able to translate simple Latin sentences
Are able to paraphrase simple Latin texts at section level
Have insight in the value of reading Latin texts in the primary language for understanding the meaning and value of historical sources", "Course Content
The course Elementary Latin 1 (6 ECTS) introduces you to Latin on a basic level. Students memorize a glossary and complete exercises on morphology and syntax. They train their skills in translating and interpreting small Latin texts. During the course, they are introduced to relatively simple textual sources, with a focus on medieval texts. They also learn about the importance of reading sources in the primary language to understand the meaning and historical value.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars (2 x 2 hours a week).", "Method of Assessment
Written exams: half-term test (30%) and final exam (70%). The resit in the resit period covers both tests (= 100 %); resits of one of the partial exams are not possible.", "Entry Requirements
The course is intended for students with no prior knowledge of Latin. The course is therefore not open to students with a Dutch 'eindexamen Latijn' or comparable secondary school certificates (e.g. British GCE level).", "Literature
Study materials will be distributed through Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
The course is open to
BA 2 students in History and International Studies
BA students in Ancient Studies (who can take it as an elective)
Minor students and other elective students", "Recommended background knowledge
The course is intended for students with no prior knowledge of Latin. The course is therefore not open to students with a Dutch eindexamen Latijn or comparable secondary school certificates (e.g. British GCE level)."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (8)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The students are able to successfully handle uncomplicated oral and written tasks in a wide number of basic social situations;
The students are able to understand uncomplicated speech and texts about some basic topics;
The students can describe in simple (yet grammatically correct) terms aspects of their background, immediate environment and matters in areas of immediate need;
The students can communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar and routine matters;
The students can write short, simple texts; their grammar and spelling are correct;
The students master the most basic structures of French grammar and are able to explain them in their own words;
The students gain basic knowledge of French-speaking countries or settings, and are able to handle some intercultural communication skills.
The aimed CERF level at the end of the course is A1 (basic).", "Course Content
This is an online course. Students learn to handle a variety of basic communicative tasks, including understanding spoken French, speaking French, reading texts and writing short – yet grammatically correct – texts. Students will train sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of most immediate relevance (e. g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, food). Students learn essential verbs, nouns and cases while working to build vocabulary and learn the basics of French grammar, syntax and spelling. Students practice listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Students will also be introduced to French culture through short texts and videos from the internet, TV, magazines and newspapers.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars (2×2 hours per week): discussion of assigned readings and language exercises; practical training; self study.", "Method of Assessment
Mandatory weekly assignments (25%) and final oral exam (75%). Contrary to the standard exam schedule, resits of the oral exam French 1 will take place in week 7 of period 2. In this way, students will have the possibility to retake the French 1 exam before they participate in the French 2 exam.", "Literature
Édito A1 Course book (newest edition, 2022): ISBN 978-2278104468.
Édito A1 Exercise book (newest edition, 2022): ISBN 978-2278103652.
You must have your own copy of both books before the start of the course.
IMPORTANT: Please make sure that you purchase the right edition (2022): check the ISBN!", "Additional Information Target Audience
Anybody who is interested in discovering their French;
BA 2 students in History and International Studies.", "Additional Information
PLEASE NOTE:
This is a 100% online course.
This course is worth 6 EC. According to European regulations, 1 EC represents 25 to 30 hours of study (including class attendance, mandatory weekly assignments, and exams). This means that you will need to spend 150 to 180 hours if you want to pass, even if you have prior knowledge of French.
This course is highly focused on grammar.
Some students may experience this course as challenging.
If you decide to enroll in this course, you have read and understood this Course Description and the Study Guide (the latter will be available on Canvas end of July)."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (48); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Artificial Intelligence; Biology; Biomedical Sciences; Business Administration; Business Analytics; Chemistry; Communication Science; Communication and Information Studies; Computer Science; Creative Technology; Criminology; Cultural Anthropology and Development Sociology; Earth Sciences; Earth Sciences, Economics and Sustainability; Econometrics and Data Science; Econometrics and Operations Research; Economics and Business Economics; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; Health Sciences; Health and Life Sciences; History; Human Movement Sciences; Information Sciences; International Business Administration; Law; Law in Society; Literature and Society; Mathematics; Mechanical Engineering; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Medical Natural Sciences; Pedagogical Sciences; Pharmaceutical Sciences; Philosophy; Physics and Astronomy; Political Science; Psychology; Public Administration and Organization Science; Science, Business & Innovation; Sociology; Theology and Religious Studies
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
1. Knowledge
You are able to describe factors in the spread of English in the world and the ways in which varieties of English have evolved world-wide. You are also able to describe some of the social consequences of Global English (e.g. language loss, social inequality).
2. Skills
Within theories of language variation and change, you are able to analyse some of the major linguistic features of varieties of English around the world.
3. Attitude
You are able to present a well-informed perspective of the nature of different Englishes and the impact of the global spread of English on people in societies around the world.
4. Communication
You are able to report on topics in Global English in short oral presentations and in writing.
5. Competence
You are able to identify people’s needs regarding the English language, including your own, and you are able to decide on the best way to act upon it.", "Course Content
In the lectures, we will examine the spread of the English language around the world. We will begin with regions in the world where English is spoken as a first language (England, the Celtic countries, the U.S., Australia, etc.). We will then move on to regions where English is spoken as a second language (Africa and Asia), and from there to regions where English is used as a foreign language or a lingua franca (e.g. The Netherlands, Europe, Japan, and so on).
We will explore a range of issues in the global spread of English. These include: linguistic issues (variation in English, World Englishes), social issues ( language and identity, language and power, language death, linguistic exclusion and discrimination), and literary concerns (the use of English in postcolonial literature).
Some of the lectures are presented by guest lecturers from Scotland, Australia, Uganda and Japan.
In the seminar, we will address questions that have arisen from the lectures or the reading and we will discuss course work.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (2 hours per week) and seminars (2 hours per week)", "Method of Assessment
Course work, marked in/complete. You will obtain the course objectives (1-5) by working with the course work.
Exam, graded (100% of your grade for the course). Your attainment of course objectives (1-3) will be assessed in the exam.
To successfully complete the course, you must obtain a grade of ≥5,5 for the exam and have submitted mandatory course work by the set deadline.
1 absence from the seminars is allowed.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have passed Academic English CIS-L&S Writing and Academic English CIS-L&S: Grammar.
Students must also have participated in English: International Communication.", "Literature
Schneider, E.W. 2020. English Around The World. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. Second edition.
Other literature and materials will be made available in Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
CIS students, Literature & Society students, students in the Minor 'English', History students, premaster- and exchange students.", "Custom Course Registration
This course has seminars, but you cannot self-register for a seminar in VU-net. If you want to know the days/times at which the seminars have been scheduled, go to rooster.vu.nl; click the 'Options' button at the right-hand side of the course title and select ‘Choose groups’.
A couple of weeks before the start of the course, your course coordinator will invite you to sign up for a seminar via Canvas."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (8)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Acquiring knowledge of and insight into the sound system, word formation processes and sentence structures of Moroccan Arabic. Developing basic conversation skills in Moroccan Arabic (the spoken language of large regions in Morocco, including most of the major cities). The goal of this course is to reach level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR). At the end of this course, you will be able to communicate in Moroccan Arabic about simple and daily life matters, such as introducing yourself, describing your family situation and housing situation, asking people for directions, and ordering food in a restaurant.", "Course Content
Language skills classes. We will not pay attention to written language as Moroccan Arabic is a language variety that is only used for oral communication.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
2 x 2 hours of language classes per week.", "Method of Assessment
Oral and written exam. The oral exam represents two thirds of your final grade and the written exam one third. Both components must be graded at least 5.5.", "Literature
Hoogland, J. (2018). The Routledge introductory course in Moroccan Arabic.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Anybody who wants to learn the basics of spoken Moroccan Arabic.
The course is also open to BA 2 students in History and International Studies.", "Additional Information
The language of instruction is English."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (8)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Introduces you to the Spanish language on a basic level which is level A1 of active language skills and level A2 of passive language skills (CEFR). Get a basic knowledge of all the grammar and vocabulary of the book that is used. On completing this course students can participate in simple conversations, read and understand simple texts and write a short text about every day subjects.", "Course Content
The minor course Spanish 1 (6ec) introduces you to the Spanish language on a basic level. You will reach level A1 of active language skills and level A2 of passive language skills (CEFR). This means that you can participate in simple conversations, read and understand simple texts and write a short text about every day subjects.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Two 90 minutes seminars per week. Please note: 80% attendance is compulsory: you cannot miss more than three lectures.", "Method of Assessment
Written exam", "Literature
Aula Internacional Plus 1. Corpas, Jaime et al. Uitgeverij Talenland (Publishers) aulainternacional.difusion.com", "Additional Information Target Audience
The minor Spanish is open to all bachelor students, including BA 2 students History and International Studies. If you are a master student you are also allowed to follow this course but do not forget: your credits in Spanish do not count for your master program.", "Additional Information
In this course all lectures are in English language."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Dutch Language is intended for FGW/HIS students: they receive curricular credits for this.
The goal is to learn Dutch to use, to improve your general oral and written language skills. Communication objectives can be linked to the levels of the CEFR.
Dutch language is not a course Dutch linguistics. Everything is focused on communication and language use. Of course you will learn something about grammar and phonology, but not on an academic theoretical level.
For students who do not yet speak Dutch, the intended end goal is A2+. If you start at a higher level, the intended language proficiency level is also higher. You will receive 12 credits if you have made sufficient effort (attendance and homework) and have passed two courses, one intensive day course and one semi-intensive evening course, regardless of the level you reach.
For Dutch Language you do one intensive day course (4x per week lesson) and one less intensive evening course (2x per week lessons).
Day courses:
0 - A2: lessons on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday; 3 contact hours per lesson, at least 3 hours of homework per lesson.
A2 - B1: classes on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday; 3 contact hours per lesson, at least 3 hours of homework per lesson.
B1 - B1+: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
B1+ - B2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
Evening courses:
0 - A1: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
A1 - A2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
A2 - A2+: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
A2+ B1: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
B1 - B1+: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
B1+ - B2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
Special courses:
Evening - Sprint for students who speak fluent German: 0 - A2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
Evening: Professional Dutch 1 and 2 for students who have B2 level: B2 - B2+ / B2+ C1; lessons on Tuesday or Wednesday evening, 3 hours per lesson, at least 3 hours of homework per lesson.
Below are three examples of the possibilities, so you do at least one day and one evening course from our program.
NB One week before the academic year we start with the intensive day course!
A. You don't speak Dutch yet. In the first period you start the day course level 1 to A2 (4 mornings per week lessons). In our period 2 (mid-November to the end of January) you will do the next course in the evening, level 2.1, to A2 (2 evenings a week).
B. You already speak and write Dutch at A1 level. In the first period you do level 1.2) in the evening to A2 (2 evenings a week). Then you do level 2 in the day course, to B1 (4 mornings per week lessons).
C. You already speak and write Dutch at B1 level. In the first period you do level 3 (3x a week lessons) in the day course to B1+. Then you do level 4 in the evening course, to B2 (2x a week lessons).", "Course Content
In the two course periods of 'Dutch as a second language' you will learn to communicate in Dutch on the basis of concrete language tasks. At home, you prepare the tasks with the book and online: you do vocabulary exercises, read short texts and listen to dialogues.
In the classroom, you work towards being able to complete the tasks. You practice with the words, grammar and pronunciation and do speaking assignments together with other students. You will also learn something about Dutch society and culture.
The exact course content (which language tasks you learn to perform and which themes are discussed) depends on your intake level.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Dutch language is about practicing skills, to acquire a certain level of proficiency. Therefore, attendance is mandatory. To earn credits, attendance must be at least 80%.
For Dutch Language, you follow one intensive day course (9 weeks, 4 lessons per week) and one less intensive evening course (8 weeks, 2 lessons per week).
The lessons (work groups) are interactive. In a group of maximum 20 students of your own level, you practice communicative language tasks which you prepare at home (you practise the vocabulary and do reading and listening assignments at home). You practice words, grammar and pronunciation and do speaking assignments in groups with other students. Your teacher speaks Dutch as much as possible, also when giving explanations and feedback. Individual feedback is mainly given on homework tasks (writing and speaking assignments).
Homework is important: you prepare for the lessons and do homework assignments after the lessons. Self-study: during the intensive daytime course, you spend at least 12 hours on homework, in the evening course at least 5 hours.", "Method of Assessment
To obtain 12 credits, the student meets the following requirements:
* Attendance: at least 80%.
* Compulsory homework done, according to the homework schedule.
* Passed the final exams of two course periods. In the final tests, we test vocabulary and all language skills.
Offline education: five tests:
vocabulary
writing skills
speaking/reading skills
listening skill
reading comprehension
In the case of an online course:
vocabulary
listening and speaking assessment
reading and writing assessment", "Literature
We use Code+. Which part you need to buy depends on the course you are taking. Above A2, you will also need the Van Dale pocket dictionary Nederlands als tweede taal (Nt2).", "Additional Information Target Audience
You will be placed in a group with 'regular' VU-NT2 students: in the daytime course these are mainly refugees, in the evening course these are (exchange) students, expats, and other migrants.", "Additional Information
If your language level allows you to start with an evening course, consult your study advisor to see if this fits into your programme. For most HIS students, starting with the intensive day course (end of August!) fits best into the programme. Please note that the course starts one week before the normal academic year.", "Custom Course Registration
Step 1: Students History and International Studies should notify dr. Chiel van den Akker before 1st July that they would like to take this module (c.m.vanden.akker@vu.nl).
Step 2: Apply via the website of VU-NT2: https://nt2.vu.nl/en/application/index.aspx. Fill in the application form. Don't forget to mention that you are a HIS student.
VU-NT2 will inform you about the procedure (intake, course dates etc). Do you have questions? Please send an e-mail to vu-nt2@vu.nl.", "Explanation Canvas
Bij de start van de cursusperiode krijg je een uitnodiging om deel te nemen aan de Canvascursus. Hierop plaatsen we het huiswerk. Je levert je huiswerk ook in via Canvas. Verder vind je hier de regels, allerlei nuttige informatie en tips om de taal goed te leren.", "Recommended background knowledge
It is easier to learn the language at this fast pace if you have previously learned another foreign language at school."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (2)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After finishing this course, the student:
has developed reading, writing and communication skills in Arabic;
is able to consolidate the achievements of Arabic I (one);
has acquired new grammatical rules and new elementary vocabulary to understand simple Classical Arabic texts as well as Modern Standard Arabic;
is able to form and understand sentences with grammatical structures;
is able to understand and translate a simple Arabic text;
is able to product a short text in Arabic from the material studied
during the courses.", "Course Content
In Arabic II, we will study: the regular and irregular plural, the declension, the nominal and verb sentence, the present tense, the past tense, the negation, the agreement between particles and suffix pronouns. In addition, simple reading texts are regularly distributed in the lessons to prepare at home and to read together in class. The
programme is provisional and is susceptible to change according the circumstances.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course is part of the Bachelor Theology and Religious Studies: track Islam, and of the Minor Arabic and Sources of Islam. For complete language acquisition, the student must be exposed to all elements of the language, including: reading, writing, listening and speaking. This is crucial to gaining an overall competency and fluency in Arabic. In class, Arabic is used as the language of instruction as much as possible. In addition, short dialogue exercises are offered.", "Method of Assessment
Translations, grammatical exercises, short essays and other works are regularly distributed in the lessons to do at home and correct in class. In addition, short dialogue exercises are offered. Homework will be given for each next course and have to be sent to the teacher before the course. Seriousness, rigour and attendance result in a bonus for the student in his global average at the end of the period.
Regarding the grading, it consists of:
- Assignment (25%)
- Oral exam (25%)
- Final exam of 3 hours consisting of oral/listening comprehension and written expression/comprehension (50%)
- Oral participation and homework (bonus)", "Literature
There is no book to purchase for this course. All teaching material will be provided by the teacher.", "Additional Information
After three absences without justification, the student will automatically fail the final exam and will have to take the resit to complete this course.", "Custom Course Registration
You can only register for this course if you are enrolled in the minor Arabic and Sources of Islam, or if you are taking the Islam track (part of the bachelor of Theology and Religious Studies), the Free Choice track (part of the bachelor of Theology and Religious Studies) or the History and International Studies track (part of the bachelor History).", "Recommended background knowledge
The student must have successfully completed the course Arabic I."]

["Course Objective
The end goal of Elementary Latin 1 and 2 is to translate and read relatively simple Latin historical sources from ancient to postclassical times. At the end of Elementary 2, students:
Have a basic Latin vocabulary and understanding of elementary morphology and syntax
Are able to use instruments such as dictionaries/glossaries, annotations, grammars/overviews of morphology and syntax
Are able to translate simple Latin sentences into English
Are able to paraphrase simple Latin texts at section level

course_programmes: Hide full list (8)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The students are able to successfully handle oral and written tasks in a wide number of social situations;
The students can understand the main ideas of more complicated texts on concrete topics;
The students can produce short texts on a range of issues. Their grammar and spelling are correct;
The students master more basic structures of French grammar and are able to explain them in their own words;
The students gain basic knowledge of culture in French-speaking countries and are able to handle some intercultural communication skills.
The aimed CEFR level at the end of the course is advanced A1/early A2.", "Course Content
This online course aims at improving and developing skills and strategies to enable students to handle successfully more demanding oral and written tasks in French (Common European Framework of Reference for Languages level A1+/early A2). Students will learn to understand the main points of clear standard input on familiar matters regularly encountered in work, school, leisure, etc. Students will learn to handle many situations likely to arise whilst traveling in an area where the language is spoken. Students will learn to produce simple, yet grammatically correct texts on topics that are familiar or of personal interest. They can describe experiences and events, and briefly give reasons and explanations for opinions and plans. Students will increase their general vocabulary of verbs, nouns, articles and prepositions while gaining a greater knowledge of complex problems in French grammar, syntax and spelling. Students will continue to learn about French culture through a range of authentic documents.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods

course_programmes: Hide full list (48)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Regarding pronunciation:
1) You will be able to describe the most common difficulties in English pronunciation, as well as four major aspects of speech fluency in English.
2) You will also be able to explain the effects of particular pronunciation features on the intelligibility and credibility of spoken English.
3) You will be able to analyse and develop aspects of pronunciation and speech fluency in your own spoken English, as well as in that of your peers whom you will support.
4) You are are able to present a well-informed view of the nature of of different English pronunciations showing appreciation of diversity in English.
Regarding presentation:
1) You will be able to strategically apply structural elements, prosodic features and conversational patterns in such a way that they will help you convey a clear message.
2) You will also be able to help and support others in presentation work.
By the end of the course, you will be able to adapt pronunciation features in the English pronunciation that you wish to develop and you are able to confidently give an oral presentation.", "Course Content
Pronunciation:
1) We will set goals for the English pronunciation that you wish to develop both at a professional and at a personal level.
2) We will analyse the most common difficulties in English pronunciation and the effects that these difficulties may (inadvertently) have on the intelligibility and credibility of spoken English. We will also take account of the role of pronunciation features in identity construction.
3) You will conduct exercises, practise ear-training and be given tools that help you analyse English pronunciation features, as well as speech fluency.
4) You will work with features in your own spoken English accordingly.
Presentation:
1) Students give presentations on academic topics. During these presentations they will show awareness and some mastery over the following elements:
structure that conveys an academic idea and its relevance and adheres to a time limit
prosodic features (intonation, voice, articulation, etc.)
body language (posture, eye-contact, etc.)
persuasive and conversational patterns (repetition, rhetorical questions, etc.)
2) Students engage in useful ways with their peers, offering feedback and working collaboratively
3) Students demonstrate awareness of their strengths and weakness with regards to the topics and skills addressed in the course.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Pronunciation: weekly interactive lectures (1,5 hour) and seminars (1,5 hours).
Presentation: weekly seminars (3 hours).", "Method of Assessment
For pronunciation: course work (marked in/complete) and a recording of your own English pronunciation (graded, 50% of your course grade).
You will obtain the pronunciation course objectives (1-4) by working with the course work. Course objective (3) is assessed in the recording.
For presentation (all graded for an average grade for presentation; 50% of your course grade):
A series of group and individual presentations (65%)
Peer review (25%)
Self-reflection paper (10%)
The presentation course objectives (1-2) will be attained through these components.
In order to successfully complete the course students must score a grade of ≥5.5 for Pronunciation and Presentation each.
Course attendance and submission of the all of the course work by the set deadlines is conditional for being awarded a grade for the pronunciation recording and the presentation components. 1 absence from the Pronunciation and Presentation seminars each is allowed.", "Literature
Literature and other materials will be made available in Canvas.
The pronunciation module is accompanied by online audio and video material (https://english-pronunciation.weebly.com).", "Additional Information Target Audience
Students across the university who wish to work on their English pronunciation and presentation skills."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (48)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successful completion of the course students will feel confident that they can write a bachelor dissertation in English and embark on a Master's degree where English is the language of tuition. Specifically, the course aims to help students in:
getting more practice in writing formal, academic English;
developing reading skills which will allow them to note linguistic and structural features of relevant academic text types in their own discipline;
gaining insight into how specific linguistic structures can contribute to text coherence and text cohesion;
acquiring greater knowledge of the stylistic and rhetorical aspects of written formal texts;
getting greater insight into the strengths and weaknesses of their English writing skills, and knowledge of how to further develop strengths and reduce weaknesses.", "Course Content
For this course we focus on your position as a writer in the academic world, i.e. as someone who is engaged in academic discourse. This means that you need to be aware of appropriate structures at sentence level as well as at text level, of ways of using language to refer to other writers, and of ways of using academic language effectively. The emphasis in this course is on (a) gaining more insight into the language and style of your own academic discipline, (b) improving coherence, compactness and readability, and (c) expanding your grammatical repertoire.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
2 hrs per week lecture; 2 hrs per week seminar.", "Method of Assessment
A series of shorter writing assignments (50% in total) and a final paper of 2000 words on a subject related to your study (50% of the mark). In order to pass the course, you need a 5.5 minimum for each component", "Literature
Hannay, M. & J.L. Mackenzie (2009). Effective Writing in English. 2nd edition. Bussum: Coutinho.
Separate materials available via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Bachelor and premaster students across the university who want to improve their written English in an academic context, with the exception of students of CIS who are following the specialization in English Language and Communication Studies and students of Literature & Society.", "Additional Information
Attendance is obligatory (80% minimum). If you miss more classes, you may still be allowed to finish the course if you submit an alternative assignment, but only if you’ve attended 70% of the classes.", "Recommended background knowledge
Students must have either (a) completed an introductory academic English course earlier in their university studies or (b) already completed Minor English: Grammar and Writing 1."]

["Course Objective
Expanding the knowledge and skills acquired in Moroccan Arabic 1. The goal of this course is to reach level A2 of the Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR). You will be able to deal with simple communication situations such as the ones you encounter when travelling through Morocco or when communicating with Moroccan Arabic speaking people in Europe. The goal of the colloquium (3 ECTS) is threefold:

Students are encouraged to choose their own thesis topic, as long as it is covered by the expertise of the teaching staff. course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Introduction to the field of work for historians: heritage institutions such as archives and museums, research organisations, (semi)governmental institutions, NGOs or media and journalism. Work placements in the business sector are also possible, provided that the work calls on the knowledge and skills as formulated in the General Academic Learning Outcomes of the BA History and International Studies. Internships abroad are recommended for students who wish to strengthen their international profile.
Learning objectives:
Gain insight into the contribution and knowledge a History student can make to organisations and in society
Developing professional skills: gaining experience of working relationships, manners, working hours, work pace, the work process and organisations
Career orientation: discovering what you like and what you are good at. You get to know people in the work field and build a network", "Course Content
An internship is the best way to put into practice the knowledge and skills you have gained so far during your studies, and to get an idea of what you want to do after you graduate.
During your BA in History, you can do an internship for 6 or 12 credits as part of your minor in the third year. A 12-credit internship is equivalent to a minimum of 336 hours, representing eight to nine weeks of work on a full-time basis. The remaining 18 or 24EC of the minor space are filled with electives. Longer internships are allowed but do not generate credits that count towards filling the minor space or graduation.
You can arrange an internship by responding to internships vacancies, or by contacting a company or organisation yourself. The internship coordinator can help you with this.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
More information on internships can be found on the faculty page: https://vu.nl/en/student/elective-space/internships-school-of-humanities and after registration on the Canvas page of the course (L_GABAHISSTA Internship BA-HIS).", "Method of Assessment

course_name: Research Seminar Global Economic and Social History 1500-present
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of this course is to build up experience working with primary (archival) source material. The course will focus on the process of research based on original archival material, will allow students to practice drawing conclusions from primary material, and write an original research paper on this basis. The experience of doing "real" research will be enhanced by the connection of this class to ongoing global history research at the VU touching on issues like land use and land distribution, dispossession of peasant populations, environmental degradation and rural social movements.", "Course Content
The first decades of the 21st century have seen a major escalation of "land grabbing": the forced transfer of land from peasant producers to commercial investors. Flashpoints of this process are large parts of sub-Sahara Africa, Indonesia and Brazil, where land-grabbing is accompanied by the dispossession of rural populations, deforestation and other forms of environmental degradation. Commercial land grabbing has deep historic roots that go back at least to the beginnings of European colonial expansion. The phenomenon has taken many different forms throughout the centuries. It has also always sparked resistance, both from local landholding elites and from rural populations. In this course, students will study primary (archival) source material to better understand the transformations of rural property structures, labour relations and human-nature interaction during major episodes of land grabbing.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar (2 hours per week) plus joint work in archives (2 hours per week).", "Method of Assessment
Mid-term paper (30%) and final written paper of approximately 6,000 words (70%)", "Literature
Selected articles (through Canvas)", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is intended for third year BA students in Geschiedenis and History and International Studies"]

course_name: Research Seminar Global and Political History 1500-present
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of this course is to acquaint students with global political history through focusing on relations in and between modern (19th and 20th century) Southeast Asia and Europe. Students will learn to identify and assess different scholarly approaches in historiographical debates on colonisation, decolonisation and nation-building in Southeast Asia. They will learn to identify and evaluate a range of textual, visual and material primary sources pertinent to this topic. They will also critically assess diverse modes of narrating histories of Southeast Asia from the Netherlands (or another European country of their choice), for example, in museum exhibitions, public monuments, news media debates, historical documentaries, or fiction. Students will advance their discussion skills by participating in seminar discussions. Students will also substantiate formal, written arguments with empirical evidence supporting an informed position on academic and sensitive public debates on colonialism and decolonisation.", "Course Content
Many Southeast Asian countries have a modern history of European colonialism, and of political movements, conflicts and revolutions that led to their independence in the mid-twentieth century. These processes have significant contemporary legacies in Southeast Asia and Europe. This course reflects on modern political history through focusing on sources from, and narratives and debates about, key themes from the last two centuries of Southeast Asian history. It attends to the global, political nature of some of these processes, but also to important local variations in how colonialism was established, contested, and dismantled in different contexts, and what nation-building in postcolonial Southeast Asia entailed. Students will critically engage with how sources are used by various institutions and actors in Southeast Asia and Europe to narrate histories of colonialism and decolonisation, and their relevance to communities in both places today.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
One seminar per week, individual research and writing", "Method of Assessment
Participation (10%)
Research portfolio (40%)
Final paper (50%)", "Entry Requirements
This course is open to BA 3 students enrolled in Geschiedenis/History and in History and International Studies. These students should have finished all first year courses of their curriculum.", "Literature
Reading list will be on Canvas at the beginning of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This elective course is open to BA 3 students enrolled in Geschiedenis/History or in History and International Studies. See also entry requirements."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
understand the development of international organizations from the late-nineteenth century until the present day,
demonstrate and explain how international organizations have set political and ideological agendas in the past, and how they have (explicitly or implicitly) influenced local, regional, national and global policies,
select and interpret primary and secondary sources using appropriate concepts and (digital) methodological tools,
effectively communicate their ideas in oral form and participate in class discussions,
advance their academic writing skills and ability to independently plan and carry out a research project.", "Course Content
From the nineteenth century onward, international organizations began interacting with state authorities in new and myriad ways. Some of these international organizations were established as networks and agreements between nation-states, while others were created by actors from civil society, independently and sometimes in opposition to the structures of national governments. Both international governmental organizations (IGOs) and international non-governmental organizations (INGOs) grew in importance and played a crucial role in social, economic, and political developments over the last 150 years.
This course engages with the practice of global history and with theories of globalization, internationalism, and transnationalism by focusing on international organizations as key actors in global decision-making processes from the late nineteenth century until the present day. Its main objective is to examine the history of IGOs and INGOs in connection to broader processes of social, cultural, and political change on a global scale. It does so by concentrating on IGOs such as the League of Nations and the United Nations, as well as on several INGOs in the fields of peace activism, women’s rights, socialism, and anticolonial struggle.
As a research seminar, it draws upon a combination of primary and secondary sources, requiring students to submit a portfolio that includes a research paper based on archival material. The course is tailored for third-year Bachelor students, and active engagement is essential and expected. This entails reading all assigned materials before each class, working with primary sources, and taking responsibility for the depth of understanding required.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars; Individual research", "Method of Assessment
Participation in class (10%) + Research portfolio (30%) + Final research paper (50%)", "Entry Requirements
Students can only partake after passing all courses of the first year of the BA program History: History and International Studies.", "Literature
Reader, available on Canvas at the beginning of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is mandatory for BA 3 students History and International Studies."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In deze cursus verwerf je de studie- en leervaardigheden die nodig zijn voor het doen van historisch literatuuronderzoek. Dit is de basis voor het schrijven van een academisch paper.
Na deze cursus kun je
op systematische wijze zoeken naar wetenschappelijke literatuur in de catalogus van de universiteitsbibliotheek
voor jouw deelonderwerp relevante wetenschappelijke publicaties identificeren
de betrouwbaarheid van publicaties beoordelen
wetenschappelijke literatuur samenvatten
teksten van anderen op correcte wijze citeren in je eigen tekst
teksten van anderen op correcte wijze parafraseren in je eigen tekst
verschillende benaderingen en standpunten in een wetenschappelijk debat onderscheiden
een literatuuroverzicht op een logische wijze structureren
op grond van de gelezen literatuur een relevante probleemstelling formuleren
bronvermeldingen in de noten opmaken volgens de regels van het vakgebied
bronvermeldingen in de bibliografie opmaken volgens de regels van het vakgebied
op een respectvolle wijze feedback geven aan medestudenten (peer-review)
feedback van de docent en van medestudenten accepteren
een realistische inschatting maken van het eigen functioneren (zelf-evaluatie)", "Course Content
Tijdens de cursus Academische Vaardigheden (AcVa) leer je een vaardigheid aan die aan de basis ligt van elk historische onderzoek: goed in kaart brengen wat de stand van het onderzoek is op een bepaald terrein. Je verdiept je in een door de docent aangereikt historiografisch thema en schrijft daarover een status quaestionis : wat is er al over dit onderwerp geschreven door andere onderzoekers? In hoeverre zijn zij het met elkaar eens, of staan zij tegenover elkaar? Welke tegenstrijdigheden, lacunes of uitdagingen zijn er? Welke nieuwe invalshoeken, methoden of technieken zouden het onderzoek in een andere richting kunnen sturen? Anders dan bij een regulier werkstuk is je eigen onderzoeksvraag niet het begin, maar het sluitstuk van de status quaestionis. Je gaat dus geen onderzoek doen om een vooraf gestelde vraag te beantwoorden, maar je gaat onderzoeken welke vraag er nog gesteld zou moeten worden.
Om te beginnen leer je hoe je wetenschappelijke informatie moet zoeken en beoordelen.
Je wordt vertrouwd gemaakt met de inrichting en organisatie van de bibliotheek van de VU (UBVU), en met de conventies rond het beschrijven en opslaan van bibliografische gegevens in voetnoten en literatuurlijsten. Vervolgens komen allerlei elektronische vormen van informatievergaring aan de orde: het gebruik van online catalogi, zoekmachines en bibliografische naslagwerken. Het kritisch beoordelen van informatie is een belangrijke vaardigheid van de historicus. Wie in het kader van een werkstuk, collegeopdracht of scriptie onderzoek doet, wordt voortdurend geconfronteerd met allerlei soorten feiten, kennis en interpretaties waarvan de waarde niet op voorhand vaststaat. In de cursus AcVa leer je de betrouwbaarheid en partijdigheid van informatie beoordelen.
Een tweede belangrijke academische vaardigheid is het verwerken en interpreteren van informatie: hoe vat je een wetenschappelijk artikel en een wetenschappelijk debat goed samen? Hoe maak je een onderscheid tussen gefundeerde argumenten en goedkope meningen? Wat is de probleemstelling van een artikel en wordt die afdoende beantwoord? Welke benadering is daarvoor gekozen en welke bronnen heeft de auteur gebruikt? Hoe is die keuze verantwoord?
Vervolgens schrijf je stap voor stap een status quaestionis, een samenvatting van de bestaande kennis over een thema, die uitmondt in een eigen onderzoeksvraag. Aan de hand van praktische oefeningen komen alle aspecten van het schrijfproces aan de orde, vanaf het eerste idee tot de laatste tekstrevisie. Daarbij leer je over een goede probleemstelling, aanpak, structuur en stijl. Er wordt in het bijzonder aandacht geschonken aan verantwoord citeren, parafraseren, het vermelden van je bronnen, en het omgaan met AI. Het verwerken van feedback en het beoordelen van je eigen vorderingen en die van je medestudenten is een belangrijk onderdeel van het leerproces.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Per week 2 uur werkcollege en 2 uur practicum. Wie een college niet kan bijwonen, moet dat van tevoren aan de coördinator laten weten.
Indien meer dan twee bijeenkomsten/opdrachten zonder geldige reden gemist zijn, volgt uitsluiting van het college.", "Method of Assessment
Er is een reeks verplichte opdrachten waar je feedback op krijgt van de docent en je medestudenten (formatief), en een eindopdracht (de status quaestionis), die beoordeeld wordt met een voldoende of onvoldoende (summatief). De deelopdrachten moeten zijn ingeleverd en de eindopdracht moet met een voldoende worden afgerond om het vak te halen.", "Literature
Jeannette Kamp, Susan Legêne, Matthias van Rossum, Sebas Rümke, Geschiedenis schrijven! Wegwijzer voor historici (Amsterdam University Press, 2016)", "Additional Information Target Audience
Studenten BA1 Geschiedenis.", "Additional Information
Deze module is een verplicht vak in het eerste jaar van de opleiding Geschiedenis en maakt een verplicht onderdeel uit van het BSA. Voor deze module is het met succes afronden van de taaltoets (L_TAALTOETS) een voorwaarde voor het toekennen van de behaalde studiepunten.", "Custom Course Registration
Voor deze module geldt een uitzondering op de standaard intekenprocedure voor modules van de Faculteit der Geesteswetenschappen (standaard: studenten tekenen zelf in op module, leermethode en tentamen). Voor deze module wordt de werkgroepindeling gemaakt door de docent/vakcoördinator, waarna de intekening op werkgroepen door het onderwijsbureau wordt gedaan; studenten kunnen dus wel zelf op de module en het hoorcollege intekenen maar niet op het werkcollege/werkgroep."]

course_coordinator: prof. dr. R.B. ter Haar Romeny
course_programmes: Hide full list (8)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Acquiring a working knowledge of the ancient history of the Middle East and the Greek world and their interrelationship through time.", "Course Content
In this course we approach the globalizing worlds of ancient Western Asia, Egypt, and Greece from a non-Eurocentric perspective. From the late 4th to late 2nd millennia BCE we witness the emergence of complex societies using script in Mesopotamia and Egypt, and the rise of expanding, territorial states in Mesopotamia, followed by competing super-powers in Anatolia, Syria and Egypt. After a temporary breakdown in smaller entities we find that during the first millennium BCE a sequence of empires were carved out by Assyrians, Babylonians, and Persians. In about the same period, we can follow the evolution of the Greek city-states, notably Sparta and Athens, which eventually clashed with the Persian empire. The struggle for hegemony in the Aegean world between some of the larger Greek city states and the emergence of the Macedonian kingdom as the hegemonic power form the prelude to Alexander the Great conquering the Persian Empire. After his death this broke down into smaller empires ruled by Macedonian dynasties in Egypt and Western Asia until their demise as the result of the emergence of such new powers as the Parthian Empire and the Roman Republic which, evolving into the Imperium Romanum, conquered the Mediterranean world at the close of the first millennium BCE. But ancient history is not just a succession of states and empires: in this course we also look at more structural aspects of the societies under consideration, including economic and social relations, class conflicts, political and religious institutions, and developments in warfare.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars.", "Method of Assessment
Written examination. A resit takes place in the next period.", "Literature
For students of the History and International Studies track:
L. de Blois & R.J. van der Spek, An Introduction to the Ancient World. Third edition, London & New York: Routledge 2019.
For students of the Geschiedenis track:
L. de Blois & R.J. van der Spek, Een kennismaking met de oude wereld, Bussum: Coutinho 2017.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Obligatory for first year students of Geschiedenis and History & International Studies, as well as for students studying Classics as part of an UvA double degree programme. Recommended for other students with a serious interest in ancient history. Part of the Culture of the Ancient World minor programme.", "Additional Information
This course is part of the regular first year bachelor programme. The language of the lectures is English, the language of the seminars either English (for students of the History and International Studies track) or Dutch (for students of the Geschiedenis track)."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Knowledge Acquisition: Students will develop a foundational understanding of major political, social, and cultural developments in modern European history (c. 1800–1914) through lecture participation, seminar discussions, and reading with core primary and secondary texts.
Knowledge Recall: Students will be assessed on their ability to accurately recall, contextualize, and explain key events, figures, and concepts—such as the French Revolution, nationalism, industrialization, imperialism—through written exams, quizzes, and structured presentations.
Knowledge Relevance: Students will examine and debate the enduring legacies of modern European history, reflecting on how the long nineteenth century continue to inform present-day European political culture, identities, and institutions through class debates, presentations, and the written examination.", "Course Content
Profound political, social, economic, and cultural transformations reshaped Europe between the French Revolution of 1789 and the outbreak of the First World War in 1914—a period often referred to as the “long nineteenth century.” It was an era marked by revolution and reaction, the rise of the nation-state, the spread of liberalism and socialism, the expansion and contestation of empires, and the emergence of modern mass politics and culture. These decades witnessed not only dramatic shifts in power and ideology, but also enduring changes in the ways Europeans understood society, identity, and progress.
Rather than following a purely chronological narrative, the course is organized thematically around key developments: the revolutionary legacy and the reconfiguration of political order; the industrial transformation of economies and societies; the making and unmaking of empires at home and abroad; the cultural construction of class, gender, race, and religion; and the increasing tensions between order and upheaval in the lead-up to global war.
Students will be encouraged to critically evaluate both contemporary interpretations and retrospective analyses of the nineteenth century, while developing a nuanced understanding of the ways in which this formative period laid the groundwork for modern Europe and and the global forces that shaped its development during this transformative century. Particular emphasis will be placed on these transnational processes and comparative perspectives that challenge conventional national narratives.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
A mixture of lectures and seminars in which key texts will be presented and debated. Students should be prepared for each session by completing assigned readings and being prepared to explain their comprehension of the period and theme in question.", "Method of Assessment
Assignments consist of spoken structured presentations, knowledge quizzes which test recall from reading texts, and finally a closed-book examination. Lectures will be given in English whereas seminars will be in English for some groups and Dutch for other groups. Students on a Dutch track may complete all assignments in whichever language they choose where possible.", "Literature
We will use T.C.W. Blanning's The Ninteenth Century (OUP 2000) as the course textbook.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA HIS / BA GES", "Explanation Canvas
Canvas is the key medium for dissemination of texts, sources, and other relevant materials for the course.", "Recommended background knowledge
We assume a general familiarity with key events (i.e. the Congress of Vienna) but no detailed knowledge ahead of the course."]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
De VU vindt het belangrijk dat je de taal van je opleiding goed beheerst. Daarom moeten alle eerstejaars bachelorstudenten verplicht een taaltoets Nederlands of Engels afleggen, afhankelijk van de voertaal van de opleiding die ze gaan volgen (Nederlandstalig of Engelstalig).
Zie ook: Alles over de taaltoets - Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (vu.nl)", "Course Content
De toets bestaat uit multiplechoicevragen en invulvragen over de volgende onderwerpen:
grammatica
spelling en interpunctie
structureren
woordkeus/woordenschat
formuleren", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
De taaltoets vindt plaats in de DigiTenT, in september.", "Method of Assessment
De taaltoets is een digitale toets met 200 vragen.", "Additional Information
De VU-Taaltoets is gekoppeld aan een eerstejaars vak. Het eindcijfer voor dit vak wordt pas toegekend als aan de Taaltoets is voldaan. De student die geen voldoende resultaat voor de VU taaltoets behaalt, volgt de ‘Bijspijkercursus Nederlands’ van het Taalloket.
Voor meer informatie over de taaltoets, zie: Alles over de taaltoets - Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (vu.nl)", "Custom Course Registration
Je hoeft je niet voor de toets aan te melden. Het onderwijsbureau van jouw faculteit tekent je in voor de taaltoets. Wanneer je bent ingetekend vind je op je persoonlijke rooster terug op welk moment je de toets maakt. Als je op 8 september nog niet bent ingetekend, neem dan contact op met de studentenbalie. In de tussentijd kun je in het rooster terugvinden op welk moment je de toets moet maken.
Het is belangrijk om je VUnet-ID en bijbehorend wachtwoord te kennen. Je kunt bij de taaltoets alleen inloggen met deze gegevens. Tip: verander je wachtwoord in iets dat je makkelijk kunt onthouden."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
You have knowledge of the structure and register of academic texts in your discipline.
You have insight into the most important stylistic and rhetorical aspects of formal written texts in English.
You have insight into the strengths and weaknesses in your own English writing skills, and know how you can go about expanding the strengths and reducing the weaknesses.
You can write a well-structured English text in a formal style about a subject related to your own degree. The text is free of serious lexical and grammatical mistakes that have a negative effect on the readability of your text.
You have knowledge of and insight into the most important areas of English grammar, particularly those which typically cause students problems when writing formal English.
You have insight into your own strengths and weaknesses in grammatical terms, and know how to go about resolving the weaknesses.", "Course Content
The course consists of a grammar and a writing component.
The grammar component consists of an introduction into the most important aspects of English grammar, with an emphasis on the structures which are frequently used in academic language and on structures which typically cause problems for students when writing formal English.
The writing component consists of a lecture series focusing on the characteristics of written academic English, plus a series of seminars which provide practice on specific language elements and also guide students in writing academic texts.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars each week", "Method of Assessment
Grammar: multiple choice computer exam (50%).
Writing: a series of writing assignments about a topic in your field (50%).
In order to pass the course, you need a minimum of 5.5 for both components.", "Additional Information Target Audience
First-year students of Geschiedenis/ History and International Studies", "Additional Information
This is an obligatory course in the first year programme for students enrolled in Geschiedenis/ History and International Studies and is not open to students following other degrees."]

course_coordinator: prof. dr. R.B. ter Haar Romeny
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Please note that this 6 EC version of Ancient History 2 is meant for first-year students of History and International Studies or Geschiedenis. Students following a minor and students who took Ancient History 2 in 2024-25 but were not yet successful should take the 3 EC version of this course, which has the code L_GOBAGES103.
Acquiring knowledge of the history of Rome, Roman Italy, and the Roman Empire.", "Course Content
In Ancient History 2, we deal with the history of Rome. We will begin with the origins of Rome as a major city state in central Italy, initially ruled by kings, but a Republic since the late sixth century BCE. We study the internal developments in the Early Republic (fifth to third centuries BCE), especially the so-called Struggle of the Orders (Patricians and Plebeians), resulting in a compromise and a curious oligarchic constitutional system. We will see how Rome, from the fourth century BCE onwards, first became the ruling power of Italy, subsequently to conquer the Mediterranean in a series of wars against Carthage and the kingdoms founded by the successors of Alexander the Great. We will also see that Roman expansion had devastating effects on internal stability: in the first century BCE the Republic crumbled in a series of civil wars, and by the turn of the Common Era a monarchic system had been established. The holders of monarchic power in this system are nowadays usually (at least in English) labelled ‘emperors’ (from Latin imperator, meaning something like ‘commander-in-chief’).
The first and second centuries CE were for the Roman Empire, now encompassing the Mediterranean and a considerable part of north-western Europe, a period of stability guaranteed by military superiority and accompanied by progressive integration of the population of the provinces in the Roman citizenry. This stability was shaken in the third century, when the Empire was confronted with a severe crisis which it survived, although not without considerable adaptations in the administrative, military, and ideological sphere.
In Late Antiquity (from the fourth century onwards), the Roman Empire in north-western Europe and the western Mediterranean was superseded by Germanic kingdoms. In the Eastern Mediterranean, however, it survived as what we now call the Byzantine Empire. In addition to the events and developments here sketched, we will also go into more structural aspects of Roman history: social relations, economic developments, class conflict, political institutions, law, warfare, and last but not least changes in the religious sphere. The dominant position of Christianity in European history is, after all, a legacy of the Roman Empire.
Finally, in January we will return to classical Athens to examine how democracy was viewed there: Is it truly the best form of government? What threats must a democracy be able to overcome in order to survive?", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars.", "Method of Assessment
Written exam (contributing 100% to the final grade). A minimum number of seminar assignments must be submitted. You must obtain a pass for the democracy assignment in January. Please refer to the course manual for details.", "Literature
For students following an English track:
L. de Blois, R.J. van der Spek, An Introduction to the Ancient World. Third edition, London & New York: Routledge 2019.
For students following a Dutch track:
L. de Blois & R.J. van der Spek, Een kennismaking met de oude wereld. Bussum: Coutinho 2017.
The reading material on democracy for January will be provided via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Obligatory for first year students of History and International Studies or Geschiedenis. Recommended for other students with a serious interest in ancient history.", "Additional Information
This course is part of the regular first year bachelor programme in History and International Studies/Geschiedenis. Lectures are in English, seminars either in English (for students of the History and International Studies track) or in Dutch (for students of the Geschiedenis track)."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of the course Modern Europe 1900 – present is to aquatint students with the most important events and processes that shaped Europe in the 20th and 21st century and provide insight in both. This will be done from a global perspective where the interaction bewteen Europe and the rest of the world will be an integral element of the course. By using a multitude of different source material – written, visual and oral sources will be employed – students will be challenged to critically reflect on sources and make connections.
After finishing the course students will be able to critically read and engage with various sources and are able to present their findings in a structured fashion both orally as well as in a written manner.
Students will be able to find additional sources by themselves and assess these on their reliability.
Students will be able to make connections between the various themes and topics that will be featured in the course.
Students are aware of ths historical dimension of current affairs.", "Course Content
In the course attention will be guven tot he following topics: the road towards and the aftermath of the First and Second World Warm European colonial policy and the process of decolonization, the process of European cooperation in the contact of the Cold War, the process of globalization after the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, the impact of the end of the Soviet-Union and the rise of ethno-nationalism in Europe, economic and political crises in the 21st century.
All these topics will be put into their historical context amd different perspectives and opinions will be compared.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Each week there will be:
Lectures of 1.45 hrs where lecturers will address specific themes based on assigned literature.
Seminars of 1.45 hrs where students are split into smaller seminar groups. Students will be assigned to small project groups and will provide presentations based upon assigned literature and additional sources that have been found by themselves. Students will formulate discussion points and will lead the group discussion.", "Method of Assessment
The group presentations during the seminars will be evaluated and are part of the final grade.
At the end of the course, there will be a written exam with essay questions covering the course content.", "Literature
Handbook
Best, Antony, Jussi M. Hanhimäki, Joseph A. Maiolo, and Kirsten E. Schulze. 2015. International History of the Twentieth Century and Beyond. Third edition. London: Routledge/Taylor & Francis Group.
Additional course literature will be assigned by lecturers.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Bachelor students Geschiedenis and History and International Students
(Exchange) students interested in modern European History", "Explanation Canvas
The course Canvas page contains all the relevant information about the course. All communication will take place through Canvas.", "Recommended background knowledge
Students from outside the Bachelor-program Geschiedenis or History and International Studies need to contact the course coordinator W.Manuhutu (w.c.h.r.manuhutu@vu.nl).
Basis knowledge of modern European History will enhance the chance of succesfully finishing the course."]
