course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Hoofddoelstelling: studenten leren nadenken over de vraag of historici hun maatschappelijk relevante taak van het lessen trekken uit het verleden weer op zouden moeten pakken en zo ja, hoe zij denken dat dat er dan idealiter uit zou moeten/ kunnen zien.
Diachroon: de betrokken leerstoelen bieden elk een hoorcollege waarin wordt gereflecteerd op de vraag of en welke bijdrage de eigen vakkennis kan bieden aan de discussie over en oplossing van actuele maatschappelijke- en beleidsvraagstukken.", "Course Content
In deze module gaat het over een - nader bekend te maken - algemeen thema dat momenteel actueel is. Dat thema zal worden behandeld als een verschijnsel door de eeuwen heen. Voortbouwend op de basiskennis die je hebt opgedaan in de eerstejaars handboekcolleges, wordt vanuit de verschillende leerstoelgebieden van de opleiding Geschiedenis dieper op het thema ingegaan. In aansluiting daarop denk je na over de maatschappelijke relevantie van het diachroon thema dat centraal staat in de cursus en de manier waarop het door historici voor een breed publiek kan worden gepresenteerd.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Hoorcolleges, werkcolleges, excursies.", "Method of Assessment
Wekelijkse opdrachten.", "Literature
Artikelen via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Studenten BA1 Geschiedenis."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students acquire knowledge about and insight into the most important events and developments in the history of Europe and the Mediterranean during the period known as the ‘Middle Ages'. Students acquire basic skills in analyzing with medieval primary source materials, both individually and working in groups. That is:
Students can identify and describe the most important events and developments in the history of Europe and the Mediterranean during the Middle Ages.
Students can explain the significance of key events and developments in medieval European and Mediterranean history.
Students are able to analyze medieval primary source materials (in translated and edited form) with appreciation for the differences between different types of sources (media), potential biases, and their nature of transmission.", "Course Content
During the Middle Ages Europe first took shape as a interconnected region with distinctive cultural, political, and economic features. From the 7th century onward the kingdoms of Latin Christianity first developed in Western Europe, alongside the civilization of the Byzantine Empire, and Islam in the Arabic world. We explore the main events and developments in each of these cultural spheres, with particular attention for developments and institutions in Western Europe. After initial ruralization during the during the early Middle Ages, Europe became a highly urbanized and commercialized area during the later Middle Ages, which in turn laid the foundations for its global expansion from the 15th century onward. During this course, students thus become familiar with the most important developments in the history of Europe and the Mediterranean during the period c. 600-1350, including connections to Eurasia.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
A weekly lecture and a weekly seminar. Seminars are taught in Dutch for BA students Geschiedenis; seminars taught in English for BA students History & International studies, minor students, and exchange students.", "Method of Assessment
Written exam (individual, 60%); presentations on source dossiers and contributions to textbook quizzes (group work, 30 %), active and constructive participation during seminars (individual, 10%).", "Literature
Rosenwein, Barbara H. A Short History of the Middle Ages. Volume I, from c. 300 to c. 1150. Sixth edition. Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2023.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Obligatory course for BA 1 students Geschiedenis, and for BA 1 students History & International Studies. Obligatory course for students who want to take the full minor programme 'History'. Recommended course for other students with an interest in medieval history."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In this course, we analyse World History as Global History (GH). Global History is a response to the increasing awareness of the growing interconnectedness of the various regions of the world, as a result of the circulation of people, goods and ideas. Over the last two decades, Global History has developed into a strong international, dynamic and productive discipline in the field of history research and education. The focus of this discipline is the deep underlying material and sociocultural structural changes which shaped the human experience throughout history. It is a form of ‘Meta History’; a historical narrative that puts events, phenomena and processes in a broad context.
To understand the complexity of globalization processes from approximately 1000 to c. 1800. Developing historical skills.", "Course Content
Characteristic of this historical approach is that it does not focus specifically on civilizations and nation states, but on processes, whereby thematic research is focused on comparisons and differences within and between regions of the world. GH is non- Eurocentric, because all units of study are treated equally, therefore non-Western concepts and local knowledge are included. The first-year program of GH I from c. 1000 to c. 1800 provides background knowledge for the World History II course in period 4 which covers the period after ca. 1800 to the present.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, assignments aimed at textbook training and skills training, and discussion.", "Method of Assessment
Skills training (5%) textbook assignments (35%) and final written exam with essay questions (60%). You need a pass for the exam in order to receive a pass for the course.
In this course, you acquire knowledge about world history between c. 1000 to c. 1800 and you learn to reflect on historical processes. You familiarize yourself with the large regional changes and with the ‘events and facts’ that those histories comprise: the lives and deeds of emperors, kings and warlords; the thought and influence of religious leaders and scholars; the development of trade routes and trading ports; the formation and collapse of empires and states and much more. This also includes some geographic orientation as you need to know not only when things happened but where they happened.
Working with a textbook is a two-step learning process, consisting of skills training and textbook training. This first step of learning we call skills training. First you attend a lecture on Monday (mandatory), introducing the textbook chapter, and a lecture about a topic that is of special interest for the period concerned, for example, the Black Death in the period 1300-1500. You read and study the chapter of the week in the textbook Worlds Together, Worlds Apart thoroughly (see schedule of lectures).You must distinguish between the more and less important parts. For instance, you can underline or highlight the important key words, events and facts and you take notes. You also study the maps and the legends and distinguish which are the most important ones and how they express major spatial aspects of the main arguments and developments."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This course offers a general overview of European History between roughly 1500 and 1800. Themes that will be discussed include religious history, state formation, intellectual and cultural developments, economic crises and innovation, and political and social upheaval. In addition to this, you will learn engage with primary sources, such as works of art and important political documents, and present your findings both orally and in writing.
By the end of this course you will be able to:
describe the major developments in European History from ca. 1500 to 1800;
explain how specific historical events are related to larger historical developments;
connect European history to a global context;
distinguish between different interpretations of historical events and developments;
analyse a primary source in connection to historical events and circumstances", "Course Content
Europe went through great changes in the early modern period. This course takes you from the rediscovery of Greek and Roman antiquity during the Renaissance, the introduction of the printed book, the religious reforms that divided church and people in the 16th century, leading to bloody wars, to the period of political and economic expansion. We discuss the development of nation states, the gradual transition from feudal to market-oriented economies and the overseas expansion of Europe, with dramatic consequences for both European societies and people around the world. The course also pays attention to intellectual and cultural developments. European curiosity and desire for conquest was not confined to discovering the globe, as scientists fundamentally challenged ideas about the functioning of the cosmos and nature. New ideas were also applied to the notions of man and governance during the period of Enlightenment, and they posed a threat to the Ancien Regime with its absolutist tendencies, ultimately leading to democratic revolutions in a number of states.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
A weekly lecture and a weekly seminar. Seminars taught in Dutch for BA students Geschiedenis; seminars taught in English for BA students History & International studies; Minor students and exchange students.", "Method of Assessment
Written and oral assignments (30%) and a written exam (70%)", "Literature
Merry E. Wiesner-Hanks, Early Modern Europe, 1450–1789. Cambridge University Press, 2022.
A hard copy of this book should be purchased before the start of the course. (The VU bookstore will stock them.)
Additional literature will be made available through CANVAS and the UBVU.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Obligatory course for BA1 students Geschiedenis and BA1 students History & International Studies.
The course is also part of the minor 'History', recommended for students with a serious interest in early modern European History and open to exchange students.", "Custom Course Registration
You will be assigned to a seminar group by the coordinator of the course."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The student acquires the ability to:
understand and explain ideas of key thinkers in the history of philosophy that are relevant for historians;
read, analyse and interpret highly influential philosophical texts;
discuss and develop arguments about and critical reflections on the texts.", "Course Content
Philosophers from antiquity until the present day have reflected upon questions about the past, about history, our relation to it, and how and why to conduct the study of history. In this course, you will read important texts from the history of, mainly western, philosophy in which such questions are addressed. We discuss ancient Greek philosophy in week 1, modern philosophy in week 2, and contemporary philosophy in week 3.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course consists of lectures in which the philosophical themes and the philosophers will be introduced and of text-reading seminars, in which original texts of philosophers are discussed in detail. Reading the original sources will give you a better understanding of the specifics of the philosopher’s thinking about time and history, and will equip you with academic skills. Lectures and seminars are mandatory (80% attendance each).", "Method of Assessment
Weekly assignments about the primary texts in small groups (assessment of learning objectives 2, 3)
Written exam with open questions on the course materials (100% of the final grade). (assessment of learning goals 1-3).
Attendance: an 80% attendance each for lectures and seminars is required to be admitted to the exam.", "Literature
Mandatory and recommended literature will be announced and made available through Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Students BA1 Geschiedenis and History & International Studies."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Upon completion of the course, the students are able to:
Understand key concepts in global and world history and explain the complexity of globalization processes from approximately 1800 to the present
Recall and summarize historical knowledge from a textbook written in English
Identify and evaluate key arguments in academic articles concerning world history
Analyze and interpret primary sources from various periods and regions included in the textbook", "Course Content
In response to increasing awareness of the interconnectedness of the various regions of the world, and as a result of the circulation of people, goods, and ideas, global history has in the last two decades developed into a strong international, dynamic, and productive discipline in the field of research and education. Focusing on the underlying sociocultural and structural changes which shaped the human experience throughout history, it is a historical narrative that puts events, phenomena, and processes in a broad context. Characteristic of this historical approach is that it does not focus specifically on “civilizations” and nation states, but on processes, whereby thematic research is focused on comparisons and differences within and between the regions of the world. Global history is non-Eurocentric, because all units of study are covered with the same interest, and non-Western concepts and local knowledge are included. The first-year course World History I (from c. 500 to c. 1800) provides background knowledge for this World History II course, which covers the period after ca. 1800 to the present.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, handbook exercises, analysis of scholarly literature, discussion, and written assignments.", "Method of Assessment
Participation + written assignments + written exam", "Literature
Jeremy Adelman, et. al. (eds.), Worlds Together, Worlds Apart. Volume 2. From 1000 CE to the Present. Seventh edition. (New York/London 2024), chapters 16-21.
Selection of scholarly articles", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA1 students enrolled in Geschiedenis; BA 1 students enrolled in History and International Studies; Exchange students.", "Additional Information
Lectures and readings are in English. Seminars, assignments, and examinations are offered in English (for exchange students and for students of the BA History & International Studies) and in Dutch (for students of the BA Geschiedenis)."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Aan het einde van deze cursus
Heb je globale kennis van de sociale en politieke verhoudingen in de Noordelijke Nederlanden c.q. de Nederlandse Republiek tussen 1500 en 1800 en kun je die in verband brengen met een aantal culturele verschijnselen;
Heb je inzicht in de methoden, concepten en historiografie van de Nederlandse cultuurgeschiedenis;
Kun je dominante historische verhalen kritisch benaderen en herken je normatieve denkwijzen in het wetenschappelijk debat;
Ben je (nog weer beter) in staat een Status Quaestionis: een ‘stand van zaken’ van het onderzoek in een bepaald kennisgebied zowel mondeling als schriftelijk samen te vatten;
Ben je in staat een cultuurhistorische bron of artefact te analyseren in de sociale of politieke context.", "Course Content
Dit vak biedt je zowel een inleiding in de politieke en sociale verhoudingen in Nederland in de periode 1500-1800 als ook in de mogelijkheden van een cultuurhistorische benadering van de geschiedenis. Cultuur en macht zijn nauw met elkaar verbonden. In de eerste vier weken lees je hoe en door wie Nederland werd bestuurd tussen 1500 en 1800. Wie maakte hier de dienst uit en hoe zien we dat terug in de cultuurgeschiedenis van deze tijd? We combineren hier het verwerven van kennis over de Nederlandse geschiedenis met het analyseren van cultuurhistorische bronnen. Tegelijk leer je hoe de cultuurhistorische benadering zich onderscheidt van andere subdisciplines binnen de geschiedwetenschap. Wat is eigenlijk cultuur en hoe kun je die analyseren?
In week 5 wordt de door jou opgedane kennis en inzicht getoetst in een schriftelijk tentamen.
In week 6 en 7 werk je aan een thema waarover je een status quaestionis schrijft. Tijdens de colleges bespreken we aan de hand van presentaties en discussies hoe je hier een echt betoog van maakt.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Werkcolleges 2x 2 uur.", "Method of Assessment
Participatie: aanwezigheid en opdrachten (10%), tentamen (50%), Schriftelijke opdracht (40%).", "Literature
Wordt via Canvas bekendgemaakt.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Studenten BA2 Geschiedenis", "Additional Information
Deze module is een verplicht vak in het tweede jaar.", "Explanation Canvas
Alle communicatie over dit vak verloopt via Canvas. Zorg dat je tijdig bent ingeschreven en toegang hebt tot de cursuus.", "Recommended background knowledge
BA1 Academische Vaardigheden"]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After this course students are able to:
formulate in their own words different answers to the questions (a) What sort of science (discipline) is history? and (b) What is its value?; and
present arguments in favor of one of the answers to these questions.", "Course Content
This course provides an overview of the modern concept of history and the philosophical underpinnings of history as an academic discipline. Two basic questions are discussed: What is history? And what is its value? We also show how the answers to these questions are mutually dependent. The focus is on history as the teacher of life, the need for truth and objectivity, the moral standards of the historian, realism and the value of historical insight, historical explanation and understanding, the intelligibility of the historical process, the tragedy of history, the politics of history-writing, and the close connection between history, narrative and the desire for justice.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars. Lectures are in English. For students Geschiedenis there will be a seminar in Dutch.", "Method of Assessment
Written exam", "Literature
Chiel van den Akker, The Modern Idea of History and Its Value: An Introduction (Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press 2020) NB. for students History and International Studies", "Additional Information Target Audience
Ba 2 students Geschiedenis; Ba 2 students History and International Studies; All interested"]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Na afloop van de cursus kunnen studenten:
Beschrijven en uitleggen welke concepten, benaderingen en historiografische debatten centraal staan in de wereldwijde ontwikkeling van handel en kapitalisme, en de invloed daarvan op sociale ongelijkheid.
Analyseren hoe historische thema’s in diachronisch en geografisch verband staan, en toepassen hoe verschillende benaderingen van de geschiedenis van het kapitalisme worden ingezet.
Kennis over de mondiale geschiedenis van het kapitalisme integreren met lokale processen, waaronder de sociaal-economische ontwikkeling van Nederland in de afgelopen duizend jaar.
Relevante vakliteratuur verwerven, selecteren en organiseren ten behoeve van een status quaestionis (SQ).
Academische handboeken en artikelen interpreteren en kernproblemen binnen het vakgebied verklaren.", "Course Content
Grote maatschappelijke thema’s in het heden, van globalisering en economische groei tot de toe- of afname van sociale ongelijkheid, en van klimaatverandering tot de opkomst van de platformeconomie, zijn alleen goed te begrijpen als ze worden geplaatst in de context van de stormachtige mondiale geschiedenis van het kapitalisme. In dit college wordt het proces van economische verandering in de wereld en in Nederland vanaf ca. 1000 besproken in samenhang met ecologische, sociaal-politieke en sociaal-culturele gevolgen. Centraal in dit college staan de basisproblemen van verwerving en verdeling van inkomen, vorming en verdeling van macht en de risico’s van het bestaan.
De geschiedenis van het kapitalisme is sinds de achttiende eeuw altijd het terrein geweest van de ontwikkeling van sociale analyse en maatschappijkritiek. In het college worden de belangrijkste debatten, theorieën, begrippen en benaderingen in de globale economische, ecologische en sociale geschiedenis in hun onderlinge samenhang bediscussieerd.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
De cursus bestaat uit twee bijeenkomsten per week van twee uur. In deze bijeenkomsten staat discussie op basis van van tevoren ingeleverde opdrachten en gelezen teksten centraal. De cursus vereist actieve participatie, en dus aanwezigheid bij de colleges.", "Method of Assessment
Actieve deelname aan discussies tijdens het college + status quaestionis + tentamen", "Literature
Geselecteerde artikelen en boeken (via Canvas)", "Additional Information Target Audience
2e jaars BA Geschiedenis; De cursus staat open voor studenten uit andere richtingen."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Kennismaken met verschillende soorten Nederlandstalige archiefbronnen
Het zelfstandig kunnen lezen en interpreteren van Nederlandstalige handschriften uit de zestiende tot en met de achttiende eeuw. Het toepassen van bronnenkritiek.
Het zelfstandig kunnen vinden van archiefbestanden die relevant zijn voor historisch onderzoek
Kennismaking met de mogelijkheden en beperkingen van door archiefdiensten gedigitaliserde inventarissen en bronnen (ICT-component)", "Course Content
Wie onderzoek wil doen naar een thema uit de middeleeuwen of de vroegmoderne periode, bijvoorbeeld voor zijn BA scriptie, wil ook geschreven bronnen uit deze periode kunnen lezen en interpreteren. In dit college wordt een training gegeven in het lezen van oud schrift, het begrijpen en kritisch beoordelen van vroegmoderne teksten, het plaatsten van deze teksten in hun context en het maken van transcripties. Ook tijdrekening, eenheden voor geld, maten en gewichten en veel voorkomende afkortingen en Latijnse begrippen komen kort aan bod. Daarnaast geeft deze cursus basale archiefkennis: Welke archieven hebben we in Nederland, waar vind je wat? Hoe zit een archiefinventaris in elkaar, welke publieke en particuliere instellingen vormden allemaal archieven in de periode tot ca. 1800? Tenslotte kijken we naar de nieuwe ontwikkelingen op het gebied van digitalisering in de archiefwereld en bespreken we de voor- en nadelen.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods

course_programmes: Hide full list (48)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This course is designed from an interdisciplinary perspective so that students learn how empirical qualitative method such as ethnography contributes to history and researching history:
Students gain familiarity with ethnographic methods and use of objects in ethnography.
Students will be able to differentiate Emic and Etic
Students learn to illustrate how objects are ethnographic components and expose socio-historical complexity.", "Course Content
This course introduces ethnography as a method of data collection and empirical research which helps to understand the idea of history and how histories inform the present. The course highlights the value of interdisciplinary knowledge production by combining conventional research methods of historians with creative ethnography and material culture from anthropological perspectives. By discussing ethnography, students will learn social scientists look at phenomena by following perceptions of people while historians look through them by rethinking what was perceived. This course, as a skill-learning course, introduces students to ethnography, its interdisciplinary use, and how ethnography can be included in historians' toolboxes.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Twice every week (interactive lectures/seminars)
Student-led classes", "Method of Assessment
Active Participation
Group presentation and Reports
Ethnography of Histories", "Additional Information
The basic knowledge about social sciences is NOT required!"]

course_programmes: Hide full list (48)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students will have:
Knowledge and understanding of the traditional quantitative approaches in historiography as well as new tools and methods in data analysis in the field of computational history
Knowledge of recent developments in the field of data digitisation and research by archives and in historical research
Knowledge and understanding of the statistical methods and visualisation techniques that are regularly used in historical research
The ability to critically reflect on how historians use and present (quantitative) data
The ability to select, structure and manipulate numeric data critically by themselves: creating pivot tables and simple data visualisations such as graphs and maps, and to use them for analysis in their papers and presentations", "Course Content
This course aims to familiarise you with basic data analysis techniques for historical research. Traditionally, socio-economic historians often worked with numbers. They conducted research on, for example, demographic developments and wages and prices in the past, or they analysed social characteristics of groups of people. In recent decades, we have seen the rise of new quantitative methods thanks to the rapidly growing availability of digitised historical sources. Within the field of digital humanities, for instance, quantitative approaches are also used to analyse large text corpora.
In this course, you will learn what is necessary to understand such research, and how to critically and responsibly assess, visualise, and interpret quantitative data yourself. These skills can be used in the continuation of your studies, in your own research, but they are also useful in various other societal fields. Basic knowledge of statistics and digital technology also helps you to better assess the value of certain claims (both in academic literature and more broadly).
Students who get a taste for Digital Humanities and want to delve further can opt for the Digital Humanities and Social Analytics Minor in their third year", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars, practical workshops, group work, presentations. 12 x 2 hours", "Method of Assessment
Portfolio containing several small assignments 50%
Participation in discussions and presentations 20%
Written examination 30%", "Literature
Hudson, Pat, and Mina Ishizu. History by Numbers: An Introduction to Quantitative Approaches. Second edition. London ; Bloomsbury Academic, an imprint of Bloomsbury Publishing Plc, 2017. This book can be purchased in paperback and is also available as e-book via the VU Library
Other readings will be made available on CANVAS", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA students History/Geschiedenis", "Additional Information
For this course you need a computer with a working internet connection and MS Office"]

Understand the specificities of oral history and biography as sources and methods of historical research and assess their value.
Prepare, conduct, and interpret an oral history interview, and store it in a digital repository for reuse.
Critically reflect on oral history and the biographical method and take up an informed position in (sensitive) academic debates on these sources and methods, including their digital reuse.", "Course Content

course_programmes: Hide full list (2)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course, students will:
have an understanding of the main historical developments that shaped our idea of what scientific or academic knowledge is;
understand how several institutions helped to create, preserve and pass on this knowledge throughout history;
have a broad overview of the changing practices of scholarly and scientific knowledge production over time;
understand how the advent of the internet, data digitisation and artificial intelligence have changed both the practices of knowledge production as well as the status and accessibility of knowledge;
be able to reflect on the position of their own discipline within today’s knowledge society", "Course Content
In the course History of Knowledge, we will focus on questions about what knowledge is and what was seen as valuable knowledge, from classical antiquity up until today, and the way this knowledge was preserved and passed on over time, with special attention for the institutions that played a major role in the process: the library, monasteries, the university, the Republic of Letters, the internationalisation of the sciences in the 19th century, and the latest developments marked by the digital turn and artificial intelligence. Students will learn to reflect about different styles and methods of knowledge production, the necessity of preserving existing knowledge, the relation between authoritative knowledge and power, the accessibility of knowledge over time and for various social groups, and the challenges for and the relevance of the humanities in the digital era.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course consists of lectures (2 x 2 hours a week).", "Method of Assessment
Written assignments (40%)
Final written examination (60%)", "Literature
A reading list will be provided via Canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is part of the 2nd year Bachelor’s programs History, Geschiedenis and Literature & Society: English", "Additional Information
This course is part of the Academic Core. Attendance is compulsory. Students may miss maximum 2 classes."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Studenten kunnen na afloop van het behalen van deze cursus:
verschillende theorieën over de manier waarop religie een rol in de samenleving kan spelen, op zowel privé als publiek niveau, uitleggen;
religieuze fenomenen in verschillende landen en in verschillende tijdperken met elkaar vergelijken;
de achtergrond en gevolgen van een aantal belangrijke historische ontwikkelingen die betrekking hebben op religie beschrijven;
reflecteren op hedendaagse thema’s rond de rol van religie in de samenleving vanuit een historisch perspectief.", "Course Content
Religie houdt de gemoederen in het wereldnieuws voortdurend bezig. Waar velen veronderstellen dat ‘God dood is’ (Nietzsche) en religie verleden tijd, zien anderen juist een opleving van oude en nieuwe vormen van zingeving en spiritualiteit. In het opleidingsbrede college ‘Religiegeschiedenis in mondiaal perspectief’ staat de vraag centraal welke rol religie speelde en nog steeds speelt in de maatschappij en het leven van de mensen die aan die samenleving deelnemen. Nauw verbonden hiermee is de vraag op welke wijze macht wordt uitgeoefend in godsdienstige aangelegenheden. Dit college gaat in op een aantal belangrijke historische ontwikkelingen die invloed hebben gehad op de positie van religie in de westerse samenleving (de opkomst van monotheïstische religies, het kersteningsproces, de Reformatie, opwekkingsbewegingen, secularisatie en fundamentalisme). Maar de uitdaging van dit college ligt op mondiaal niveau: hoe verklaren we de expansie en invloed van de islam, welke rol spelen religieuze tradities die als ‘wereldgodsdiensten’ zijn bestempeld (hindoeïsme, boeddhisme, confucianisme), en wat kunnen we zeggen over geheel nieuwe religieuze bewegingen in de moderne cultuur? Naast een macrohistorische lijn in de colleges is er een microhistorische lijn waarin je via opdrachten op zoek gaat naar de betekenis van religie en religieus erfgoed op individueel en lokaal niveau.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Combinatie van hoor- en werkcolleges.", "Method of Assessment
Opdrachten (50%) en schriftelijk tentamen (50%).", "Literature
John C. Super en Briane K. Turley, Religion in World History: The persistence of imperial communion (New York/London: Routledge, 2006) en artikelen op Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Studenten BA2 Geschiedenis.", "Additional Information
Deze module is een verplicht vak in het tweede jaar voor studenten Geschiedenis."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Studenten reproduceren accuraat kernconcepten en historische feiten over de Amerikaanse en Franse revoluties door middel van kennisvragen waarin begrip van chronologie en hoofdthema’s wordt getoetst.
Studenten analyseren het belang van sleutelfiguren binnen hun historische context door deze individuen te bespreken in essays die hun rol en invloed in revolutionaire processen verklaren.
Studenten passen historiografische benaderingen toe op een nieuwe casestudy en tonen hun begrip van interpretatieve verschillen door vergelijkende analyses te schrijven op basis van uiteenlopende secundaire literatuur.
Studenten evalueren representaties van historische figuren op nauwkeurigheid en perspectief via schriftelijke opdrachten waarin zij visuele of tekstuele bronnen kritisch analyseren.
Studenten presenteren hun historische bevindingen op heldere wijze en reageren beargumenteerd op medestudenten tijdens groepsdiscussies, waarmee zij hun communicatieve vaardigheden en kritische denkvermogen in een academische setting demonstreren.", "Course Content
De politieke en sociale omwentelingen van de late achttiende eeuw zijn algemeen bekend door twee monumentale gebeurtenissen: de Amerikaanse Revolutie (ca. 1775-1783) en de Franse Revolutie (ca. 1789-1799). Beide revoluties brachten diepgaande culturele veranderingen teweeg en leidden tot de opkomst van een moderne wereld gebaseerd op rechten en democratisch bestuur. Evenzeer zijn de vooraanstaande figuren van deze revoluties tot in het heden bekend—soms positief, soms negatief—als de architecten en vertegenwoordigers van deze dynamische periode in de trans-Atlantische geschiedenis. Op de een of andere manier hebben we allemaal weleens gehoord van enkele Founding Fathers of Franse Jakobijnen. In dit vak maken studenten nader kennis met de politieke en culturele transformaties uit het revolutionaire tijdvak tussen 1770 en 1850, en de betekenis daarvan voor de ontwikkeling van moderne politiek. Een nadere bestudering van de Amerikanse en Fraanse Revoluties biedt daartoe een uitstekende mogelijkheid, ook vanuit een internationaal perspectief, omdat deze revolutie duidelijk is verbonden met andere 'Atlantische Revoluties' en zelfs 'Global Revolutions' uit dit tijdperk.
Maar deze cursus stelt de vraag: hoeveel weten we écht over deze twee revolutionaire momenten? En hoeveel weten we daadwerkelijk over deze beroemde revolutionaire figuren? Hoe ervoeren zij de veranderende wereld om hen heen? Hoe begrepen zij hun rol in de revolutionaire onrust? Hoe zijn zij de symbolen geworden van hun respectieve politieke bewegingen?
In deze cursus bestuderen we de evoluerende geschiedschrijving over deze revoluties en de leidende figuren in deze revolutionaire gebeurtenissen. Vaak worden deze individuen onderworpen aan interpretatie, zowel in populaire media als in academische debatten. Door hun biografieën kunnen we niet alleen meer te weten over hun historische realiteit, maar ook over hoe historici, auteurs en het publiek hen hebben geportretteerd. Deze perspectieven zijn van belang, omdat ze onze hedendaagse opvattingen over deze revoluties en hun nalatenschap beïnvloeden. Hoe we over deze individuen schrijven—of het nu als vertegenwoordigers van hun tijd of als belichamingen van bepaalde politieke ideologieën is—blijft een sterk gepolitiseerd onderwerp.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Combinatie van hoor- en werkcolleges. Hoorcolleges over revoluties, werkcolleges met nadruk op bronnen en literatuur.", "Method of Assessment
De opdrachten bestaan uit mondelinge presentaties, actieve deelname aan de les, kennisquizzes over de bronnen en literatuur, en een schriftelijke eindpaper gebaseerd op een casestudy.", "Literature
Noodzakelijke teksten voor de werkcolleges worden via Canvas gedeeld. Daarnaast wordt van studenten verwacht dat zij zelf relevante aanvullende literatuur voor de casestudy identificeren en samenvatten.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Studenten BA2 Geschiedenis.", "Additional Information
Deze module is een verplicht vak in het tweede jaar.", "Explanation Canvas
Noodzakelijke teksten voor de werkcolleges worden via Canvas gedeeld", "Recommended background knowledge
Kennis van het vak moderne Europese geschiedenis uit het eerste jaar, in het bijzonder de Franse Revolutie, wordt als bekend verondersteld."]

course_name: Colonialism, Migration and Decolonization in the Lowlands
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Het vak Kolonialisme, migratie en dekolonisatie in de Lage Landen beoogt een overzicht te geven van de invloed van het kolonialisme en de dekolonisatie op de Nederlandse samenleving en de verschillende vormen van migratie naar Nederland in de twintigste en eenentwintigste eeuw.
Na het volgen van het vak zijn studenten in staat om de impact van kolonialisme, dekolonisatie en de oorzaken en gevolgen van de verschillende vormen van migratie naar Nederland beter te begrijpen en de onderlinge verbanden te zien.", "Course Content
Nederland is al eeuwenlang een gebied waar migratie een belangrijke rol heeft gespeeld in maatschappelijke, economische en politieke ontwikkelingen. In het vak Kolonialisme, migratie en dekolonisatie in de Lage Landen wordt gekeken naar de ontwikkelingen in de twintigste en eenentwintigste eeuw waarbij kolonialisme en dekolonisatie ook gevolgen hadden op migratiestromen. Daarnaast heeft de wederopbouw van West-Europa migratie op gang gebracht.
In het vak zal zowel worden gekeken naar de feitelijke gebeurtenissen en ontwikkelingen rondom migratie als naar het discours dat daar in de verschillende periode heeft plaatsgevonden. Daartoe zullen verschillende bronnen worden ingezet die als uitgangspunt van gedachtenwisseling zullen dienen.
In het vak zal gebruik worden gemaakt van een variatie aan bronmateriaal. Naast geschreven bronnen, zullen ook (audio-)visuele bronnen worden behandeld.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Iedere week vinden hoor- en werkcolleges plaats. In de hoorcolleges behandelen docenten specifieke thema's die verband houden met de inhoud van het vak aan de hand van aangereikte literatuur.
In de werkcolleges bereiden studenten de te bespreken literatuur voor door groepspresentaties en het formuleren van discussiepunten waarbij studenten zelf aanvullende bronnen aandragen.", "Method of Assessment
Participate (10 %),
Presentaties (30 %),
Eindopdracht in de vorm van een recensie essay (60 %)", "Literature
Lucassen, L., & Lucassen, J. (2018). Vijf eeuwen migratie : een verhaal van winnaars en verliezers. Uitgeverij Atlas Contact.
Daarnaast zal gebruik worden gemaakt van aanvullende literatuur die door de docenten zal worden geselecteerd.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Het vak is bedoeld voor Bachelor studenten Geschiedenis maar ook geschikt voor studenten die meer verdiepende kennis willen opdoen over de thema's kolonialisme, dekolonisatie en migratie in Nederland.
Bij vragen kunnen studenten contact opnemen met drs. W. Manuhutu (w.c.h.r.manuhutu@vu.nl)", "Explanation Canvas
Alle informatie betreffende het vak zal binnen de Canvas omgeving worden gedeeld. Communicatie met docenten vindt ook via Canvas plaats.", "Recommended background knowledge
Basiskennis van de moderne Nederlandse geschiedenis (vanaf 1800) is aanevolen."]

course_coordinator: prof. dr. R.B. ter Haar Romeny
course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; History
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course:
The student is able to apply the most important social/anthropological theories and historical concepts with regard to cultural interaction, acculturation and identity;
The student recognizes the problems related to periodizations and generalizations in history and is acquainted with the most important discussions about the relation between culture, identity, and power;
The student is acquainted with the most important viewpoints in general (cultural-historical) discussions about East/West, Hellenism, and Orientalism;
The student has gained awareness of conflicting opinions in Anglophone scholarship and has learned to take a position in debates.", "Course Content
For a long time, Western scholars were mostly interested in the cultures of Classical Greece and Rome, regarding them as the twin cradles of Western civilization. However, in Egypt, the Levant and Mesopotamia, there were great civilizations whose roots stretched back much further into the past and whose fates became inextricably intertwined with those of the Greeks and Romans. This module is concerned with the interaction between the cultures of the Mediterranean and Western Asia. How did Greeks, Romans, Egyptians, Persians, and Jews interact? From the Greco-Persian Wars to the success of Oriental cults in the Roman Empire, the focus will be not only on the ongoing confrontations between “East” and “West”, but also on the intense flows and contacts between both regions. We will examine these historical contacts and confrontations from the perspectives of cultural history, anthropology, and contemporary theoretical thought. Through the interdisciplinary use of different sources and media, we will discuss the reciprocity of cultural contacts and the possibilities for scholars to analyse them from various perspectives.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
One lecture and one seminar per week.", "Method of Assessment
Written assignments (not graded)
Mid-term writing assignment (20 %)
Written exam (80 %)
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual. This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. course_programmes: Hide full list (48)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
To give an intensive introduction to an unfamiliar period and/or approach to the study of history;
To offer experience in the history and debates about sub-Saharan Africa and the world since 1800;
To develop skills in analysing historiography; and
To develop core skills such as: bibliographical search techniques; source analysis; essay writing; giving presentations; and, undertaking independent research.
Students who complete this module successfully will:
Acquire insight into the history, historiography, and debates about the historical relationship between sub-Saharan Africa and the world since 1800;
Comprehend how incorporation into/ participation in global networks has shaped sub-Saharan African societies over time.
Work with primary and secondary sources, applying appropriate concepts and (digital) methodological tools;
Effectively communicate their ideas in oral form, participating actively in class, preparing group presentations, and coordinating class discussions;
Develop their academic writing skills, by preparing a book review, a primary source analysis, and a research paper based on primary and secondary sources.", "Course Content
Africans and people for whom Africa has been a critical point of reference are actors on the world scene and have been for a long time. For this reason, sub-Saharan African countries, institutions, people, and economies are intertwined with the world in many ways. Its recent history has mostly been characterized by, among other things, violent conflict, abject poverty and governmental mismanagement. Despite its long painful and tragic engagement with the world, sub-Saharan Africa is probably one of the most misunderstood and misrepresented regions in the modern world. This module utilizes sub-Saharan Africa as a starting point from which to explore the spatial, technological, political and socio-economic location of Africa in global networks since 1800, and demonstrate how this has had an impact on the African condition. It seeks to inculcate a productive understanding of Africa’s place (past and present) in the world. Special attention is given to the dynamics that produced generations of African facilitators, as Joseph Miller has argued, “from the suppliers of slaves through post-colonial “gatekeeping” elites brokering flows of funds and commodities between national economies and international capital, often to their and their clients’ personal advantage.” An understanding of the relationship between sub-Saharan Africa and the world enriches understanding of both global connections and specific regional, sub-regional and local contexts. Crucially, it encourages students to assess how Africans shaped as well as experienced such engagements.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
2 Seminars (4 hours per week) plus work in archives, independent and assisted by teachers (scheduled moments)", "Method of Assessment
Participation in class (10%)
Research portfolio (40%), including
a book review (20%)
a primary source analysis (10%)
a research pitch: an oral presentation of the research paper (10%)
Research paper (50%)
Format: The teacher will provide a list of texts that students can select. Students are also allowed to suggest their own preferred texts. Within the broader theme, the reading list will be adapted to fit the interests and needs of the students who participate.
Meetings: weekly, by appointment.
Reading list as discussed with students (ca. 600 pages)"]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The course will familiarise students with the concept of migration and learn to see global history as a history of mobilities of human and other than humans. The course engages with critical literature in the field, and introduce grounded perspectives on migration and mobilities that configure globe and globalization. By the end of the course:
students will be able to illustrate the overlapping dynamics of migration and settler colonialism.
students will be able to demosntrate ethnonationalism through histories of migration.
students will be to identify between labour mobility and European colonial expansionism.
student will be able to discuss connection between diaspora, refugeehood, and their world-making beyond one's homelands.
students will be discuss the connection between global migration and environmental histories through other-than-human mobilities", "Course Content
The course begins with an introduction to colonial worldmaking through reading 19th Century English church-man petitions to facilitate migration of imperial subjects to Canada as well as the establishment of Hovevei Zion to colonize Palestine. Then, they progress with literatures and key concpets of migration studies.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course will be a combination of lectures, (supervised) student-led classes (documentaries and discussions) and student group presentations.", "Method of Assessment
Group presentations and reports
Walking migration tours or collecting oral histories of migration
Individual essays (based on literature review, ethnographic research or visual studies)", "Literature
Book chapters and articles as indicated in the syllabus.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second-year students of History and International Studies; social science students; exchange students.", "Recommended background knowledge
This course is an elective for second-year students of History and International Studies. The course is also open to students who have completed at least one year of History or Social Sciences."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
De studenten verwerven kennis over de Holocaust en over het concept genocide aan de hand van overeenkomsten en verschillen tussen de Joodse, Armeense, Cambodjaanse en Rwandese genocide, waarbij de Holocaust centraal staat, als degene die het meest breed en diepgaand onderzocht is.
De studenten leren de belangrijkste benaderingen, theorieën en concepten kennen die in de historiografie van de Holocaust gehanteerd worden.
Zij krijgen inzicht in de wijze waarop de herinnering aan de Holocaust en andere genocides wordt overgedragen en hoe de post-genocidale samenleving met haar verleden omgaat.
De studenten leren geschreven en mondelinge getuigenissen kritisch te analyseren en krijgen kennis over de voortgaande discussie over de waarde van getuigenissen als historische bron.
De studenten leren onderzoek te doen in verschillende archieven (voor zover externe omstandigheden dat toelaten) en leren hoe ze verschillende bronnen kunnen evalueren en combineren om tot een goed beeld van een gebeurtenis te komen.
De studenten leren schriftelijk en mondeling verslag doen van onderzoek dat individueel of in groepsverband is uitgevoerd.", "Course Content
In dit college in periode 4 staat de Holocaust en de doorwerking ervan centraal. Speciale aandacht gaat uit naar de rol van getuigenissen in de herinnering en de geschiedschrijving en naar de waarde daarvan als historische bron. Daarbij komen ook de geschiedenis en nasleep van andere genocides aan de orde, en de verschillen en overeenkomsten daartussen. Studenten werken via opdrachten mee aan onderzoeksprojecten: over onderduiklocaties van Joden, Roma en Sinti in Europa; en over de gang van zaken voorafgaand, tijdens en na de Jodenvervolging in grotere en kleinere provincieplaatsen 1925-1950. Ook digitale vaardigheden zoals het visualiseren in kaarten komen in de cursus aan de orde.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Er worden verschillende werkvormen gehanteerd: inleidende hoorcolleges, werkcolleges, excursies. Studenten maken kennis met verschillende soorten archieven (voor zover externe omstandigheden dat toelaten) en oefenen hun vaardigheid in het doen van individueel en groepsonderzoek, in mondeling presenteren en in het schrijven van een paper.", "Method of Assessment
Er is een tussentijdse toets na de eerste collegewerken die voor 40% van het eindcijfer meetelt. Het eindpaper telt mee voor 60%. Wijzigingen zijn mogelijk.", "Literature

Doris Bergen, War and Genocide: a concise history of the Holocaust (Lanham, etc., Rowman & Littlefield, 2016);
Ook losse artikelen worden bestudeerd, t.z.t. nader aangegeven op Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience

Beknopt overzicht van de Holocaust is te vinden bij Wichert ten Have en Maria van Haperen,'De Holocaust, 1933-1941-1945' in Barbara Boender en Wichert ten Have (red.), De Holocaust en andere genociden. Een inleiding (Amsterdam University Press, 2012), 15-43. Zie https://www.niod.nl/nl/de-holocaust-en-andere-genociden/de-holocaust-193"]

["Course Objective
At the end of the course students can:

This course introduces students to key debates in the history and anthropology of the Maghreb (with emphasis on Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia), while continuously connecting the region to world history at large. The course reflects on the history of both disciplines in the region and offers critical insights into the construction of historical and ethnographic knowledge. It provides insight into political, social, and cultural issues that have caught the attention of historians and anthropologists, such as Islam and religious minorities, gender, colonialism and the colonial legacy, nationalism, language and ethnicity, migration and development, and revolts and revolutions.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The goal is to learn how to identify, know, understand and apply scholarly approaches of Environmental History; to design and conduct a historical research independently; to apply concepts and theories in a research paper; to take a stand in a historical debate.", "Course Content
In this course we focus on the complex historical relationship between humans and the environment. It addresses environmental change in relation to large global processes like population growth, industrialization, technological progress, the rise of the nation state, (de)colonisation and urbanization. We read studies from environmental history on topics like drought and floods, human - animal relations and climate change.
Examples of questions area: How did human societies interact with the environment? How did we cope with climate change? What was the role of climate sceptics in the democratic debate? How did human-made oases for tourism and draining aquifers affect long-term chances for agriculture and for surviving chances of indigenous peoples? How did low-lying countries cope with (locally) rising sea levels? How did we cope with periods of drought? Did the societal improvement of hydro-resilience in the former colonies also include low-income groups? How important was animal agency in history?
We concentrate on the period 1800-2000, when the global population underwent unprecedented growth, cities exploded worldwide and environmental change occurred at an ever higher speed, thanks to the transition from organic to fossil fuels. We compare developments in some global regions, in particular Europe (Netherlands, England and Germany), USA and Asia (Indonesia, India and the Middle East). The course content is enriched by and connected to on-going research projects like Coping with Drought: https://copingwithdrought.com.
As a special primary source we will explore newspaper databases.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar of 2 sessions of 2 hours per week in April and May. Final
presentations of research projects and submission research paper in
June.", "Method of Assessment
Literature reading and writing assignments 40%, Oral presentation (10%), Research paper (50%).", "Literature
Literature is provided by the lecturer in CANVAS.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA 2 students HiS", "Additional Information
Deze cursus wordt gegeven in het Nederlands (deel werkcolleges, werkstuk) en Engels (hoorcolleges) .", "Custom Course Registration
Access for students who have not done BA1 HIS only after approval of the lecturer.", "Explanation Canvas
yes", "Recommended background knowledge
The knowledge acquired in the first year of the BA study History & International Studies (HIS)."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
During this course and after completing it, students will:
develop a familiarity with the history of Latin America since the late eighteenth century.
acquire knowledge from (and critically assess) academic literature.
be able to recognize historiographical debates in the field.
apply historical knowledge acquired in previous courses to further examine the peculiarities of Latin American history in a global context.
understand and discuss primary sources (translated into English, in case of written sources) in their historical context.
use their historical knowledge to understand and take a critical stance in contemporary discussions in and about Latin America.
be able to effectively communicate their ideas in oral form.
further develop their academic writing skills, by preparing a final paper based on a critical historiographic survey", "Course Content
This course offers students an introduction to the history of modern Latin America. Starting with the period of revolutions that swept through the region in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, it discusses the main political, social, and economic developments that shaped its history in the last two centuries. Avoiding a juxtaposition of national cases and events, the course develops a global and transnational perspective that focuses on several crucial aspects, including the processes of state-building and economic transformation, the consequences of internal and international migrations and displacements, the development of nationalist and populist ideologies, the recurrence of military dictatorships, and the victories and defeats of revolutionary movements. Moreover, it pays particular attention to the relationship between Latin America and other regions of the world, in particular Western Europe and the United States.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Two sessions per week. Students should come to the meetings prepared to actively discuss the readings.", "Method of Assessment
Participation in class + assignments about primary sources + final research paper", "Literature
Chasteen, John C. Born in Blood & Fire: A Concise History of Latin America. Fourth edition. New York: W.W. Norton & Company, 2016.
Students will also read a selection of book chapters, articles, and primary sources that will be available via the VU Library and/or in Canvas.
Additionally, students will be encouraged to discuss a selection of Latin American films, music, art, and literature.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA2 students History and International Studies and Geschiedenis.
The course is open as an elective course for VU-students and exchange students."]

course_name: The Middle East in Contemporary History
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students can:
demonstrate historical-political trajectories that constitute contemporary Middle East,
analytically debate Orientalism and engage with misrepresentations of the Middle East through works of revolutionary/social justice-oriented thinkers from Nazik Al-Abid, Abdul Rahman Al-Kawakibi to Edward Said and from the Middle East.
define the notion of Empire as a mode of persistent domination that remains in effect in the Middle East.", "Course Content
In the midst of what ICJ called a plausible genocide in Gaza, some in the Global North said, 'the situation in the Middle East should not divide us'; however, the question remains: what and where is this Middle East? This course addresses these questions by diving into the Middle East's historiographies, histories and memories to open up its political-historical construction. The course discusses how past and present influence the armed conflicts in the Middle East and how historiographies have shaped the dominant imagination of the Global North about the peoples of the Middle East.
This course unpacks the notion of Empire and Dispossession through revolutionary thinkers whose criticism of colonialism shaped colonial struggles against French and British mandates in the Middle East and their legacy have enabled resistance against Middle Eastern authoritarian regimes and also Israel as the ongoing colonial settler project. Furthermore, it shows Empire is mode of persistent domination that impacts of decolonized nations through cultural framing, Racialisations and border regimes.
This course engages with Middle Eastern thinkers such as Nazik Al-Abid, Abdul Rahman Al-Kawakibi to Edward Said to introduce Orientalism and Islamophobic framing of Muslims and peoples of the contemporary Middle East. The course also discusses Racism and Aryanism within the Middle East (the case of Iran), and it ends by engaging the cultural politics of images, visuals, aesthetics and objects in and from the Middle East.
This course operates through academic dialogues that begin from the point of view of dispossessed and colonised peoples such as Palestinians and engages with literature that radically criticised and dismantled perspectives of the Dominant.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
This course partially uses the flipping classroom method, which means students receive content in advance and discuss it in class during group discussions or in conversations with the teacher. Attendance is mandatory, and students missing two lectures will be given extra assignments and tasks to compensate for their absence. Students missing three lectures will not be allowed to finish the course.", "Method of Assessment
Students will deliver three assignments: 10% (a freestyle essay on historical visual representations of the Middle East), 45% (an essay introducing one of the key revolutionary critical and social justice-oriented thinkers of the Middle East), and 45% (a final paper/essay or an open book exam). The overall word count of assessments (min 4000 words and max 5000 words)", "Literature
Please refer to the course manual", "Recommended background knowledge
Students are recommended to familiarise themselves with news outlets such as Aljazeera International, the map of the Middle East and sectarian differences in Islam."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In the course of their study of Themes in Political History, students will:
develop a familiarity with major topics in modern political history,
develop their ability to identify and evaluate contemporary cultural and/or media mobilisations of topics in political history,
acquire knowledge from and critically assess academic literature,
be able to build their own research topic on a theme in political history,
be able to formulate arguments in written form,
be able to effectively communicate their ideas in oral form.", "Course Content
This course offers students an introduction to ‘big’ themes in modern political history that might include violence, (in)equality, citizenship, freedom and responsibility, ideologies or social movements. The course explores the themes through historical case studies from Europe, Asia and Oceania to underline the global and transnational connections as well as specificities of political histories. Each topic is examined at three levels: first, historical actors’ understandings of the politics of their own actions; second, how scholars have explained ‘the political’ in these histories; and third, how the past is mobilised in the present for contemporary political purposes. We therefore examine primary sources, historiography and contemporary representations and debates around each major theme. The course encourages students to critically evaluate the political as a category of historical action, as well as an approach to the past, and a way of understanding its relevance to the present.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
1 lecture and 1 seminar per module, plus class discussions and presentations. Students must be prepared to actively discuss the work they prepared for class.", "Method of Assessment
Class participation (10%), module assignments (50%), final essay (40%).", "Literature
A selection of book chapters, articles, and primary sources will be made available via the VU Library and/or in Canvas.", "Additional Information
BA2 students History and International Studies and Geschiedenis.
The course is also open as an elective course for VU-students and Exchange Students."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; History
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course:
The student is able to apply the most important social/anthropological theories and historical concepts with regard to cultural interaction, acculturation and identity;
The student recognizes the problems related to periodizations and generalizations in history and is acquainted with the most important discussions about the relation between culture, identity, and power;
The student is acquainted with the most important viewpoints in general (cultural-historical) discussions about East/West, Hellenism, and Orientalism;
The student has gained awareness of conflicting opinions in Anglophone scholarship and has learned to take a position in debates.", "Course Content
For a long time, Western scholars were mostly interested in the cultures of Classical Greece and Rome, regarding them as the twin cradles of Western civilization. However, in Egypt, the Levant and Mesopotamia, there were great civilizations whose roots stretched back much further into the past and whose fates became inextricably intertwined with those of the Greeks and Romans. This module is concerned with the interaction between the cultures of the Mediterranean and Western Asia. How did Greeks, Romans, Egyptians, Persians, and Jews interact? From the Greco-Persian Wars to the success of Oriental cults in the Roman Empire, the focus will be not only on the ongoing confrontations between “East” and “West”, but also on the intense flows and contacts between both regions. We will examine these historical contacts and confrontations from the perspectives of cultural history, anthropology, and contemporary theoretical thought. Through the interdisciplinary use of different sources and media, we will discuss the reciprocity of cultural contacts and the possibilities for scholars to analyse them from various perspectives.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods

course_name: Politics and International Relations in Antiquity
course_coordinator: prof. dr. R.B. ter Haar Romeny
course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; History
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By preparing and attending classes students will get acquainted with the different types of evidence used by ancient historians, and in particular with the possibilities and limitations of these types of evidence for research into political history and into interstate relations in Antiquity. In addition, students will acquire a basic knowledge of some of the more important theories on international relations.", "Course Content
After an introductory lecture, we will study and discuss evidence relating to eleven subjects (one subject per class). We will cover topics from the history of the Ancient Near East, Greek history (including the history of the Hellenistic world), and Roman history (including Late Antiquity). About each subject students will read c. 40 pages of sources in translation, and answer questions in writing. Class discussions will be based on these questions and other issues that the readings may raise.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars", "Method of Assessment

Written sssignments (per class)
All eleven assignments will be checked for completeness. Two of these will be selected at random for grading. The average of these two will be your final grade for the course. The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Literature

course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Ancient Studies; History
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By the end of this course, students will be able to:
Situate this subject in different historical, cultural, and political contexts, including comparative and diachronic perspectives
Process, evaluate, and critically analyze the relevant ancient sources and academic literature in English (and other languages of which the student has sufficient knowledge)
Present information from different sources with their analyses and lead peer discussion on their chosen topic", "Course Content
Subject: Conspiracies and Assassinations in the Ancient Mediterranean World
Being a ruler or powerful political figure was a dangerous life in the ancient Mediterranean. They were at risk of becoming victims of political machinations, professional jealousies, or civil disruptions, sometimes with fatal results. We will analyze several cases of conspiracies and successful assassinations from Mesopotamia, Greece, and the Roman Empire to answer the following questions: what do these events tell us about what different communities considered a “good” or “bad” leader? How did these events disrupt politics and society? What were the differing attitudes towards the death of rulers? And, finally, what were the measures those in power took to prevent themselves from being violently ousted?", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar", "Method of Assessment
45% Group presentation and leading discussion
50% Written assignments
5% Attendance and participation
There is no exam or final paper for this course.
Seminar participation is obligatory; students are permitted maximum two absences.", "Literature

The course can also be taken as an elective by other students, but see the entrance requirements.", "Recommended background knowledge
