course_name: Colonialism, Migration and Decolonization in the Lowlands
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Het vak Kolonialisme, migratie en dekolonisatie in de Lage Landen beoogt een overzicht te geven van de invloed van het kolonialisme en de dekolonisatie op de Nederlandse samenleving en de verschillende vormen van migratie naar Nederland in de twintigste en eenentwintigste eeuw.
Na het volgen van het vak zijn studenten in staat om de impact van kolonialisme, dekolonisatie en de oorzaken en gevolgen van de verschillende vormen van migratie naar Nederland beter te begrijpen en de onderlinge verbanden te zien.", "Course Content
Nederland is al eeuwenlang een gebied waar migratie een belangrijke rol heeft gespeeld in maatschappelijke, economische en politieke ontwikkelingen. In het vak Kolonialisme, migratie en dekolonisatie in de Lage Landen wordt gekeken naar de ontwikkelingen in de twintigste en eenentwintigste eeuw waarbij kolonialisme en dekolonisatie ook gevolgen hadden op migratiestromen. Daarnaast heeft de wederopbouw van West-Europa migratie op gang gebracht.
In het vak zal zowel worden gekeken naar de feitelijke gebeurtenissen en ontwikkelingen rondom migratie als naar het discours dat daar in de verschillende periode heeft plaatsgevonden. Daartoe zullen verschillende bronnen worden ingezet die als uitgangspunt van gedachtenwisseling zullen dienen.
In het vak zal gebruik worden gemaakt van een variatie aan bronmateriaal. Naast geschreven bronnen, zullen ook (audio-)visuele bronnen worden behandeld.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Iedere week vinden hoor- en werkcolleges plaats. In de hoorcolleges behandelen docenten specifieke thema's die verband houden met de inhoud van het vak aan de hand van aangereikte literatuur.
In de werkcolleges bereiden studenten de te bespreken literatuur voor door groepspresentaties en het formuleren van discussiepunten waarbij studenten zelf aanvullende bronnen aandragen.", "Method of Assessment
Participate (10 %),
Presentaties (30 %),
Eindopdracht in de vorm van een recensie essay (60 %)", "Literature
Lucassen, L., & Lucassen, J. (2018). Vijf eeuwen migratie : een verhaal van winnaars en verliezers. Uitgeverij Atlas Contact.
Daarnaast zal gebruik worden gemaakt van aanvullende literatuur die door de docenten zal worden geselecteerd.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Het vak is bedoeld voor Bachelor studenten Geschiedenis maar ook geschikt voor studenten die meer verdiepende kennis willen opdoen over de thema's kolonialisme, dekolonisatie en migratie in Nederland.
Bij vragen kunnen studenten contact opnemen met drs. W. Manuhutu (w.c.h.r.manuhutu@vu.nl)", "Explanation Canvas
Alle informatie betreffende het vak zal binnen de Canvas omgeving worden gedeeld. Communicatie met docenten vindt ook via Canvas plaats.", "Recommended background knowledge
Basiskennis van de moderne Nederlandse geschiedenis (vanaf 1800) is aanevolen."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; History; Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By the end of the course, students will:
Acquire knowledge and understanding of the theoretical foundations of heritage studies and discuss the main (inter)national political and public debates surrounding heritage practices.
Become familiar with the concept of Critical Heritage and apply it to different analytical approaches.
Become familiar with different types of conflicts that can emerge in the practice of World Heritage management: conflicts of appropriation, political conflicts, paradoxes in protecting heritage and managing change, climate and environmental changes.
Analyse (World) Heritage sites and heritage objects, and gain insight into processes of appropriation, canonization, musealization, and possible sources of conflict concerning a World Heritage status.
Be able to compare and reflect critically upon individual case studies.", "Course Content
In this course, students are made familiar with the international political framework that shapes our contemporary interaction with and debates on cultural heritage, with a specific focus on UNESCO World Heritage designations. The meaning of the concept of (World) heritage has radically changed throughout the last decades; whilst initially World Heritage designations were limited to objects and buildings, increasingly sites and (cultural) landscapes are considered as well. There is also increasing attention to immaterial forms of cultural heritage, such as artistic practices, craftsmanship and traditions. Thanks to the contribution of critical heritage studies, it is now acknowledged that, whether objects or landscape, tangible or intangible, heritage values are not intrinsic but constructed by stakeholders and communities. It is also clear that World Heritage is never undisputed and often gives rise to conflicts, ranging from armed crises to disputes relating to the management of heritage, as connected to national identities, historical traumas, tourism and economic developments, or climate and environmental changes.
In this module, we will specifically focus on the relationship between (World) Heritage and such conflicts. By discussing critically recent academic, political, and public debates on individual World Heritage sites, students will reflect upon what is called the ‘heritage paradox’ – the constant tension between the management of future changes and to urge to protect relics of the past. During this course, conflicts will be addressed by discussing case studies, visiting heritage sites, reflecting on the way in which UNESCO seeks to encourage the identification, protection and preservation of cultural and natural heritage of “outstanding value to humanity”, and debating how heritage is co-created in national and local scales.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, excursions.", "Method of Assessment
Group assignment during seminar 1 (15%): learning objectives 2, 3, and 5
Group assignment during seminar 2 (15%): learning objectives 1, 4, and 5
Group assignment during self-guided excursion (15%): learning objectives 3 and 4
Individual essay assignment (in class) (55%) :learning objectives 1, 2, and 4
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,4,5,6,8,12", "Literature
course literature to be announced in Canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA2 students Geschiedenis variant History & Heritage;
BA 2 students History and International Studies; BA2 and BA3 MKDA students;
International humanities students, level 200-300.", "Recommended background knowledge
For international exchange students a basic knowledge of (art or architectural) history or heritage studies. is required (on level 200-300)."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Learning goals
You acquire knowledge on long-term developments in the history of collecting and exhibiting and you are able to relate this to the visited institutions, collections and professionals.
You become familiar with the current debates, theories and terminology surrounding collecting and exhibiting and you can apply these in new situations.
You get familiar with the many layers of meaning within an object as primary source in historical research.
You gain insight into the historical drives behind collecting and exhibiting and the ever changing significance of objects and collections.
You will learn how, over time, different layers of meaning have been selectively highlighted in exhibitions.
You learn to communicate the acquired knowledge in spoken and written form.", "Course Content
Throughout history, private people, religious institutions and museums have amassed vast amounts of objects. What purposes did these collections serve through time? What was the mentality and the nature of knowledge, for instance with respect to one's own identity, one's own cultures, and that of others, and how did changes in such knowledge systems come about?
By focusing on interrelated phenomena and themes such as Epistemes, Inclusion - Exclusion, Religion, Power, Decolonisation, Multiperspectivity, Appropriation, Tangible - Intangible, Contemporary Collecting, Looted Art and Forgeries, we will discuss the contingently changing context of collections. In turn, the modes of collecting, organising and displaying influenced the way the public thought about themselves and their culture.
By means of an introduction, all students and the professor each bring their own object to reflect on its personal meaning and the message to future generations if it was to become part of a museum collection. A private collector, who will be invited to the introduction seminar, will do the same on her collection. This first day will end with a visit to a private house/small museum in the centre of Amsterdam.
During the following sessions, we will visit the St. Bavo in Haarlem, the Royal Antiquity Society and the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam, the Dutch Open Air Museum in Arnhem, and the Collection Centre of the Netherlands in Amersfoort. In the end, this will give you a good overview of the seven above mentioned topics in relation to collecting and exhibiting", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, fieldwork, excursions.", "Method of Assessment
Assessments consist of active participation in the classroom, attendance of museum visits, completing written assignments, and a formal presentation.", "Literature
Eileen Hooper-Greenhill, Museums and the Shaping of Knowledge. London: Routledge, 1992, Chapter I & II (p. 1-46).
Michael G. Gromotka, Transformation Campaigns of Church Interiors and their Impact on the Function and Form of Renaissance Altarpieces The Example of S. Pietro in Perugia and Pietro Perugino's 'Ascension Of Christ'. Marburger Jahrbuch für Kunstwissenschaft, 42. Bd. (2015), p. 79-125.
Csilla E. Ariese and Magdalena Wróblewska, Practicing Decoloniality in Museums. A Guide with Global Examples. Amsterdam: University Press, 2022, p. 11-18; 21-24; 37-40; 51-54; 67-70; 81-84; 97-100.
Christoph Brumann, 'Heritage agnosticism: a third path for the study of cultural heritage'. In: Social Anthropology/Anthropologie Sociale, 2014, vol.22 (2), p. 173–188.
Denis Dutton, 'Authenticity in Art'. In: Jerrold Levinson (ed.), The Oxford Handbook of Aesthetics. Oxford University Press, 2003, p. 258-274.
Mayke Groffen, Collecting Contemporary Home Life. Het verzamelen van eigentijdse wooncultuur. Thesis. Erasmus Universiteit Rotterdam, 2021, p.13-46.
Lynn H. Nicholas, The Rape of Europa. The Fate of Europe’s Treasures in the Third Reich and the Second World War, New York, 1995. Chapter IV: Lives and Property: Invasion of the West; The Nazi Art Machine in Holland, p. 81-114.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA2 History students, BA2 and BA3 MKDA students, International humanities students, level 200-300.", "Additional Information
This course is obligatory in the second year for students of History with a 'Heritage studies: histories, memories, spaces'- specialization.
For them this course is a prerequisite for the second year course 'World Heritage & Conflict, and the third year course Research Seminar Heritage and Public History. The course is complementary as well to the MKDA-course 'Exhibition Machines' and also welcomes MKDA-students (minor). For international exchange students at BA2 or BA3 level a basic knowledge of (art) history is required.", "Explanation Canvas
All announcements and communication will take place through Canvas", "Recommended background knowledge
This is a BA2 history course, open for MKDA and History students. For international exchange students (level 200-300) from other disciplines a basic knowledge of (art) history is required."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Bijdragen aan het verhelderen van de vraagstelling en aan het verbeteren van de opzet en aanpak van de bachelorscriptie door onderlinge discussie tussen studenten die hiermee bezig zijn. Bijdragen aan de realisering van het tijdplan voor de scriptie door de verplichting tot gefaseerde tussentijdse presentaties.", "Course Content
Opstellen van een scriptieovereenkomst en tijdplan, een status quaestionis, een inleiding en werkplan, en een posterpresentatie.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Vier werkcolleges.", "Method of Assessment
Opdrachten + presentatie.", "Entry Requirements
Alleen toegankelijk voor studenten die bij het begin van periode 4 alle vakken van het eerste jaar en het tweede jaar hebben afgerond (dit wordt gecontroleerd) en die daadwerkelijk met hun scriptie bezig zijn. Dit laatste houdt in dat er contact moet zijn geweest met de begeleidende docent en dat er een scriptieonderwerp is bepaald. Hiervan dient een schriftelijk een bewijs in de vorm van een getekende scriptieovereenkomst te worden overlegd. De coordinator van dit vak stuurt daarover voorafgaand aan dit college een instructie.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Studenten BA3 Geschiedenis.", "Additional Information
Deze module is een verplicht vak in het derde jaar. Alleen deelname als jaar 1 en 2 zijn afgerond. Wie zich inschrijft heeft toegang tot de informatie op Canvas. Voor de bachelorscriptie wordt het cijfer pas toegekend als het scriptiecolloquium in voldoende mate is afgerond."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Onder begeleiding van een docent een onderzoek ontwerpen en uitvoeren en van de resultaten schriftelijk verslag doen.", "Course Content
Studenten kiezen zelf een onderwerp en hebben daarbij een grote vrijheid, zolang het vanuit de expertise van de staf begeleid kan worden. Het thema van de scriptie wordt in overleg tussen de student en de begeleidende docent nader vastgesteld. Aansluiting bij lopend onderzoek van docenten is mogelijk. Zie daarvoor de persoonlijke websites van de staf (research.vu.nl). Een BA-scriptie bevat een goede verwoording van de stand van zaken met betrekking tot het onderwerp in de scriptie (status quaestionis) en is mede gebaseerd op het onderzoek van een afgebakende set literatuur, eventueel aangevuld met primaire bronnen. Zie verder de BA-scriptiehandleiding in Canvas.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Individuele begeleiding; deelname aan het Bachelor scriptiecolloquium.", "Method of Assessment
De voltooide scriptie is de toets. Voor toetsingscriteria zie de scriptiehandleiding.", "Entry Requirements
Voor het schrijven van de bachelorscriptie is deelname aan het Bachelorscriptie Colloquium Geschiedenis (L_GABAGESCOL) verplicht. Aan de scriptie kan worden begonnen in het derde jaar; alle modules uit het eerste en tweede jaar moeten zijn afgerond.", "Literature
De student zoekt verder zelf literatuur eventueel aangevuld met primaire bronnen, en krijgt hierin ondersteuning van de docent.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Derdejaars studenten Geschiedenis, pre-masterstudenten Geschiedenis. Aan het begin van het tweede semester moeten de studenten jaar 1 en jaar 2 van hun bachelorprogramma hebben afgerond. Dit zal worden gecontroleerd."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Kennismaking met het werkveld voor historici: erfgoedinstellingen zoals archieven en musea, onderzoek, (semi)overheidsinstellingen, NGOs of media en journalistiek. Ook stages in het bedrijfsleven behoren tot de mogelijkheden mits de werkzaamheden een beroep doen op de kennis en vaardigheden zoals geformuleerd in de Algemene academische eindtermen van de BA Geschiedenis:
Leerdoelen:
Inzicht verkrijgen in de bijdrage en kennis die een student Geschiedenis kan leveren aan organisaties en in de samenleving
Het ontwikkelen van professionele vaardigheden: ervaring opdoen met werkverhoudingen, omgangsvormen, arbeidsuren, werktempo, met het arbeidsproces en met arbeidsorganisaties
Loopbaanoriëntatie: ontdekken wat je leuk vindt en waar je goed in bent. Je leert mensen uit het werkveld kennen en bouwt een netwerk op", "Course Content
Een stage is dé manier om de kennis en vaardigheden die je tot nu toe hebt opgedaan tijdens je studie in praktijk te brengen, en alvast een idee te krijgen van wat je na je studie wilt gaan doen.
Tijdens je BA geschiedenis kun je stage lopen voor 6 of 12 studiepunten als onderdeel van je minor in het derde jaar. Een stage van 12 studiepunten staat gelijk aan minimaal 336 uur, wat neerkomt op acht tot negen weken werk op fulltime basis. De overige 18 of 24EC van de minorruimte worden gevuld met keuzevakken. Langere stages zijn toegestaan maar leveren geen studiepunten op die meetellen voor het vullen van de minorruimte of het behalen van het diploma.
Je kunt een stageplaats regelen door te reageren op aangeboden stageplaatsen, of door zelf contact op te nemen met een bedrijf of organisatie. De stagecoördinator kan je daarbij helpen.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Meer informatie over stages vind je op de facultaire pagina: https://vu.nl/nl/student/keuzeruimte/stages-school-sgw en na inschrijving op de Canvaspagina van het vak (L_GABAGESSTA)", "Method of Assessment
Stageverslag", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA3 studenten Geschiedenis. Schrijf je in voor het vak L_GABAGESSTA", "Additional Information
Voor vragen neem contact op met stagecoördinator dr. Erika Kuijpers (erika.kuijpers@vu.nl).", "Explanation Canvas
De canvaspagina van de stage biedt tips over hoe je een stage kunt vinden en praktische aanwijzigingen voor wat je allemaal moet regelen voor en tijdens je stage."]

course_name: Research Seminar Culture, Religion and Knowledge 500-1800
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Deze cursus richt zich op belangrijke ontwikkelingen op het gebied van kennis en informatie, religie en wetenschap in de vroegmoderne tijd met een nadruk op de Nederlanden in de periode 1650-1800. In het bijzonder bestudeer je een aantal belangrijke ontwikkelingen op het gebied van Religie in de periode 1350-1800 en de manier waarop leken of gewone burgers daarmee aan de slag ingingen via allerhande media. De leerdoelen van de cursus zijn de volgende:
Verwerven van kennis van de ontwikkeling van pre- en vroegmoderne religie en van de culturele veranderingen die daarmee in verband worden gebracht.
Kennis van en inzicht in het historiografische debat rondom private en publieke devotie in de lage landen vanaf de late middeleeuwen tot de moderne tijd.
Concepten en theorieën op het gebied van culturele geschiedenis begrijpen, kunnen uitleggen en toepassen.
Ervaring opdoen met selecteren, analyseren en interpreteren van een primaire bronnen uit de periode voor 1800.
Vaardigheid opdoen in het gebruik van primaire bronanalyse: Naast het nauwkeurig bestuderen van bronnen in hun context (close reading) leer je ook enkele methoden fysieke archiefstukken en handschriften te hanteren.
Oefening in mondelinge en schriftelijke verslaggeving van onderzoek: op een zorgvuldige, gestructureerde en aantrekkelijke manier rapporteren over eigen onderzoek, argumenten onderbouwen met empirisch bewijs.
Vaardigheid opdoen in het gebruik van digitale methoden voor historisch onderzoek: maast het nauwkeurig bestuderen van bronnen in hun context (close reading) leer je ook enkele methoden om een groter corpus aan bronnen te onderzoeken met behulp van digitale methoden.", "Course Content
De periode 1350-1800 was in Europa een periode van spectaculaire omwentelingen, zowel op het gebied van religie als op andere vlakken (klassiek zijn boekdrukkunst, kompas en buskruit). De reformatie die plaatsvond tijdens de zestiende eeuw is voor velen een bekend gegeven. Maar hoe beleefden gewone mensen hun geloof nu echt in de eeuwen daarvoor en daarna? Werden de late middeleeuwen in de lage landen uitsluitend gedomineerd door onwetendheid en aflatenhandel gedomineerd door de katholieke kerk, of was er ook ruimte voor individuele invulling en creativiteit? Wat was de rol van vrouwen en leken daarin? En hoe werkte de breuk in het westerse christendom door in het dagelijks leven van katholieken en protestanten? De opvattingen en praktijken veranderden, maar de patronen en functies misschien minder dan je zou denken.
In dit derdejaars onderzoekscollege leer je onderzoek doen met primaire bronnen. Dit jaar sluiten we daarbij nauw bij handschriften en oude drukken, in het bezit van de afdeling Bijzondere Collecties van de UB VU. De thema’s die we centraal willen stellen zijn: de beleving en vormgeving van lekendevotie in de privésfeer (verinnerlijking), de fysieke primaire bronnen die ons in staat stellen om dat te bestuderen, en de manier waarop we met verschillende (klassieke en digitale) methoden zo goed mogelijk het verleden kunnen reconstrueren.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Werkcolleges (1 x 3 uur per week)", "Method of Assessment
Opdrachten (60%) en een klein paper gebaseerd op eigen onderzoek (40%).
Voor het paper moet minimaal een 6.0 worden behaald om deze cursus met een voldoende te kunnen afronden.", "Entry Requirements
Dit vak is alleen te volgen voor studenten die Nederlands beheersen.
Studenten moeten alle vakken van het 1e jaar hebben behaald.", "Literature
Literatuur wordt bekend gemaakt via Canvas en is beschikbaar via de UB van de VU", "Additional Information Target Audience
Studenten BA3 Geschiedenis"]

course_name: Research Seminar Global Economic and Social History 1500-present
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of this course is to build up experience working with primary (archival) source material. The course will focus on the process of research based on original archival material, will allow students to practice drawing conclusions from primary material, and write an original research paper on this basis. The experience of doing "real" research will be enhanced by the connection of this class to ongoing global history research at the VU touching on issues like land use and land distribution, dispossession of peasant populations, environmental degradation and rural social movements.", "Course Content
The first decades of the 21st century have seen a major escalation of "land grabbing": the forced transfer of land from peasant producers to commercial investors. Flashpoints of this process are large parts of sub-Sahara Africa, Indonesia and Brazil, where land-grabbing is accompanied by the dispossession of rural populations, deforestation and other forms of environmental degradation. Commercial land grabbing has deep historic roots that go back at least to the beginnings of European colonial expansion. The phenomenon has taken many different forms throughout the centuries. It has also always sparked resistance, both from local landholding elites and from rural populations. In this course, students will study primary (archival) source material to better understand the transformations of rural property structures, labour relations and human-nature interaction during major episodes of land grabbing.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar (2 hours per week) plus joint work in archives (2 hours per week).", "Method of Assessment
Mid-term paper (30%) and final written paper of approximately 6,000 words (70%)", "Literature
Selected articles (through Canvas)", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is intended for third year BA students in Geschiedenis and History and International Studies"]

course_name: Research Seminar Global and Political History 1500-present
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of this course is to acquaint students with global political history through focusing on relations in and between modern (19th and 20th century) Southeast Asia and Europe. Students will learn to identify and assess different scholarly approaches in historiographical debates on colonisation, decolonisation and nation-building in Southeast Asia. They will learn to identify and evaluate a range of textual, visual and material primary sources pertinent to this topic. They will also critically assess diverse modes of narrating histories of Southeast Asia from the Netherlands (or another European country of their choice), for example, in museum exhibitions, public monuments, news media debates, historical documentaries, or fiction. Students will advance their discussion skills by participating in seminar discussions. Students will also substantiate formal, written arguments with empirical evidence supporting an informed position on academic and sensitive public debates on colonialism and decolonisation.", "Course Content
Many Southeast Asian countries have a modern history of European colonialism, and of political movements, conflicts and revolutions that led to their independence in the mid-twentieth century. These processes have significant contemporary legacies in Southeast Asia and Europe. This course reflects on modern political history through focusing on sources from, and narratives and debates about, key themes from the last two centuries of Southeast Asian history. It attends to the global, political nature of some of these processes, but also to important local variations in how colonialism was established, contested, and dismantled in different contexts, and what nation-building in postcolonial Southeast Asia entailed. Students will critically engage with how sources are used by various institutions and actors in Southeast Asia and Europe to narrate histories of colonialism and decolonisation, and their relevance to communities in both places today.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
One seminar per week, individual research and writing", "Method of Assessment
Participation (10%)
Research portfolio (40%)
Final paper (50%)", "Entry Requirements
This course is open to BA 3 students enrolled in Geschiedenis/History and in History and International Studies. These students should have finished all first year courses of their curriculum.", "Literature
Reading list will be on Canvas at the beginning of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This elective course is open to BA 3 students enrolled in Geschiedenis/History or in History and International Studies. See also entry requirements."]

They will learn to identify and evaluate a range of textual, visual and material primary sources pertinent to this topic. They will also critically assess diverse modes of narrating histories of Southeast Asia from the Netherlands (or another European country of their choice), for example, in museum exhibitions, public monuments, news media debates, historical documentaries, or fiction. Students will advance their discussion skills by participating in seminar discussions. Students will also substantiate formal, written arguments with empirical evidence supporting an informed position on academic and sensitive public debates on colonialism and decolonisation.", "Course Content
Many Southeast Asian countries have a modern history of European colonialism, and of political movements, conflicts and revolutions that led to their independence in the mid-twentieth century. These processes have significant contemporary legacies in Southeast Asia and Europe. This course reflects on modern political history through focusing on sources from, and narratives and debates about, key themes from the last two centuries of Southeast Asian history. It attends to the global, political nature of some of these processes, but also to important local variations in how colonialism was established, contested, and dismantled in different contexts, and what nation-building in postcolonial Southeast Asia entailed. Students will critically engage with how sources are used by various institutions and actors in Southeast Asia and Europe to narrate histories of colonialism and decolonisation, and their relevance to communities in both places today.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
One seminar per week, individual research and writing", "Method of Assessment
Participation (10%)
Research portfolio (40%)
Final paper (50%)", "Entry Requirements
This course is open to BA 3 students enrolled in Geschiedenis/History and in History and International Studies. These students should have finished all first year courses of their curriculum.", "Literature
Reading list will be on Canvas at the beginning of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This elective course is open to BA 3 students enrolled in Geschiedenis/History or in History and International Studies. See also entry requirements."]

course_name: Research Seminar Culture, Religion and Knowledge 500-1800
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Deze cursus richt zich op belangrijke ontwikkelingen op het gebied van kennis en informatie, religie en wetenschap in de vroegmoderne tijd met een nadruk op de Nederlanden in de periode 1650-1800. In het bijzonder bestudeer je een aantal belangrijke ontwikkelingen op het gebied van Religie in de periode 1350-1800 en de manier waarop leken of gewone burgers daarmee aan de slag ingingen via allerhande media. De leerdoelen van de cursus zijn de volgende:
Verwerven van kennis van de ontwikkeling van pre- en vroegmoderne religie en van de culturele veranderingen die daarmee in verband worden gebracht.
Kennis van en inzicht in het historiografische debat rondom private en publieke devotie in de lage landen vanaf de late middeleeuwen tot de moderne tijd.
Concepten en theorieën op het gebied van culturele geschiedenis begrijpen, kunnen uitleggen en toepassen.
Ervaring opdoen met selecteren, analyseren en interpreteren van een primaire bronnen uit de periode voor 1800.
Vaardigheid opdoen in het gebruik van primaire bronanalyse: Naast het nauwkeurig bestuderen van bronnen in hun context (close reading) leer je ook enkele methoden fysieke archiefstukken en handschriften te hanteren.
Oefening in mondelinge en schriftelijke verslaggeving van onderzoek: op een zorgvuldige, gestructureerde en aantrekkelijke manier rapporteren over eigen onderzoek, argumenten onderbouwen met empirisch bewijs.
Vaardigheid opdoen in het gebruik van digitale methoden voor historisch onderzoek: maast het nauwkeurig bestuderen van bronnen in hun context (close reading) leer je ook enkele methoden om een groter corpus aan bronnen te onderzoeken met behulp van digitale methoden.", "Course Content
De periode 1350-1800 was in Europa een periode van spectaculaire omwentelingen, zowel op het gebied van religie als op andere vlakken (klassiek zijn boekdrukkunst, kompas en buskruit). De reformatie die plaatsvond tijdens de zestiende eeuw is voor velen een bekend gegeven. Maar hoe beleefden gewone mensen hun geloof nu echt in de eeuwen daarvoor en daarna? Werden de late middeleeuwen in de lage landen uitsluitend gedomineerd door onwetendheid en aflatenhandel gedomineerd door de katholieke kerk, of was er ook ruimte voor individuele invulling en creativiteit? Wat was de rol van vrouwen en leken daarin? En hoe werkte de breuk in het westerse christendom door in het dagelijks leven van katholieken en protestanten? De opvattingen en praktijken veranderden, maar de patronen en functies misschien minder dan je zou denken.
In dit derdejaars onderzoekscollege leer je onderzoek doen met primaire bronnen. Dit jaar sluiten we daarbij nauw bij handschriften en oude drukken, in het bezit van de afdeling Bijzondere Collecties van de UB VU. De thema’s die we centraal willen stellen zijn: de beleving en vormgeving van lekendevotie in de privésfeer (verinnerlijking), de fysieke primaire bronnen die ons in staat stellen om dat te bestuderen, en de manier waarop we met verschillende (klassieke en digitale) methoden zo goed mogelijk het verleden kunnen reconstrueren.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Werkcolleges (1 x 3 uur per week)", "Method of Assessment
Opdrachten (60%) en een klein paper gebaseerd op eigen onderzoek (40%).
Voor het paper moet minimaal een 6.0 worden behaald om deze cursus met een voldoende te kunnen afronden.", "Entry Requirements
Dit vak is alleen te volgen voor studenten die Nederlands beheersen.
Studenten moeten alle vakken van het 1e jaar hebben behaald.", "Literature
Literatuur wordt bekend gemaakt via Canvas en is beschikbaar via de UB van de VU", "Additional Information Target Audience
Studenten BA3 Geschiedenis"]

course_name: Research Seminar Global Economic and Social History 1500-present
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of this course is to build up experience working with primary (archival) source material. The course will focus on the process of research based on original archival material, will allow students to practice drawing conclusions from primary material, and write an original research paper on this basis. The experience of doing "real" research will be enhanced by the connection of this class to ongoing global history research at the VU touching on issues like land use and land distribution, dispossession of peasant populations, environmental degradation and rural social movements.", "Course Content
The first decades of the 21st century have seen a major escalation of "land grabbing": the forced transfer of land from peasant producers to commercial investors. Flashpoints of this process are large parts of sub-Sahara Africa, Indonesia and Brazil, where land-grabbing is accompanied by the dispossession of rural populations, deforestation and other forms of environmental degradation. Commercial land grabbing has deep historic roots that go back at least to the beginnings of European colonial expansion. The phenomenon has taken many different forms throughout the centuries. It has also always sparked resistance, both from local landholding elites and from rural populations. In this course, students will study primary (archival) source material to better understand the transformations of rural property structures, labour relations and human-nature interaction during major episodes of land grabbing.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar (2 hours per week) plus joint work in archives (2 hours per week).", "Method of Assessment
Mid-term paper (30%) and final written paper of approximately 6,000 words (70%)", "Literature
Selected articles (through Canvas)", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is intended for third year BA students in Geschiedenis and History and International Studies"]

track_from_label: Bachelor Geschiedenis, traject Geschiedenis jaar 1, Overgangsprogramma
course_coordinator: prof. dr. R.B. ter Haar Romeny
course_programmes: Hide full list (8)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Please note that this 3 EC version of Ancient History 2 is meant for students following a minor and for students who took Ancient History 2 in 2024-25 but were not yet successful. If you are a first-year student of Geschiedenis or History and International Studies, the 6 EC version of this course, with the code L_GOBAGES104, is for you.
Acquiring knowledge of the history of Rome, Roman Italy, and the Roman Empire.", "Course Content
In Ancient History 2, we deal with the history of Rome. We will begin with the origins of Rome as a major city state in central Italy, initially ruled by kings, but a Republic since the late sixth century BCE. We study the internal developments in the Early Republic (fifth to third centuries BCE), especially the so-called Struggle of the Orders (Patricians and Plebeians), resulting in a compromise and a curious oligarchic constitutional system. We will see how Rome, from the fourth century BCE onwards, first became the ruling power of Italy, subsequently to conquer the Mediterranean in a series of wars against Carthage and the kingdoms founded by the successors of Alexander the Great. We will also see that Roman expansion had devastating effects on internal stability: in the first century BCE the Republic crumbled in a series of civil wars, and by the turn of the Common Era a monarchic system had been established. The holders of monarchic power in this system are nowadays usually (at least in English) labelled ‘emperors’ (from Latin imperator, meaning something like ‘commander-in-chief’).
The first and second centuries CE were for the Roman Empire, now encompassing the Mediterranean and a considerable part of north-western Europe, a period of stability guaranteed by military superiority and accompanied by progressive integration of the population of the provinces in the Roman citizenry. This stability was shaken in the third century, when the Empire was confronted with a severe crisis which it survived, although not without considerable adaptations in the administrative, military, and ideological sphere.
In Late Antiquity (from the fourth century onwards), the Roman Empire in north-western Europe and the western Mediterranean was superseded by Germanic kingdoms. In the Eastern Mediterranean, however, it survived as what we now call the Byzantine Empire. In addition to the events and developments here sketched, we will also go into more structural aspects of Roman history: social relations, economic developments, class conflict, political institutions, law, warfare, and last but not least changes in the religious sphere. The dominant position of Christianity in European history is, after all, a legacy of the Roman Empire.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars.", "Method of Assessment
Written examination (100%). A minimum number of assignments must be submitted for the seminars. See the course manual for details.", "Literature
For students in the History and International Studies BA track :
L. de Blois, R.J. van der Spek, An Introduction to the Ancient World. Third edition, London & New York: Routledge 2019.
For students in the Geschiedenis BA track:
L. de Blois & R.J. van der Spek, Een kennismaking met de oude wereld. Bussum: Coutinho 2017.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This 3 EC version of Ancient History 2 is meant for students following the Culture of the Ancient World minor programme and for students who took Ancient History 2 in 2024-25 but were not yet successful.", "Additional Information
This course is part of the Culture of the Ancient World minor programme and is also avaialble to students who took Ancient History 2 in 2024-25 but were not yet successful.
Lectures are in English, seminars either in English or in Dutch."]

Hide full list (6); Business Administration; Econometrics and Data Science; Econometrics and Operations Research; Economics and Business Economics; International Business Administration; Philosophy, Politics and Economics
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Understanding strategy is an important part of the business acumen for every educated manager. The overarching objective of this course is to develop your understanding of strategy and strategic management. You will engage with the course material through extensive in-class discussions, and team-based analyses of a major public corporation.
After successfully completing this course, you will:
understand the different theoretical perspectives that have informed strategy research (Bridging Theory and Practice - Knowledge)
develop competencies in the critical application of AI-generated material (Academic and Research Skills)
be able to communicate effectively their own informed ideas regarding the focus and purpose of corporate strategy (Academic and Research Skills)
gain confidence in using evidence-based theoretical reasoning to evaluate a modern public corporation (Bridging Theory and Practice - Knowledge & Application)
improve your skills in working with teammates from with diverse background (Academic and Research Skills)
gain competence in allocating tasks among team members under time pressure (Academic and Research Skills)
develop critical thinking and creativity in your approach to problem-solving (Broadening your Horizon)
develop the critical thinking needed to analyze and evaluate complex organizational problems and make well-reasoned decisions (Broadening your Horizon)", "Course Content
Here’s a couple simple questions: why do some organizations outperform others? Why do some organizations prosper and grow, while others in the same industry go out of business and die? It turns out that answering these questions is not so simple ... and has motivated decades of scholarly research on strategic management.
This course will explore the core theoretical perspectives in the research that has examined these questions. We begin from the premise that the organization’s strategy is its approach to achieving success in general, and competitive advantage in particular. We then examine four theoretical perspectives that unpack this premise in very different ways and come to very different conclusions about the role of the manager in formulating and executing an organizational strategy. Developing a critical understanding of these different perspectives is important not only for aspiring managers, but also for anyone who wants to be an informed consumer of the business press and an active participant in today’s fast-paced global economy.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and tutorials.", "Method of Assessment
The final grade will be composed of both individual (50%) and team-based (50%) components:
Individual components: quizzes, class participation and individual reflection paper
Team-based components: corporation analysis and living case studies", "Entry Requirements
A basic understanding and acquaintance with the current world of business and economics (or a great passion and desire to understand and get acquainted) is expected of students in order to allow an in-depth discussion of the selected topics.", "Literature
Whittington, R. (2001). What is Strategy -- and does it matter? (2nd Edition) Hampshire, UK: Cengage Learning EMEA. ISBN: 978-1-86152-377-8.
Other articles and readings will be posted on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Honours Program students: the course can be followed by a broad audience, but requires an interest in business administration in general, and strategic management in particular.", "Explanation Canvas
Canvas will be used as the primary mode of communication outside the classroom."]

course_name: Economics of Globalization: A Transaction Cost Perspective
course_programmes: Hide full list (6); Business Administration; Econometrics and Data Science; Econometrics and Operations Research; Economics and Business Economics; International Business Administration; Philosophy, Politics and Economics
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successfully completing this course, you will:
be familiar with the concept of transaction costs (Bridging Theory and Practice - Knowledge)
be able to show the relevance of transaction costs for understanding several of the empirical phenomena (Bridging Theory and Practice - Application)
be able to apply the insights in a paper on a topic of your own choice that links to the broad topic of transaction costs (Academic and Research Skills)
will be able to present your paper and contribute to discussion on the papers of others (Academic and Research Skills)", "Course Content
Globalization is an important source of welfare, but at the same time heavily contested in modern societies. This course elaborates on the costs and benefits of globalization introducing modern non-mainstream theories that at points challenge the traditional wisdom regarding the benefits of globalization and helps to understand the prevailing sentiments against globalization. We will heavily rely on insights from transaction cost theory which challenges the neglect in traditional neoclassical theory of transaction costs. The (oftentimes implicit) reliance in mainstream trade theory on frictionless trade is surprising for theories in which exchange is at the heart of the matter. This course aims to familiarize you with the concept of transaction costs and to show the relevance of transaction costs for understanding several of the empirical phenomena that are impossible to understand without relying on such costs.
Insights are particularly relevant to appreciate current discussions on the impact of globalization on a small open economy such as the Netherlands. Think, for example, about recent discussions on reshoring and the impact of globalization on wage inequality and unemployment. The course will focus on four main areas of research in which transaction costs are dominant, viz. (i) international trade with a focus on the multiple dimensions of transaction costs distinguishing between transport costs, institutional costs and cultural costs of exchange, (ii) foreign direct investments with a focus on outsourcing and the organization of the firm in a globalizing world, (iii) industrial organization with a focus on the determinants of the boundaries of the firm, and (iv) networks with a focus on the role of social and regional networks, and on standards as institutionalized settings that facilitate exchange of goods, ideas, etc.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Interactive lectures.", "Method of Assessment
Individual paper and presentation, and optional assignments.", "Literature
An extensive reading list is made available at the start of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second and third year participants in the honours program.", "Custom Course Registration
SBE rules and dates apply for this SBE HP course.", "Recommended background knowledge
Basic familiarity with the principles of economics and statistics."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (6); Business Administration; Econometrics and Data Science; Econometrics and Operations Research; Economics and Business Economics; International Business Administration; Philosophy, Politics and Economics
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The goal of the course is to introduce you to economic perspectives on financial asset bubbles and crashes (Bridging Theory and Practice - Knowledge & Application). Additional goals are the development of your discussion skills, presenting an writing in English, and critical thinking (Academic and Research Skills).", "Course Content
The history of financial markets is littered with asset price booms and subsequent busts. In this course, we will explore the underlying drivers of asset price bubbles, examining the psychological and economic factors that contribute to their formation. By analyzing historical and contemporary examples, we will identify common characteristics and patterns that all asset bubbles share. Additionally, the course will address the critical question of how policymakers can respond to these phenomena. We will evaluate various policy responses aimed at preventing, mitigating, and managing the impacts of bubbles and crashes on the economy.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course is structured as a combination of lectures and discussion sessions, for which students have to prepare in advance. In three group assignments, students will engage with historical crashes, policy measures that mitigate the effects of such crashes, and potential future bubbles and crashes. Additionally, three individual assignments will test students' learning progress throughout the course.", "Method of Assessment
The final grade is calculated as a weighted average, with group assignments contributing 70% and individual assignments contributing 30% to the overall result.", "Literature
Relevant literature (links) is provided both in the reading list and as on-slide references.", "Additional Information Target Audience
The intended audience is second and third-year students of Economics and Business Economics, (International) Business Administration, Econometrics or PPE.", "Custom Course Registration
SBE rules and dates apply for this SBE HP course. Registration via VU.nl", "Recommended background knowledge
Rudimentary knowledge of Finance is recommended, for example, having followed Finance I."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (6); Business Administration; Econometrics and Data Science; Econometrics and Operations Research; Economics and Business Economics; International Business Administration; Philosophy, Politics and Economics

course_programmes: Hide full list (5); Business Administration; Econometrics and Data Science; Econometrics and Operations Research; Economics and Business Economics; International Business Administration
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
An internship is an excellent way to apply the knowledge and academic skills that students acquire during their studies. For this reason, it is highly recommended. The primary learning objective of internships is to become familiar with professional and market-related skills in a real and new organisational environment. With the job market becoming increasingly competitive, gaining relevant experience provides students with a strong start to their professional careers. The ‘not-for-credit’ (0 ECT) internship course is available to all SBE programmes. Students can undertake an internship alongside their studies or after completing all their courses. The internship will be recorded on the student’s diploma supplement. If you are interested in other types of internships, such as a minor internship, thesis internship, or extracurricular internship, you can find detailed information in the Bachelor internship manual or watch the video Internships at SBE.", "Course Content
n.a.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Career Services (internships.sbe@vu.nl) will function as the SBE supervisor for the 0-ECT internships. Students who take the ‘not for credit’ internship need to fulfil the following requirements (see also the detailed Bachelor internship manuals):
Watch the following video about how to register for the internship and the Canvas page: 0-ECT internship video
Before you can start the internship, you need to complete the following two steps:
1. Fill out the internship proposal on Canvas no later than two weeks before the start. The main purpose of the internship proposal is a description of what the student intends to learn during the internship. The proposal includes the following elements:
A description of the organization and the department where the internship is located (for instance, sector, age of the organization, number of employees, etc.);
A description of the internships tasks and responsibilities;
Personal learning objectives: what do you intend to learn from this internship?
A description of why the internship is relevant for your study program.
2. After the approval of the proposal by the SBE supervisor from Career Services, the internship agreement has to be signed by three parties: Fill in the blanks in the internship agreement, sign the agreement yourself and make sure it is signed by the representative of the organization providing the internship. Upload the signed agreement on Canvas, two weeks before the start of your internship. Your SBE supervisor will be the last person to sign the agreement and send you a signed copy of the document.
To make sure you successfully complete the internship, you need to do the following two steps:
1. Two weeks before completion of the internship, the reflection report (max. 5 A4) should be submitted in Canvas. The main purpose of the internship report is a description of what the student has learned during the internship. The report includes the following elements:
a description of the internship (i.e. goal, activities, results);
a personal reflection on the internship (i.e., the supervision by the organization providing the internship, the working atmosphere, comparison of expectations and realizations, etc.);
reflection on the personal learning objectives;
advice would you give to students that are currently looking for an internship;
advice would you give to students who are interested in a similar position.
2. Together with the internship report, please submit the evaluation from your company supervisor in Canvas. Based on the reflection report and the evaluation of the company supervisor, the SBE supervisor checks whether the student has met the requirements and subsequently sends a confirmation to the study administration.", "Method of Assessment
n.a.", "Custom Course Registration
To register for the 0-ECT internship, please watch 0-ECT internship video. The internship proposal and the internship agreement should be submitted a minimum two weeks before the start of the internship in Canvas. The internship agreement should include all the required signatures. Career Services will function as the SBE supervisor for the 0-ECT internship. After the internship proposal has been approved and the internship agreement is signed by the student, SBE supervisor and the company, the student can start the internship. For more information see the Bachelor internship manual.
For questions you can also send an e-mail to internships.sbe@vu.nl or join one of the Internship Advice sessions or Internship Q&A's with Career Services. Career Services can also help prepare for an internship, for instance when it comes to writing a good resume and application letter, or answer questions about internships. For more information, click here."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (4)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The Broader Mind Course is an entirely new form of education that combines fun, active engagement, and personal development. It is an extracurricular, interdisciplinary course which focuses on personal development in relation to challenging societal issues. The course load can be easily combined with your regular study program as the work loads consists of about 2 hours of work per week on average while it runs in periods 4 and 5 (except during exam and assessment weeks).
This course provides you with the unique and valuable experience of meetups in small groups with a mix of BA-students from different disciplines and VU-faculties. In these groups you will be supervised by a well-trained guide.
Together you will explore and discuss issues that you may already be encountering in your life now (or might encounter in your future career),
In order to accommodate your personal interests, there are two ‘editions’ of the Broader Mind Course, called ‘tracks’, of which you can choose one (and the other one you can do another year if you wish)
Track A discusses the following themes: Success & Failure, Poverty, Human Body, Rebellion
Track B focuses on Health & Happiness, Digital World, Viewpoints & Worldview and Sustainability.
(it is even possible to take both tracks simultaneously)
While working on these issues, the course also provides you with the unique opportunity for practicing a host of important social and academic skills that would be considered highly valuable in any future workplace today. Among the skills that you will practice are:
Communication (public speaking, presenting your own opinion, active listening, debating)
Cooperation (working in interdisciplinary groups)
Problem solving and innovation (conflict resolution, challenging existing ideas, creating original solutions)
Ability to deal with complexity and ambiguity (self-introspection, empathy, perspective taking, mediation)
The course is a blended course (which provides you with the flexibility to complete elements of the course at a time that is suitable for you): background information on the various themes is provided online, and in offline (group) meetups (5 meetings of 2h in period 4, 5 meetings in period 5) you will discuss the themes and work together toward possible new perspectives and solutions.
Through this non-traditional academic way of learning – more an experience than a traditional course - you will grow, not only as a person, but also both as a citizen and as an academic. Additionally, at the end of the course you will receive a certificate for your CV as well as having the course listed on your diploma!
Have a look at https://vu.nl/en/student/extra-challenge/broader-mind-course", "Course Content
This course is designed by students for students, with input from professors, researchers and other enthusiastic members of staff at Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam. The topics are chosen by students based on their own experiences and on the challenges that our society faces right now.
The course is divided into two tracks and you can choose one (with the opportunity to follow the other track in a different year if you would like to).
Track A: Success & Failure, Poverty, Human Body, Rebellion
Track B: Health & Happiness, Digital World, Viewpoints & Worldview, Sustainability.
The meetups take place at the end of the afternoon either Tuesday or Wednesday. The background information for the various themes as well as small online assignments are provided online in Canvas.
For each theme there is one relatively short ‘getting acquainted with the theme’-meetup and in the other week a longer ‘meetup’ where you will engage in various real-life activities, simulations, educational games, etc.; in short: learning by experience (as well as a great opportunity to meet new people).
Your personal group-guide will facilitate your discussions and meetups, provide feedback on your assignments and provide you with guidance throughout the course.
Contents:
4 (on-campus) (short) meetups on Tuesdays or Wednesdays (17:30-19:30).
6 (on-campus) ‘meetups’ on Tuesdays or Wednesdays (17:30-19:30).
In addition, you will do online assignments at home.
Beginning of February: Kick-off Event
Mid-May: Closing Ceremony Event
You will receive a digital certificate for successfully completing the course and it will be mentioned in your diploma as well.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Target audience: VU Amsterdam Bachelor’s students (1st – 3rd year).
Time period(s): Period 4 and 5 (02 Feb – 29 May 2026) except during exam weeks.
Language of instruction: English.
Study load: 40 hours (± 2- 2.5 hours per week). Online activities can be completed in your own time.
Teaching method: Blended learning in an interdisciplinary setting (mix of students from all faculties)", "Method of Assessment
Attending and participating in the offline activities (of which you may miss no more than 3 meetups); completing at least 55% of all milestones; and completing three creative assignments.", "Literature
Study material will be made available on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Bachelor’s students from all faculties of the VU.", "Additional Information
The Broader Mind Course is an extra course that can be taken by all VU-students. However, an increasing number of programmes are considering (or have already implemented) to make the course part of their regular study programme, for these students the course then has or will become mandatory.", "Custom Course Registration
1. Select the track you would like to follow and sign up:
Track A (W_ABM_CTA): Success & Failure, Poverty, Human Body and Rebellion.
Track B (W_ABM_CTB): Health & Happiness, Digital World, Viewpoints & Worldview and Sustainability.
2. Choose whether you would like to be part of a group on one of two different weekdays: Tuesdays or Wednesdays.", "Recommended background knowledge
The course is designed at a BA-level and therefore BA-students (from all faculties and programmes) are welcome to enroll. However, if MA-students want to follow the course, they are welcome too."]

track_from_label: Extra courses concerning entry requirements to SBE Master Programmes
teaching_method: Study Group, Written partial exam, Lecture
course_programmes: Hide full list (5)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This course covers the most important concepts, theory, methods and techniques related to the linear regression model and forms a basis for future econometrics courses. You will develop a thorough understanding of linear regression for cross-sectional data and study its use from both a theoretical and empirical point of view. We derive various estimators (ordinary least squares, weighted least squares and maximum likelihood) in the context of linear regression models and study their finite-sample and asymptotic properties. Moreover, you will learn how to assess model fit based on different measures and how to perform prediction and inference in the linear regression model. Period 1 mostly focuses on the simple linear regression model (i.e. only one explanatory variable). In Period 2, we exploit the strength of matrix algebra and study the multiple linear regression model.", "Course Content
The course focuses on linear regression models for cross-sectional data. In Period 1 of the course, we study the simple linear regression model using standard notation (specifying quantities per cross-sectional unit). We deviate from this in Period 2 and study the multiple linear regression model in matrix form, which leads to compact formulas for estimators and tests statistics. We cover the following topics throughout the course:
Estimation: ordinary least squares, weighted least squares and maximum likelihood
Assumptions on the linear regression model (why are they important, how could we check/test their validity)
Inference: hypothesis and diagnostic testing using t-tests and F-tests, confidence intervals
Finite-sample and asymptotic properties of estimators and tests
Prediction: making point predictions and setting up prediction intervals", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
2 x 2 hours of classes per week: one lecture and one tutorial.", "Method of Assessment
Individual assignment - Individual assessment (part 1)
Intermediate exam – Individual assessment (part 1)
Group assignment - Group assessment (part 2)
Final exam – Individual assessment (part 2)", "Literature
The mandatory literature for this course is given below.
Period 1
J.H. Stock and M.W. Watson (2019). Introduction to Econometrics. 4th edition. (The 3rd updated edition of 2015 is also fine).
Period 2
J.R. Magnus (2017). Introduction to the Theory of Econometrics. VU University Press. (From sixth printing onwards, the book has video links).
J.R. Magnus and S. Telg (2021). Mastering Econometrics: Exercises and Solutions. VU University Press.", "Additional Information
Please note that this course is part of an entry requirement for Integrative Practical (part of BSc Econometrics and Operations Research) and Data Science Practical (part of BSc Econometrics and Data Science).", "Recommended background knowledge
Linear Algebra, Analysis I & II, Statistics"]

track_from_label: Extra courses concerning entry requirements to SBE Master Programmes
teaching_method: Computer lab, Study Group, Written partial exam, Lecture
course_programmes: Hide full list (5)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Acquainting the student with numerical methods and applications to econometric problems.", "Course Content
Several methods will be discussed for solving numerical problems in econometrics. Topics include:
floating point representation of numbers on computers
numerical differentiation
numerical integration: quadrature and Monte Carlo integration
interpolation methods
finding zeros of functions: bisection, Newton(-Raphson), Secant methods
univariate optimization: golden section search.
random number generation: inverse CDF, rejection sampling
multivariate optimization: Newton(-Raphson) and BFGS with linesearch, Nelder-Mead. Differential Evolution.
optimization under restrictions using transformations.
using optimization methods to compute Maximum Likelihood estimators in non-Gaussian/non-linear econometric models
Power method for computing eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
solving a system of linear equations: Gaussian Elimination", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Classes and tutorials.", "Method of Assessment
Intermediate exam – Individual assessment
Final exam – Individual assessment
Assignment - Groups of 3-4 students", "Literature
Cheney & Kincaid (2012), Numerical Mathematics and Computing. 7th edition.", "Additional Information
Please note that this course is part of an entry requirement for Data Science Practical (part of BSc Econometrics and Data Science).", "Recommended background knowledge
Programming, Linear Algebra, Analysis II, Probability Theory, Statistics"]

track_from_label: Extra courses concerning entry requirements to SBE Master Programmes
teaching_method: Study Group, Written partial exam, Lecture
course_programmes: Hide full list (5)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
An introduction into optimization, and in particular deterministic optimization. One aim is to learn how to model a practical optimization problem into the appropriate mathematical formulation. The other is to learn the theory and application of solution methods for general classes of optimization problems.", "Course Content
This is an introductory course in deterministic optimization. The optimization models studied are unconstrained non-linear optimization, constrained non-linear optimization, convex optimization, linear optimization and integer linear optimization. Solution techniques for these classes of optimization problems are the central theme of this course. Another important element of the course is the mathematical formulation of (practical) verbally described problems as instances of the optimization models, and application of the solution methods to solve the resulting problems.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures: 2 hours per week.
Tutorials: 1 hour per week", "Method of Assessment
Separate exams for the first half (period 1) and second half (period 2) of the course are held at the end of each period. The overall grade is the average of these two partial exams. There is a minimum grade requirement in the first partial exam to have access to the second partial exam. Individual assignments, such as short quizzes or written feedback on aspects of the course - will be assigned as the course progresses. A re-sit combines the two parts into one exam.", "Literature
H.A. Taha: Operations Research: An Introduction, International Edition, 9th or 10th Ed., Pearson.", "Additional Information Target Audience
2nd-year students Econometrics and Operations Research
Applied Mathematics students", "Additional Information
The course is suitable to be taken in an exchange programme for students who have successfully completed courses in Linear Algebra and Analysis.
Please note that this course is part of an entry requirement for Integrative Practical (part of BSc Econometrics and Operations Research).", "Recommended background knowledge
Linear Algebra and Analysis I and II"]

track_from_label: Extra courses concerning entry requirements to SBE Master Programmes
teaching_method: Study Group, Written partial exam, Lecture
course_programmes: Hide full list (4)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The learning objectives are as follows:
Knowledge and understanding of basic concepts of probability theory and probability distributions.
Selecting an appropriate method to solve typical problems in probability theory and applying these methods correctly.
Translating verbally described problems in the language of probability theory to solve the problems.
Knowledge of probability distributions which occur most commonly in practice and being able to use the known properties of these distributions to solve problems.", "Course Content
The mathematical foundation for both modelling decisions under uncertainty when performing statistics is probability theory and probability theory therefore has a central role in the bachelor Econometrics and Operations Research.
The structure of this course is as follows:
Introduction of basic elements of the probability theory (random experiment, outcomes space, eventuality and opportunity) and fundamental calculation rules for combinations, permutations.
Discussion of axioms of probability, combinatorial probability models, conditional probabilities, the rule of Bayes, and the law of total probability.
Introduction of the concept of a random variable, and concepts such as distribution function, probability mass function, expectation and variance of a random variable.
Discussion of specific discrete probability distributions, such as the binomial, hypergeometric, Poisson, and geometric distribution.
Introduction of continuous random variables and associated probability density and distribution functions.
Discussion of specific continuous probability distributions such as the uniform, normal, exponential and gamma distribution. Relations between these continuous probability distributions and the previously introduced discrete probability distributions are discussed.
Discussion of the concepts of bivariate and multivariate probability distributions and related concepts such as joint and marginal distribution functions, conditional probability distribution, and independence of stochastic variables.
Discussion of moment generating functions.
Introduction of the limit theorems such as laws of large numbers and the central limit theorem.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and Work groups", "Method of Assessment
Midterm exam - individual mark
Final exam - individual mark", "Literature
Author: Saeed Ghahramani; Title: Fundamentals of Probability (with stochastic processes); Fourth Edition; publication year: 2018; publisher: CRC Press, Taylor & Francis Group; EAN: 9781498755092", "Recommended background knowledge
Good knowledge and skill of mathematics taught at VWO."]
