course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of the course, students will be able to:
Define, explain, and exemplify key concepts from the principal traditions in literary theory, including Marxism, feminism, New Criticism, queer studies, and postcolonial theory.
Summarise and compare the main ideas, values, and practices defining each theoretical approach.
Identify key thinkers from each school or tradition.
Recognise and describe the ideological implications of narrative choices.
Compare different approaches to the interpretation of a literary text.
Analyse a range of texts with and against the grain and through a range of theoretical frameworks.", "Course Content
Each meeting, the basic tenets of a particular tradition in literary theory are discussed. Subsequently, students apply this theoretical perspective to different short stories to see how a variety of theoretical approaches lead to different insights about the text and/or the society in which it was written.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar meetings, 2 x 2 hours per week.", "Method of Assessment
Participation (30%)
Final written exam on TestVision (70%)", "Literature
Lois Tyson, Critical Theory Today: A User-Friendly Guide: Third Edition (2015).", "Additional Information Target Audience
This module is part of the Bachelor’s track Literature & Society: English, year 1.", "Additional Information
Attendance is compulsory. Exceptions may be made in grave personal circumstances. Make sure to inform both your lecturer and the academic advisor in such cases.", "Custom Course Registration
In case of a large cohort, the instructor will assign the students to the seminar groups. The group division will be announced on Canvas."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (2)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of the course:
Students will be able to recall key concepts and debates about the relationship between literature and society.
Students will understand, interpret and explain literary and critical texts from diverse national, cultural, and historical backgrounds.
Students will be able to apply their knowledge to a variety of literary texts and present their research findings both in writing and verbally.
Students will analyse and break down complex texts and debates to understand their components and relationships.
Students will be able to evaluate, assess and critique literary works and peer feedback, providing constructive criticism.
Students will creatively produce original research and presentations, synthesising their understanding and analysis of the texts.", "Course Content
For centuries, literary and other cultural texts have changed the way people think and look at the world. They reveal social injustices and societal ills, offering ideas and ammunition for social change, thereby helping people to imagine different, better realities. A single text may trigger an individual’s struggle for emancipation, but also that of a group or a nation. This course will explore the important ways in which literary texts have contributed to societal change and have liberated people throughout the centuries up to the present.
The texts we discuss have instigated individual readers as well as collectivities to discover and become aware of injustices, unfairness and abuse. This course analyzes that process, using the following questions as leading threads in the discussions: Which rhetorical strategies employed in the texts evoke the readers’ empathy and possible agency? How do the texts simultaneously assist in emboldening the reader, strengthening an emerging community, and gaining acceptance from a wider audience? In which way do they balance realities that are already being lived and imagined possibilities that have yet to materialize? How do they interact with other expressions of the struggle for emancipation, by way of imitation, opposition, appropriation? And, finally, how do they function within the communities that they have helped found, how are they remembered, recreated, redefined, and to which purposes?", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Students and instructor meet three times per week: Lectures, 1 x 2 hours per week. Seminar meetings, 2 x 2 hours per week.", "Method of Assessment
Assessment: Participation (20%), written task (50%), and final report (30%).
Students will only receive credits for the course if their grade for the written exam is 5.5 or higher. They are not allowed to compensate an exam grade that is below 5.5 with other partial grades.", "Literature
Primary and secondary sources; to be announced on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is only open for first year students of Literature & Society: English, or students enrolled in the Schoolvakminor English Literature.
Please note, this course is NOT suitable for exchange students.", "Additional Information
This course is obligatory in the first year. Attendance required: 80% (including lectures, seminars, practicums). Students who miss more than 20% will not receive credits for the course. Exceptions may be made in grave personal circumstances. Make sure to inform both your lecturer and the academic advisor in such cases.", "Custom Course Registration
There is a slightly different enrollment procedure for this module. The standard procedure of the Faculty of Humanities has students sign up for (i) the module, and (ii) the form of tuition (lecture and/or preferred seminar group). However, for this module the instructor will assign the students to the seminar groups. Therefore, students should sign up for (i) the module, but not for (ii) the seminar groups.", "Recommended background knowledge
The history and literature of social movements such as feminism and the abolitionist and anti-apartheid movements."]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of Academic Skills 1 students will be able to:
Identify the characteristics of a well-defined research topic (e.g., focus, clarity, relevance).
Remember the fundamental rules of MLA citation style for in-text citations and Works Cited pages and explain why proper citation is necessary to avoid plagiarism and to maintain academic integrity.
Implement MLA citation style in writing, correctly formatting in-text citations and the Works Cited page.
Examine sample citations for accuracy and consistency with MLA style guidelines and assess the correctness of MLA formatting in a paper, ensuring all sources are properly cited and produce a properly formatted academic essay or research paper using MLA citation style throughout.
Discuss the standard structure of an academic essay (introduction, body paragraphs, conclusion) and explain how each part of the essay contributes to the overall argument and organization.", "Course Content
Set up as a mini-thesis trajectory, this module (together with Academic Skills 2) teaches students how to conduct and write about research in the field of literary studies. In Academic Skills 1, students are introduced to particular aspects of the research and writing process (topic delineation, finding sources, MLA citation style, structuring an essay, paragraph writing), and they submit short written assignments on each of these aspects.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lecture: 1 x 1.5 hours per week.", "Method of Assessment
Short written assignments graded with a pass or fail.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have participated in Literary Theory (L_ELBALES101).", "Literature
To be announced.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This module is part of the Bachelor’s program Literature & Society: English.", "Additional Information
This module is part of the BRCS (Binding Recommendation on Continuation of Studies). This means you have to pass this course in order to get a positive BRCS. If you do not pass this course, you will receive a negative binding recommendation for your study programme. This means you won’t be able to re-enroll in this particular VU programme for the next three years.
Passing the English Language Test (L_ELT) is a prerequisite for being awarded credits for this module."]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Creative writing offers students an opportunity to approach the object of their study from a new perspective: that of writing rather than reading. The objectives of this course are (1) to train students to read literary texts with an awareness of the writers’ poetic and narrative strategies, (2) to teach students to actively apply such literary techniques in their own writing of literary texts, (3) to introduce students to different theories on the relation between the writer and the meaning of the text. The course trains students' writing skills, aiming to foster a regular writing practice and a playfulness in approaching the act of writing that will sustain students' creative and academic writing practices throughout their curriculum. The seminar setup of a small writing community also trains students in drafting and revising their texts, as well as in providing constructive feedback on each other's work.", "Course Content
The course combines the reading of literary texts in English, with an eye on the authors' poetics, and the fostering of a practice of creative writing in which the studied techniques are used by students in their own literary texts.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
2 seminar meetings of 2 hours each per week.", "Method of Assessment

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students can:
Describe the role of globalization in different national and cultural contexts;
Explain the effect of globalization on identity, tourism, and nationalism, among other concepts;
Relate concepts used in class, such as “imagined communities” or “decentered identity” to current events and/or other texts and media;
Use cultural theory to analyze literary texts, both in class discussions and in writing;
Write a clear and coherent argument about one of the primary texts, and use theory to frame this argument.", "Course Content
What purpose does an attachment to “place” serve in a globalized world? How does our ability to travel and communicate across vast distances affect our own beliefs, perspectives, and identities? Who benefits from these experiences, and who is excluded? And what role does literature, specifically, play in all of these debates?
In this course, we cover these and other questions to figure out what it means to read and tell stories in a globalized world. Covering topics such as nationalism, identity, translation, race, and tourism, we explore both the limits and opportunities offered by literature in a transnational era.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars, 2 x 2 hours per week.", "Method of Assessment
You will be assessed on the following aspects:
Participation (20%)
Writing portfolio (30%)
Final essay or similar assignment (50%)
The precise details will be announced on the course syllabus, which will be posted on Canvas.
Please note that you must score at least 5,5 on both the final assignment and participation to pass the course.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have participated in Literary Theory (L_ELBALES101).", "Literature
To be announced in the course syllabus, which will be posted to Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience

["Course Objective
Students research and present on the possibilities and potential pitfalls of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society, track English.", "Course Content
This course is built around an interview assignment. First-year students interview a third-year student of the Literature and Society program, track English, to learn about the program’s possibilities and potential pitfalls. They subsequently present on their findings in class to an audience of the program’s students (years one, two, and three) and teachers.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
We meet once a week for two hours in period 4.
Attendance is mandatory.
Meetings are held on campus; no hybrid alternative is offered.
Devices with access to social media (this includes laptops) are not allowed in class. If an exception needs to be made for medical reasons, students must contact the academic advisor prior to the start of the course.
There will be no meetings in period 5.", "Method of Assessment
The course is assessed with either a pass (“voldaan”) or a fail (“niet voldaan”). For a pass (“voldaan”), students must satisfactorily execute the interview assignment, i.e., both conduct the interview and present in class. No alternative assignment will be offered.", "Additional Information Target Audience

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of the course students will
understand and be able to apply key themes and theories that underpin the genre of literature we call Life Writing.
have learned new vocabulary and methodologies found in Life Writing Studies.
be able to use the course tools to reflect on selected texts.
have practiced writing academically and creatively on the writing of life narratives.", "Course Content
Life Writing is a rather new, interdisciplinary field covering a broad spectrum of writing categories such as (auto)biography, memoir, diary, travel writing, graphic novel, letter writing, poetry and online blog. In this introductory course we will examine the various debates that life writing scholars have been engaged in since its beginning ca. two decades ago. Which new perspectives on historical events or the formation of identity can writing ‘from life’ reveal? How can life writing possibly retrieve and recover perspectives and voices that would otherwise be lost? How are politics and privileges involved in this? How do social, cultural, and technological shifts determine what, how and why people remember, and how they express their life experiences? These and more questions will be central to the class discussions.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Two interactive seminar sessions per week:
plenary discussions on the assigned texts (both creative texts and scholarly texts); some plenary discussions may be led by students
in-class group work (creative work; academic reflections)
videoclip viewings and discussion
discussion of written assignments
In addition, there may be one excursion to the VU Botanical Garden, the Amsterdamse Bos, or the medicinal garden at Beatrixpark (all located in the southern part of Amsterdam).
6 credits = 20 hours per week:
4 hours: class sessions
16 hours: self-study (including writing two Canvas posts; preparations for the final exam)", "Method of Assessment
Active class participation: 20%
Brief written assignments: 40% (2 Canvas posts)
Exam: 40% (digital exam via Testvision; on-campus)
Students will receive credits for the course if:
they have on time submitted the two written assignments (Canvas posts).
the grade for their exam is 5.5 or higher. If the exam grade is lower than 5.5 you can do the resit. You are not allowed to compensate the grade for your exam with grades for other assignments.
they have not missed more than two sessions. This course is not lecture-based but discussion-based. We need the critical input, insights, and response of all participants to build (on) our knowledge. The instructor is also obliged to follow the Faculty's 80% attendance rule for seminar sessions.", "Entry Requirements
Literature & Society: English students: You must have participated in Literary Theory (L_ELBALES101).
Exchange students: You must be doing (or have finished) a major in English literature. No exceptions will be made whatsoever.", "Literature
Caryl Phillips, Foreigners: Three English Lives (2007) (250 p.). You are kindly asked to purchase a copy of the text (hard-copy or E-book) or borrow from the VU Library or another library. In case a book order takes longer than planned the instructor is willing to share a PDF; but otherwise the instructor would like the author to be able to reap the benefits of their creative/intellectual work. For in-class use the instructor will distribute 'instructor's copies' of the text. Please return clean copies at the end of each class session.
Nan Shepherd, The Living Mountain (1977) (119 p.)
All secondary sources will be available online (Go to Canvas page -> Modules per week). You must bring your own photo-copies of the secondary texts, OR have them ready to consult on your laptop or I-pad. The use of cell-phones in class will not be allowed.", "Additional Information Target Audience
First year students of Literature & Society: English.
Exchange students: see above for prerequisites.", "Additional Information
Attendance required: 80%. Students who miss more than 20% will not receive credits for the course. Exceptions may be made in grave personal circumstances. Make sure to inform both your lecturer and the academic advisor in such cases.", "Custom Course Registration

However, for this module the instructor will assign the students to the seminar groups. Therefore, students should sign up for (i) the module, but not for (ii) the seminar groups.
Important: Before the course starts you must check the announcement on the Canvas course-page about the group divisions. For information about group divisions, all students need to follow the instructions provided by Canvas, not the information presented by the online VU Timetable.", "Explanation Canvas
Students must check the course's Canvas page daily for possible announcements about class sessions (preparations, texts, etc.), deadlines, and assignments.
Before the course starts you must check the Canvas announcement about the group divisions."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (2); Communication and Information Studies; Literature and Society
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of the course:

1. Knowledge
You are able to describe some of the core theoretical linguistic concepts in the study of English as a Lingua Franca. You are also able to describe major (socio)linguistic issues that arise in situations in which English is used as a Lingua Franca.

2. Skills
You are able to analyze aspects of spoken English (e.g. the transcription of human speech, with particular application to English).

3. Application
You are able to assess real-life situations of English as a Lingua Franca use; you are able to decide what is the best way to respond to them according to the knowledge and skills that you have developed in the course.

4. Attitude
You are able to reflect on the use of English as a Lingua Franca and to express your perspective on sociolinguistic issues that arise in this context. You are able to explain the significance of the study of spoken language for getting our messages across/expressing ourselves/understanding one another in international communication, and you will act accordingly where necessary.

5. Learning development
You are able to identify relations (as well as differences) between concepts and issues in English as a Lingua Franca use and other courses/fields in your study (compare-contrast); you value the ways in which different disciplines can complement one another.", "Course Content
English has become the leading language of international communication. The ratio of native-non-native speakers is currently 1:5 (David Crystal p.c.), and it is estimated that around 80% of all communication in English takes place between non-native speakers with different mother tongues (Osimik 2010). This international use of English has been termed ‘English as a Lingua Franca’. In the course, we will examine aspects of spoken English and explore both theoretical linguistic concepts as well as sociolinguistic issues of concern in the use of English as a Lingua Franca.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Period 5: Lectures (2 hrs p/w) and seminars (2 hrs p/w). Period 6: Group meetings
This course has seminars, but you cannot self-register for a group. If you want to know the times of all the workgroups, go to rooster.vu.nl, click on the options at the right hand side of the course title and select ‘Choose groups’. In the first week, your specific work group will be assigned by the course coordinator.", "Method of Assessment
Course work (in/complete)
A written exam (50%; individual mark) and a research assignment (50%; group mark).
To successfully complete the course, you need to obtain a grade of ≥5.5 for both components.
80% attendance of the seminars and submission of all of the course work by the set deadlines is conditional for being awarded a grade for the exam and the research assignment.
You will work with course objectives (1-5) in the course work. Objectives (1-2) will be assessed in the exam and objectives (3-5) in the research paper.", "Literature
Reading will be made available on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
First-year CIS and L&S students; premaster and exchange students."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students become acquainted with the study of identity representation in Shakespeare’s plays and sonnets as well as their film adaptations. By the end of the course, students can:
Interpret the selected primary texts, i.e., Shakespeare’s plays and sonnets as well as their film adaptations.
Explain the concepts and arguments put forward in the selected secondary literature.
Do all this in clear and concise written English.", "Course Content
Central to this course is the question: How does the representation of identity (mainly in terms of gender, ethnicity, sexuality, and age) shift from Shakespeare’s plays and sonnets to their film adaptations?
Topics and plays/film adaptations discussed in previous years include:
Social change in Romeo and Juliet (William Shakespeare, 1595).
Gender in Shakespeare in Love (John Madden, 1998) and Shakespeare’s sonnets (1609).
Ethnicity in West Side Story (Robert Wise and Jerome Robbins, 1961).
Sexuality in Private Romeo (Alan Brown, 2011).
Age in Wellkåmm to Verona (Suzanne Osten, 2006).
Both plays and film adaptations are subject to change.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
We meet once a week for four hours.
Attendance is mandatory.
Meetings are held on campus; no hybrid alternative is offered.
Each meeting consists of group discussions, exam instruction/practice, and a lecture portion.
Prior to each meeting, students complete a Canvas assignment.
Devices with access to social media (this includes laptops) are not allowed in class. If an exception needs to be made for medical reasons, students must contact the academic advisor prior to the start of the course.
There will be no meetings in period 6.", "Method of Assessment
Successful completion of the course is contingent on timely submission of all Canvas assignments and attendance at all meetings.
The full final grade for the course is based on a take-home exam consisting of short essay questions. The take-home exam will be held over three days in week 1 of period 6 (the week of 1 June 2026). English writing proficiency is a key aspect of the assessment.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have participated in the course Literary Theory (L_ELBALES101).", "Literature
To be announced in the course syllabus, which will be posted on Canvas well in advance of the start of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is part of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society, track English."]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
1. Knowledge
You are able to describe factors in the spread of English in the world and the ways in which varieties of English have evolved world-wide. You are also able to describe some of the social consequences of Global English (e.g. language loss, social inequality).
2. Skills
Within theories of language variation and change, you are able to analyse some of the major linguistic features of varieties of English around the world.
3. Attitude
You are able to present a well-informed perspective of the nature of different Englishes and the impact of the global spread of English on people in societies around the world.
4. Communication
You are able to report on topics in Global English in short oral presentations and in writing.
5. Competence
You are able to identify people’s needs regarding the English language, including your own, and you are able to decide on the best way to act upon it.", "Course Content
In the lectures, we will examine the spread of the English language around the world. We will begin with regions in the world where English is spoken as a first language (England, the Celtic countries, the U.S., Australia, etc.). We will then move on to regions where English is spoken as a second language (Africa and Asia), and from there to regions where English is used as a foreign language or a lingua franca (e.g. The Netherlands, Europe, Japan, and so on).
We will explore a range of issues in the global spread of English. These include: linguistic issues (variation in English, World Englishes), social issues ( language and identity, language and power, language death, linguistic exclusion and discrimination), and literary concerns (the use of English in postcolonial literature).
Some of the lectures are presented by guest lecturers from Scotland, Australia, Uganda and Japan.
In the seminar, we will address questions that have arisen from the lectures or the reading and we will discuss course work.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (2 hours per week) and seminars (2 hours per week)", "Method of Assessment
Course work, marked in/complete. You will obtain the course objectives (1-5) by working with the course work.
Exam, graded (100% of your grade for the course). Your attainment of course objectives (1-3) will be assessed in the exam.
To successfully complete the course, you must obtain a grade of ≥5,5 for the exam and have submitted mandatory course work by the set deadline.
1 absence from the seminars is allowed.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have passed Academic English CIS-L&S Writing and Academic English CIS-L&S: Grammar.
Students must also have participated in English: International Communication.", "Literature
Schneider, E.W. 2020. English Around The World. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. Second edition.
Other literature and materials will be made available in Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
CIS students, Literature & Society students, students in the Minor 'English', History students, premaster- and exchange students.", "Custom Course Registration
This course has seminars, but you cannot self-register for a seminar in VU-net. If you want to know the days/times at which the seminars have been scheduled, go to rooster.vu.nl; click the 'Options' button at the right-hand side of the course title and select ‘Choose groups’.
A couple of weeks before the start of the course, your course coordinator will invite you to sign up for a seminar via Canvas."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (2)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students
understand how travel writing is implicated in the processes of identity formation (both collective and individual) and intercultural exchange.
are able to apply theoretical notions (see below) to travel texts from ‘the long 19th century.’
can freely express their ideas in both written work and informal class discussions.
are able to engage in (and moderate) class discussions in a diversity-sensitive manner.
are (more) aware of socio-political issues that play a role in culturally diverse classroom settings.", "Course Content
This course introduces students to American and British literature written between the end of the 18th century and the beginning of the 20th century, the so-called 'long 19th century'. As it is impossible to cover all Anglo-American writing of this time-period in just seven weeks, we will focus on one specific genre: travel writing. This literary genre, which has been popular for centuries, has been much overlooked by academics and those constituting the British and American literary canons. New critical paradigms such as Transnationalism, Globalization, and Decolonization, however, necessitate a new and serious look at these texts.
We will close-read and analyze travel narratives written by authors who have produced some of the canonical texts from 'the long 19th century' (British and American), such as Charles Dickens, Robert Louis Stevenson and Margaret Fuller. In addition, we will close-read and analyze travel narratives written by authors who have been excluded from the literary canon, such as Mary Jane Seacole, Zilpha Elaw and Sarah Winnemucca Hopkins. We will discuss the major developments in the genre of (British and American) travel writing between the late 18th and early 20th century.
The course will address three themes:
Sensations of travel (weeks 1 - 2)
Taking risks (weeks 3 - 4)
The politics of travel (weeks 5 - 6)", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The class sessions (4 hours per week) will consist of:
plenary and group discussions. All sessions will be interactive sessions. The lecturer will not summarize the assigned readings; you must come to class prepared, and be able to discuss the assigned texts with your fellow students and instructor. If you have not been able to prepare for class, you should either skip the session or notify the instructor before class (via mail).
joint close-readings of the assigned texts. The instructor will distribute hard copies for in-class close-readings. These are 'teacher’s copies' that you will have to return at the end of each session. The idea behind this is that group and class discussions may benefit from focused readings without other distractions.
in-class group work.
brief student-led discussions.
film viewings (excerpts).
optional excursion to the National Maritime Museum, Amsterdam (final week).", "Method of Assessment
30% Participation (20% active class participation; 10 % student-led discussion)
30% Canvas posts
40% Exam (digital)
The weighted average of the final grade must be 5.5 or higher.
Students will receive credits for the course if they have
submitted all six Canvas posts before the deadline stated in the course syllabus and on Canvas. Each student is allowed to have one late Canvas post submission—within 24 hours of the announced deadline. If you upload after those extra 24 hours you will not be eligible to do the regular exam but you can do the resit. If you have two or more late submissions you will not receive credits for the course.
scored a 5.5 or higher for the exam. The weighted average of the final grade must be 5.5 or higher.
attended 10 sessions out of 12. The attendance rule (80%) follows the Faculty rule for seminar sessions. It is also related to the set-up of the course, which is discussion-based. Students who miss more than 2 sessions out of 12 will not receive credits for the course. This means that if you are planning to go away for a week (and thus miss two sessions), you will have to attend the sessions during the other weeks.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have participated in Literary Theory or one of the courses from the American Studies minor package.", "Literature
Selected (excerpts of) 19th century travel writings
Selected (excerpts of) 19th century canonized texts
Scholarly articles on travel writing
The excerpts mentioned above, plus the articles, will be announced and uploaded on Canvas well before the course starts.
For in-class work the instructor will provide teacher's copies (hard-copies) of the assigned readings.

Time investment for reading the assigned texts:
The total number of hours you will need when taking this course: 20 hours per week (students enrolled in L&S take two courses per block -> 40 : 2 = 20 hours per week).
This number is roughly divided as follows:
4 hours: classroom hours
16 hours: self-study (including writing a weekly Canvas post; preparing for exam)
Please note:
The 16-hour calculation is an average number. Some weeks you will spent more hours on self-study than others.
The above calculation excludes the writing of your exam: 2 hours and 45 min.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second-year students of the BA program Literature & Society: English; exchange students; participants in the Educational Minor (schoolvakminor) English Literature.", "Additional Information
Attendance required: 80%. This is according to Faculty rule. Students who miss more than 20% will not receive credits for the course. Exceptions will only be made in grave personal circumstances. Make sure to inform both your lecturer and the academic advisor in such cases.", "Custom Course Registration
Important note: There is a slightly different enrollment procedure for this module. The standard procedure of the Faculty of Humanities has students sign up for (I) the module, and (II) the form of tuition (lecture and/or preferred seminar group). However, for this module the instructor will assign the students to the seminar groups. Therefore, students should sign up for (I) the module, but NOT for (II) the seminar groups.
The group division will be published on the Canvas page 'Community Bachelor and Master English Literature'. Go to Homepage -> Modules -> Group Divisions in our Courses. The Group division is also announced in the online course syllabus. If you need to switch groups, please find someone from the other group who is prepared to swap with you. Then notify the course coordinator of this swap by e-mail, with the other student in the cc. If there is no one who is able to swap, please notify the instructor as soon as possible, but in any case before the start of the course.", "Explanation Canvas
Students should check Canvas regularly. Communication will occur via Canvas Announcement and Canvas Mail.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By the end of “American Literature 1914-present,” students can
Describe and explain the relevance of some of the common themes in modern American literature, such as the American Dream or the tension between individual expression and communal goals;
Compare and contrast literary movements of the 20th century
Articulate why and how the idea of crisis and reinvention recurs throughout modern American literature
Explain how and why social, cultural, and political changes in American society gave rise to new forms of literature;
Write a clear and coherent argument about one of the course texts that is rooted in literary analysis, connects this analysis to contemporary society, and supported by secondary sources.", "Course Content
Over the course of the twentieth century, American society underwent some tremendous changes. These changes are reflected in its literature, which not only grapples with world wars, culture wars, and the arrival of more diverse voices on the literary scene, but also experimented with form and genre.
For some, these changes felt like crises; for others, they felt like liberation. How has American literature reflected and responded to these social, cultural, and political changes? And in what way(s) has it grappled with crises and dilemmas? What defines American literature in the 20th century, and is there still such a thing as “the” American canon? In this course, we will examine these questions as well as others.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar meetings, 2 x 2 hours per week. Attendance is compulsory. Please note that you are not allowed to miss more than 3 classes, except in the case of grave personal circumstances. If such is the case, please notify both the professor and academic advisor as soon as possible.", "Method of Assessment
Students will be assessed based on in-class participation (30%) and a final essay (70%). The specifics of each assignment will be listed on Canvas and in the course syllabus.
In order to pass the course, students must receive a 5.5 or higher on both participation and the final assignment. There will be one resit possibility for the final assignment.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have participated in Literary Theory or one of the courses from the American Studies minor package.", "Literature
The Rabbit Hutch by Tess Gunty.
All other literature will be listed on the syllabus, which will be posted to Canvas well before the beginning of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This module is part of the Bachelor’s program English Literature & Society, year 2. This course is also part of the American Studies minor package and of the "Schoolvakminor English Literature" for students in CIS (specialization English Language and Communication Studies and specialization Language and Mind).", "Additional Information
The level of English in this course is high, and you will be expected to participate in class discussions.", "Custom Course Registration
There is a slightly different enrollment procedure for this module. The standard procedure of the Faculty of Humanities has students sign up for (i) the module, and (ii) the form of tuition (lecture and/or preferred seminar group). However, for this module the instructor will assign the students to the seminar groups. Therefore, students should sign up for (i) the module, but not for (ii) the seminar groups.", "Recommended background knowledge
To take this course, students must have completed Literary Theory."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Knowledge: You will be able to describe the most common difficulties in English pronunciation. You will also be able to describe four major aspects of speech fluency in English and how they can be practised or improved.
Skills: You will be able to analyse different English pronunciations with respect to challenging English pronunciation features, including your own. You will also be able to analyse aspects of speech fluency in English and carry out exercises to improve your fluency.
Attitude: You are able to present a well-informed view of the nature of different English pronunciations and you appreciate diversity in English.
Communication: You are able to explain the potential impact of particular pronunciation features on the intelligibility and credibility of spoken English.
Learning: You are able to adapt features in your own English pronunciation according to the English pronunciation that you wish to develop. You are also able to help and support others regarding their English pronunciation.", "Course Content
We will set goals for the English pronunciation that you wish to develop both at a professional and at a personal level. We will analyse the most common difficulties in English pronunciation and the effects that these difficulties may (inadvertently) have on the intelligibility and credibility of spoken English. We will also take account of the role of pronunciation features in identity construction. You will conduct exercises, practise ear-training and be given tools that help you analyse English pronunciation features, as well as speech fluency. You will work with features in your own English pronunciation accordingly.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Interactive lectures (1,5 hours per week) and seminars (1,5 hours per week).", "Method of Assessment
Course work (in/complete) and Ttwo recordings of your own pronunciation. The second recording will be graded (100%) according to the progress that you have made in relation to your first recording. To successfully complete the course, students should score a grade of ≥5,5.
Course attendance and submission of all of the course work by the set deadlines is conditional for being awarded a grade for the second recording. For the seminars, 1 absence is allowed.
Course objectives 1-4 will be attained through working with the course work. These objectives will lead to course objective 5 that is assessed in the second recording.", "Literature
Please note that the course does not use a text book; rather, the theoretical concepts will be explained in the lectures and be made available on PP-slides. It is assumed that you are familiar with these concepts before the seminars; they will not be repeated in the seminar. If absence of lectures leads to unfamiliarity with theoretical concepts, this may affect your grade.
The Pronunciation seminars are supported by online audio and video materials (https://english-pronunciation.weebly.com).", "Additional Information Target Audience
2nd year students English Literature & Society and exchange students (non-native speakers of English). If native speakers wish to develop and/or become familiar with an English pronunciation other than their own, they are very welcome.", "Additional Information
Literature & Society students who are native speakers of English AND/OR have completed their secondary education in an English-speaking country, OR have applied and been granted an exemption for the Pronunciation module may take the Presentation (L_ETBAALG009) module instead of Pronunciation. See also Additional information target audience."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successfully completing this course
you will have more insight into the language used in your discipline
you will be able to write a text in an appropriate academic style
You will also have greater insight into the strengths and weaknesses of your English writing skills
You will know how to further develop strengths and reduce weaknesses
You will be able to correct your own text and other people's texts for grammatical correctness and the specific linguistic features associated with coherence and cohesion
You will be able to take a critical look at your own English texts and those from your fellow students
You will develop the editing skills to improve it.", "Course Content
The main aim of this course is to further develop your writing skills in English, focusing on two aspects: your position as a writer in the academic world, i.e. as someone who is engaged in academic discourse; and editing, of your own and other people's texts. As a writer of academic texts, you need to be aware of appropriate structures at sentence level as well as at text level, of ways of using language to refer to other writers, and of ways of using academic language effectively. The emphasis in this course is on (a) gaining more insight into the language and style of your own academic discipline, (b) improving coherence, compactness and readability, and (c) developing your editing skills.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars each week", "Method of Assessment
Two analyses of specific linguistic features (stance/engagement/quoting and referring) in texts from your own discipline (2x30%; course objectives 1, 3, 5); comparative analysis (40%; course objectives 2, 4, 6, 7). In order to pass the course, you need a 5.5 minimum for each component.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have passed Academic English CIW-L&S: Grammar (L_EABAALG103) and Academic English CIW-L&S: Writing (L_EABAALG104).", "Literature
Strongly recommended: Hannay, M. & J.L. Mackenzie (2009). Effective Writing in English. 2nd edition. Bussum: Coutinho. There will also be separate materials posted on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year students of Literature & Society: English. The course is not open to students doing other degrees.", "Additional Information
Attendance is obligatory (80% minimum). If you miss more classes, you may still be allowed to finish the course if you submit an alternative assignment, but only if you’ve attended 70% of the classes."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Communication and Information Studies; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Course goal:
The focus of this course will be on Intercultural Philosophy. You will learn how philosophy helps to reflect on humanity and reality, in culturally differentiated ways.
Learning objectives:
You will get insight into how philosophers/philosophy help(s) to understand one’s own culture and that of others
You will acquire tools to critically question the claims to universal reason of ‘Western’ thinking
You are able to critically reflect on how your own cultural background influences your understanding
You can reflect in a philosophical manner, both collectively (in seminars) and individually (through assignments)", "Course Content
Philosophy is a discipline that focuses more on questions than answers. Examples of philosophical questions are: What is reality? What can human beings know? How do our academic frameworks steer our understanding? How does knowledge inform our practical life, and our morality?
In this course, we will focus on the intercultural aspects of philosophy, which center on the question of understanding. Human thinking is formed and rooted in cultures. These are not fixed, bounded wholes, but we are able to learn another culture from the inside by living in it, and can go back and forth through different cultures. How do we, however, translate between cultures? And how can we understand someone who is formed to think in another language, with different moral rules?
Due to colonialism, often in philosophy, Eurocentric philosophical traditions are centered while other forms of philosophy are neglected. From the end of the 20th century, German and Austrian philosophers have formed a school of Intercultural Philosophy as a way to address this. You will get acquainted with their approach, and with further developments of their thought by other philosophers. Using the intercultural philosophy approach, you will zoom in on the question of ‘Self-hood’ by reflecting on philosophies from African and Asian cultures.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Each week there are two lectures, and one seminar, for a total of 5.25 contact hours per week. In the lectures, students will be introduced to the readings and get an overview of the context they are situated in. In the seminars, they will help each other, under the guidance of an experienced teaching assistant, to read the text material, critically evaluate its contents, and apply them to real world questions.
Attendance of seminars is obligatory. If a student misses a seminar session, s/he has to do an extra assignment. Attendance of lectures is not mandatory but exam will comprise of lecture and seminar material. Complete procedure is described in the course manual.", "Method of Assessment
Personal Study Assignments (PSAs) to prepare for the seminars (pass/fail, assessment of learning objectives 3 and 4)
Take home exam (100% of final grade, assessment of learning objectives 1 and 2).
Final grade has to be at least 5,5.", "Literature
Literature will be announced and/or made available on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Students of CIS, L&S, MADA (2nd year).", "Additional Information
Obligatory 2nd year course."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After passing this course, you will:
be able to close read early modern literary texts;
be familiar with the fundamentals of (historical) ecocriticism;
be able to analyze literary texts from an ecocritical perspective;
be able to present your analysis in a brief essay.", "Course Content
In this course, we will explore the role of literature in changing relations with the natural environment in the early modern period (1550-1700). Even if we associate topics like air pollution, land grabbing, or the stripping of natural resources more readily with our current time frame, such environmental issues were encountered already in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.
We will be reading early modern literature from the perspective of ecocriticism, exploring how early modern texts (and images) represented and shaped the relation between humans and non-human others.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
2 x 2 hours seminar per week", "Method of Assessment
The final grade for this course is based Canvas assignments (50%) and a final exam (50%). You need to have a pass grade (5.5 or higher) for your final exam in order to pass the course.", "Entry Requirements

course_programmes: Hide full list (2)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course, students will:
have an understanding of the main historical developments that shaped our idea of what scientific or academic knowledge is;
understand how several institutions helped to create, preserve and pass on this knowledge throughout history;
have a broad overview of the changing practices of scholarly and scientific knowledge production over time;
understand how the advent of the internet, data digitisation and artificial intelligence have changed both the practices of knowledge production as well as the status and accessibility of knowledge;
be able to reflect on the position of their own discipline within today’s knowledge society", "Course Content
In the course History of Knowledge, we will focus on questions about what knowledge is and what was seen as valuable knowledge, from classical antiquity up until today, and the way this knowledge was preserved and passed on over time, with special attention for the institutions that played a major role in the process: the library, monasteries, the university, the Republic of Letters, the internationalisation of the sciences in the 19th century, and the latest developments marked by the digital turn and artificial intelligence. Students will learn to reflect about different styles and methods of knowledge production, the necessity of preserving existing knowledge, the relation between authoritative knowledge and power, the accessibility of knowledge over time and for various social groups, and the challenges for and the relevance of the humanities in the digital era.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course consists of lectures (2 x 2 hours a week).", "Method of Assessment
Written assignments (40%)
Final written examination (60%)", "Literature
A reading list will be provided via Canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is part of the 2nd year Bachelor’s programs History, Geschiedenis and Literature & Society: English", "Additional Information
This course is part of the Academic Core. Attendance is compulsory. Students may miss maximum 2 classes."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (2)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students become acquainted with the main developments and a number of key texts in British literature from 1900 to the present, with a focus on how fiction, through styles and themes, reflects its historical context. By the end of the course, students can:
Interpret the selected literary texts.
Explain the concepts and arguments put forward in the selected secondary literature.
Do all this in clear and concise written English.", "Course Content
This course tracks the history of British literature from the First World War and the height of the British Empire to the multicultural voices of contemporary Britain. It seeks to understand how authors reflected on the trials and tribulations of the twentieth century, when Britain went from being a world power with colonies around the globe to adjusting to a humbler role. We examine relevant cultural and literary movements, including realism, modernism, postcolonialism, and postmodernism, against their respective historical backdrops.
Topics and literary texts discussed in previous years include:
The move from realism to modernism in Virginia Woolf’s Mrs. Dalloway (1925).
The estate novel as a nostalgic genre in Evelyn Waugh’s Brideshead Revisited (1945).
The postcolonial rewriting of the nineteenth-century British bildungsroman in Jean Rhys’s Wide Sargasso Sea (1966).
The social critique of the effects of Thatcherism on the multicultural society in Hanif Kureishi’s My Beautiful Laundrette (1985) (both screenplay and film).
The postmodern revision of British literary history in Ian McEwan’s Atonement (2001).
Both topics and literary texts are subject to change.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
We meet once a week for four hours.
Attendance is mandatory.
Meetings are held on campus; no hybrid alternative is offered.
Each meeting consists of group discussions, exam instruction/practice, and a lecture portion.
Prior to each meeting, students complete a Canvas assignment.
Devices with access to social media (this includes laptops) are not allowed in class. If an exception needs to be made for medical reasons, students must contact the academic advisor prior to the start of the course.
There will be no meetings in period 6.", "Method of Assessment
Successful completion of the course is contingent on timely submission of all Canvas assignments and attendance at all meetings.
The full final grade for the course is based on a take-home exam consisting of short essay questions. The take-home exam will be held over three days in week 9 of period 5 (the week of 25 May 2026). English writing proficiency is a key aspect of the assessment.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have passed the course Literary Theory (L_ELBALES101).", "Literature
To be announced in the course syllabus, which will be posted on Canvas well in advance of the start of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is part of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society, track English."]

course_name: Novel and Identity: Women Writers in the Eighteenth Century

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

Explain foundational ideas in selected critical and cultural theories.
Apply theoretical frameworks to the close reading and interpretation of literary texts.
Analyze narrative structures, literary techniques, and thematic concerns across the selected novels.
Evaluate scholarly arguments and theoretical approaches in feminist literary criticism.
Create original, theory-informed interpretations and write critical essays using appropriate academic language and methodology.", "Course Content
The course will chart the history and development of women's writing in the Long Eighteenth Century. The course content will focus on the development of the novel as a genre in general and the ways in which it becomes pivotal in the expression and of women's identity in British culture from 1719-1820. We will build on and develop theoretical knowledge and particularly Feminist and New Historicist interpretation of the literature.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods

course_name: Bachelor Thesis Literature and Society English
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students learn how to: delineate a research topic; build a theoretical framework; structure an argument; analyze primary sources; find and assess secondary sources; write academic English; adhere to the MLA citation style; plan research and writing tasks; and incorporate feedback in their writing.", "Course Content
The thesis trajectory consists of two phases: (1) preparation and (2) writing. (1) During the preparation phase, students work in peer groups on the delineation of their thesis topic. This results in an individual thesis proposal. Based on the proposal, an individual supervisor is assigned. (2) During the writing phase, students meet with their supervisor for one-on-one feedback sessions on their written work. The outcome of the trajectory is a thesis of 7,000 to 10,000 words.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
(1) Preparation phase: two mandatory colloquium meetings. (2) Writing phase: three (optional) one-on-one meetings. The dates of both the colloquium and the one-on-one meetings will be announced in the syllabus, which will be posted on Canvas.", "Method of Assessment
The supervisor and a second assessor will assess the thesis on: topic delineation and relevance; use of theory; structured presentation of findings; precise analysis of primary materials; incorporation of secondary sources; cogency and persuasiveness of arguments; academic English writing; implementation of MLA citation style; and the student’s independence during both the preparation and writing phases.", "Entry Requirements
The Bachelor’s thesis trajectory is offered twice per academic year: (i) once in the Spring semester (the regular trajectory); and (ii) once in the Fall semester (for students who failed their thesis in the previous academic year). (i) The entry requirement for the Spring trajectory is: successful completion of all year 1 and year 2 modules of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society: English. (ii) The entry requirement for the Fall trajectory is: successful completion of all year 1 and year 2 modules, plus all year 3 (non-thesis) modules (including the modules/credits of the first semester) minus one, of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society: English.", "Literature
This will be decided on an individual basis.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This thesis trajectory is part of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society: English", "Additional Information
For any and all questions regarding the Bachelor’s thesis trajectory, students should contact the thesis coordinator (prof. dr. Diederik Oostdijk) via email (d.m.oostdijk@vu.nl).", "Custom Course Registration
Please check with the study advisor if you are not sure if you meet all the requirements to register for the thesis. Please note that as of this academic year, students no longer have to sign up separately for the Bachelor Thesis Colloquium Literature and Society English, which is now part of "Bachelor Thesis Literature and Society English."", "Explanation Canvas
All relevant information (e.g., syllabus, example theses, assessment form) will be posted on Canvas. In addition, students must upload sections and final versions of their thesis to Canvas. Hence, as soon as students have access to the Canvas site of the thesis trajectory, they should carefully read through all the documents posted there."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course, students are able to
close-read and compare English-language ‘African texts’ coming from the African continent and the African Diaspora; and from a variety of national, ethnic and cultural backgrounds, and various historical and socio-political contexts.
draw on academic theories that are relevant for an understanding of the two themes: The literary market (anthologies; literary prizes; canon formation; translations; exoticization) and Close reading (how to dissect a selection of short stories? Useful tools)
apply theoretical concepts to the texts studied, such as narration, focalization, orality, voice, agency, subject-position, representation, intersectionality, universal/particular/authentic, exoticization/stereotyping, neocolonialism, decolonization.
share their own reflections on the assigned readings with fellow participants.
freely express their ideas in both written work and oral presentations.
design and set up a brief class discussion with other members of their team.
engage in class discussions in a diversity-sensitive and respectful manner.", "Course Content
‘African writing' is booming, literary critics tell us. But what exactly is ‘African writing’? Is it possible and desirable to use this label? Which realities are being documented, and who is eligible to 'document'? Can we speak of ‘African’ literary traditions, and if so, are they different from other literary traditions? How Western-focused are the popular writers who are marketed as ‘African’? Who are the gatekeepers of the continent’s book industry? In order to be able to tackle these and other important questions we will close-read and contextualize one literary genre coming from the African continent and the African Diaspora that is particularly thriving: the short story, including flash fiction and online blogs.
Class discussions will focus on two themes:
The literary market: anthologies; literary prizes; canon formation; translations; exoticization
Close reading: how to dissect a selection of short stories? Useful tools", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Interactive seminar sessions:
close-readings of the assigned texts (both creative texts and academic articles)
videoclip viewings and discussion
in-class group work
student-led discussions (in groups and/or plenary)
discussion of written assignments
One or two guest speakers from the literary field
Possibly one excursion (museum, lecture at a cultural institute, film viewing, outdoor field-trip)", "Method of Assessment
30%: Participation (10% class participation; 20% student-led discussion)
30%: Written assignments (personal journal entries)
40%: Written exam
Please note: Students will only receive credits for the course if
they have on time submitted all journal entries. If they have not submitted them all on time, they will not be eligible to do the exam, but they can do the resit exam.
the grade for the exam is 5.5 or higher. If the exam grade is lower than 5.5 they can do the resit. They are not allowed to compensate the grade for the exam with grades for other assignments.
they have not missed more than two sessions.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have passed all courses of the first year and they must have taken part in all three second-year courses on the literary-historical overview (L_NABALES202, L_NABALES203 and L_NABALES204).", "Literature
We will read short stories by authors from Botswana, Kenya, Nigeria, Somalia, South Africa, and more places. This is meant to emphasize the heterogeneity of literary themes and strategies originating in individual African countries and in the African Diaspora.
The discussions will draw on primary sources (short stories) and secondary sources (introductions to anthologies; academic articles).
All texts will be made available through Canvas.
Your instructor also has a few packets of hard-copies for students to borrow.
During some sessions the instructor may distribute hard copies of the assigned readings (teacher's copies), so that we can close-read certain passages without getting distracted.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA students in the English track of Literature and Society
Exchange students pursuing a bachelor in English literature or literary studies", "Additional Information
Students should be sufficiently proficient both in speaking and writing in English to take part in this 300-level course.
Students should be aware that the level of theoretical reflection in this course is accordingly high.", "Explanation Canvas
Before the course starts, students must check the Canvas page for the course to obtain information about the course schedule and preparatory readings.
During the course, students must check Canvas very regularly. Communication about the course (including assignments and class sessions) will occur via Canvas Announcements and Canvas Mail."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students become acquainted with narratology (the theory of narratives) in relation to the interpretation of multimodal texts. By the end of the course, students can:
Explain selected narratological concepts.
Apply these concepts to the interpretation of selected multimodal texts.
Do all this in clear and concise written English.", "Course Content
Central to this course is S., a multimodal novel conceived by J. J. Abrams and written by Doug Dorst, published in 2013. Designed to look like an aged library book, S. contains: the novel Ship of Theseus by the fictional author Straka; a foreword and footnotes by the fictional editor and translator Caldeira; and handwritten comments in the margins plus inserted paraphernalia (e.g., maps, postcards, newspaper clippings) by two fictional readers, Jen and Eric. Furthermore, the transmedia universe of S. comprises a YouTube trailer, fictional radio broadcasts, alternative versions of the final chapter posted on Tumblr, and Twitter accounts by Jen and Eric.
We analyze S. in relation to selected narratological concepts, including:
Levels and narrators: S. consists of multiple embedded narrative levels, each with their own narrator.
Metalepsis: narrators and characters can transgress the boundaries between narrative levels.
Focalization: the agent who narrates (the narrator) does not always overlap with the agent who perceives (an event in) the story-world (focalization).
Multimodality: S. combines multiple sign systems (including typography, color, drawings, and material inserts) to convey its various narrative levels.
Authorship: S. reflects different theorizations of authorship current in literary theory, including the biographical, New Critical, and poststructuralist approaches.
The theoretical concepts are subject to change.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
We meet once a week for four hours.
Attendance is mandatory.
Meetings are held on campus; no hybrid alternative is offered.
Each meeting consists of group discussions, exam instruction/practice, and a lecture portion.
Prior to each meeting, students complete a Canvas assignment.
Devices with access to social media (this includes laptops) are not allowed in class. If an exception needs to be made for medical reasons, students must contact the academic advisor prior to the start of the course.", "Method of Assessment
Successful completion of the course is contingent on timely submission of all Canvas assignments and attendance at all meetings.
The full final grade for the course is based on a take-home exam consisting of short essay questions. The take-home exam will be held over three days in week 8 of period 4 (the week of 23 March 2026). English writing proficiency is a key aspect of the assessment.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have passed the course Literary Theory (L_ELBALES101).", "Literature
To be announced in the course syllabus, which will be posted on Canvas well in advance of the start of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is part of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society, track English."]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course, students are able to:
design, set up and run a small-scale symposium based on their work for Literature in a Changing World 1 and 2 in collaboration with their fellow students.
rework their block 4 essay in order to present that at the symposium.
share their own reflections on assigned readings with fellow participants.
freely express their ideas in both written work and oral presentations.
engage in class discussions in a diversity-sensitive and respectful manner.", "Course Content
This module is a sequel to Literature in a Changing World 1, in which we examine significant questions that come with the growing popularity of "African writing"--Which African realities are being documented, and who is eligible to do so? Are African literary traditions different from other literary traditions. In Changing World 2, we will shift focus to Caribbean Literature in order to explore differences and similarities in two Postcolonial contexts.
In the course Literature in a Changing World 2 students design, set up and run a small-scale symposium based on their work for Literature in a Changing World 1 and 2. They do so in collaboration with their fellow students. In addition they can rework their block 4 essay in order to present that at the symposium. Possible symposium components: research pitches, panel discussion, poster presentations, keynote (invited speaker), interview keynote speaker, response to keynote speaker, moderating discussion with audience. The target audience for the symposium: fellow students of the BA program Literature and Society and the MA program on Literature; instructors of the programs and of the Faculty; prospective students; library staff; guest speakers LCW1.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods

You need to score a pass grade (5.5 or higher) for your group work in order to pass the course. You need to earn a 5 or higher for the other partial grades in order to pass the course. The weighted average of the final grade must be 5.5 or higher.", "Entry Requirements

course_name: Data Structures and Algorithms for AI
course_programmes: Hide full list (6)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The goal of this course is to introduce Bachelor students enrolled in the target audience program to the basic concepts of data structures and algorithms. After taking this course, students will have gained (i) basic knowledge of data structures and algorithms, (ii) ability to analyse complexity of algorithms, and (iii) recognize trade-offs and choose an appropriate data structure and algorithm to solve a particular problem. Specifically, the student will have reached the following learning outcomes:
Describe the basic data structures and algorithms that are used for common computational problems (Knowledge and understanding; Communication).
Explain the role of algorithm complexity (time and space) in addressing problems and make complexity judgements on simple programs (Applying knowledge and understanding; Communication).
Explain the rationale of the proposed solution and possibly apply appropriate techniques on a concrete problem instance (Applying knowledge and understanding; Communication).
Identify and review pros and cons of proposed techniques for solving problems (Knowledge and understanding; Lifelong learning skills).", "Course Content
The content of the course is organised in weekly lectures, where the lecturer will cover the concepts of linear data structures (e.g., linked list, trees, graphs), basic notion of time and space complexity, which will be discussed on simple programs (e.g., sorting), and basic algorithms for traversing trees and graphs (e.g., search or decision trees). The introduced concepts will be accompanied by an explanation of the difference between solving the same problem by using a different method. More advanced topics will be covered towards the end of the course. The students will work on individual assignments during the weekly lab sessions which consist of practical programming challenges aimed to deepen their understanding of the topics covered during the lectures. The programming assignments will be automatically tested for correctness and efficiency, the latter being a determinant characteristic.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course is based on the following teaching methods:
Weekly lectures introducing new topics
Weekly lab sessions where student TAs will supervise students working on practical exercises
Assignments in the form of programing challenges including analytical tasks describing the implemented solution to an algorithmic problem", "Method of Assessment
Assignments: 30%
Theory + Practicum A: 35%
Theory + Practicum B: 35%
Assignments:
Points will be assigned with the following grading scheme:
5% assessment of the first lab assignment (A1)
5% assessment of the second lab assignment (A2)
10% assessment of the third lab assignment (A3)
10% assessment of the fourth lab assignment (A4)
Theory + Practicum:
Part A (35%): There is a first exam (in person) assessing the material covered in the first half of the lectures and the first two assignments. This examination takes place at the end of September.
Part B (35%): There is a second exam (in person) assessing the material covered in the second half of the lectures and the third and fourth assignments. This examination takes place at the end of the course.
For multiple choice tests the university standard method of correction for the chances of random answers is applied.
Resit:
There is a single resit for the examinations Part A and Part B but not the assignments
Passing requirement:
To pass the course, a student needs to pass (>5.5) on all components (assignments, theory, practicum)
Plagiarism:
The assignment submissions are automatically evaluated for plagiarism. If the submitted code (and not the boiler plate) is flagged for plagiarism the student will be reported to the Examination Board.", "Literature
Introduction to algorithms. Thomas H. Cormen et al. 4th edition.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Bachelor Artificial Intelligence (Year 2)", "Recommended background knowledge
Introduction to programming (Python) (X_401096). Good working knowledge of Python is strongly advised and if not present, the student should be prepared to put extra effort for programming in Python.
Some background in discrete mathematics and calculus is advised (polynomial and exponentials functions, logarithmic function, function compositions, simple series, factorial calculus, etc.)"]

teaching_method: Seminar, Practical, Written partial exam, Lecture
course_programmes: Hide full list (4)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The objective of the course Equational Programming is to obtain a basic understanding of the foundations of functional programming via lambda calculus and equational reasoning and to acquire basic functional programming skills.
For lambda calculus, at the end of the course, the student will:
Knowledge and understanding:
know alpha-conversion, lambda terms, beta-reduction, reduction sequences, reduction graphs,
know fixed points,
know weak and strong normalization and confluence,
know several reduction strategies,
know the encoding of several data types,
know simple types and be familiar with its typing system;
Applying knowledge and understanding:
be able to give reduction sequences and reduction graphs,
be able to reason about fixed points,
be able to reason about weak and strong normalization and uniqueness of normal forms,
be able to apply a reduction strategy,
be able to encode elementary data types and recursive functions,
be able to give elementary typing derivations;
Making judgements:
be able to analyze reduction graphs,
be able to reason about encodings.
For the equational specification part, at the end of the course, the student will
Knowledge and understanding:
know equational specifications,
know algebras, models, initial models,
know the notions of syntactic derivability and semantic consequence, know Birkhoff's theorem,
know the notion of initial specification,
know homomorphisms and isomorphisms between Sigma-algebras;
Applying knowledge and understanding:
be able to give a derivation,
be able to define an (initial) specification,
be able to give an (initial) model,
be able to give or show non-existence of an isomorphism;
Making judgements:
be able to analyze with respect to being a model, containing junk or confusion, being an initial model
be able to reflect on specifications and their relation with functional programs;
Communication:
be able to write proofs and derivations;
For the functional programming part, at the end of the course, the student will
Knowledge and understanding:
be familiar with the basics of the functional programming language Haskell: pattern matching, recursive functions, algebraic data types, and the basics of monads;
Applying knowledge and understanding:
be able to write small Haskell programs with pattern matching, and recursion,
be able to deal with partial functions using monads.
Learning skills:
have acquired flexibility in using the functional style of programming.", "Course Content
In the practical work, we use the functional programming language Haskell. We practice with the basics such as lists, recursion, data-types, and a bit of monads.
The theoretical part is concerned with the foundations of functional programming in the form of lambda calculus and equational specifications. We study untyped lambda calculus reduction theory and expressive power: beta reduction, reduction strategies, confluence, encoding of data types, fixed-point combinators, and recursive functions. In addition, we study the lambda-calculus with simple types, its typing system and a type inference algorithm, and possibly strong normalization of simply-typed lambda-calculus. In the equational specifications part, we study the syntax and semantics of equational systems, and we work towards the results that all initial models are equal up to isomorphism and that the term model is an initial model.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
We have two on campus lectures per week for the duration of seven weeks.
Twelve lectures discuss material and two lectures are meant for questions and wrap-up.
We have one on campus exercise class per week for the duration of seven weeks.
The lectures are concerned with the theoretical part, so lambda calculus and equational specifications.
In addition, we have one online Q&A afternoon per week for the functional programming part, for the duration of six weeks.", "Method of Assessment
There are three obligatory programming assignments with grade pass/fail.
All three must be pass in order to pass the course.
A fail grade for an assignment can during the course be improved to a pass grade using the feedback. After the course, there is only a resit possibility for the programming part for those students who already actively participated (as in: handed in all assignments) and have a pass grade for the exam, in consultation with the teacher.
There is a written closed book midterm exam in week 4 of the course about the lambda calculus part that counts for 45%.
There is a written closed book final exam in week 8 of the course about the equational specifications part and a bit of functional programming that counts for 55%.
Both parts should have grade at least 5.0 in order to pass the course.
In addition, the calculated final grade must be at least 5.5 to pass the course.
The resit is either about one of the two parts, or about both parts.", "Literature
Course notes, slides, and exercise sheets provided via Canvas.
We further refer to various online material about Haskell for example the Haskell wiki.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Bachelor Mathematics (elective)
Minor Deep Programming", "Explanation Canvas
We use Canvas for the schedule of the course, and to make available the course notes and the slides for the lectures, the exercises for the exercise classes, and the programming assignments.
We use Canvas further to provide feedback to the obligatory programming assignments, and to the non-obligatory homework assignments, to give the grade for the midterm, and for announcements.", "Recommended background knowledge
For the theoretical part, some familiarity with formal reasoning is recommended (as for example taught in the course Logic and Modelling)."]
