course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course successfully, students should be able to:
Problematise the complex and culturally layered phenomenon of dwelling in relation to architecture, (interior) design, ritual, usage and custom;
Understand the culture of ‘home’ and dwelling within design historical developments and in socio-cultural and historical contexts;
Read plans, elevations, sections, etc.;
Reproduce in writing the most important interpretations and definitions within the study of domestic space and related concepts, by studying and synthesizing relevant academic literature.
The student acquires knowledge and insight into dwelling as a cultural practice and domestic space as a layered form of cultural expression and how these are defined in various contexts. The student develops the ability to understand domestic space as an ambiguous concept and studies to be able to place it within a historical as well as a contemporary setting.", "Course Content
The way in which people live is prominent in today’s popular media. From celebrities profiles in Architectural Digest, to Instagram: ‘home’, domestic spaces, interior design and dwelling are instantly connected to the development of a particular lifestyle and to personal choices made within current trends. However, dwelling is much more than the popular media would suggest. It is a complex and layered activity of cultural significance. This course highlights several components of the study of the domestic, dwelling and housing culture, such as domestic and interior architecture, concepts of ‘home’ and dwelling, policy versus practices, the impact of changing technology and the concept of domesticity. Throughout the course these components are connected to the choices that designers and residents make or made in the designing, building and furnishing of their homes. The course pays attention to both contemporary and historical interpretations of domestic space.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, practical and excursions.
The lectures of this course are offered in English. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks)", "Method of Assessment
Matching of assignments and course objective:
All learning goals will be addressed during the weekly meetings and will be practiced through practical and written exercises and a smaller midterm assignment (assignment 2), a substantial paper (assignment 1), and a written exam (assignment 3) at the end. Assignments 1 and 3 will be graded, assignment 2 only has to be completed (graded as pass/fail). In order for the final grade to be published, assignment 2 has to be graded with a ‘pass.' Assignments 1 and 3 each count for 50% of the final grade, but to pass the course they both need to have been graded with at least 5.5 (sufficient).
Connection between learning objectives and assessment:
Learning objective 1 and 4: assignment 1 (paper)
Learning objective 1-4: assignment 2
Learning objectives 2 and 3: assignment 3 (exam)
Final Attainment Levels (eindtermen) BA MKDA: 1,2,4,5,8,9", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
Digital reader provided by your tutor in advance.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Design or Architecture as their specialization. It is open as an elective to other MKDA students.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.", "Custom Course Registration
For exchange approval of the coordinator is requested to be admitted to the course."]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Design
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Be familiar with the theoretical notions of urban culture and public space, and with the design aspects and the implicit methods of inclusion and exclusion that are connected to these notions;
Know how to actively analyze urban space, the objectives of its designers, and the ways in which citizens put public space to use;
Be able to connect historical, sociological and anthropological concepts with primary sources (e.g., know how to analyze public space through observation);
Have improved their academic skills through individual study, group work, and a final report.", "Course Content
Public space is omnipresent in our daily existence as represented in the streets, squares and public buildings of our cities. Public space is where we meet friends and strangers, encounter new ideas and objects, commemorate and celebrate, discuss our worries or simply enjoy the moment.
This course focuses on the multifaceted relationship between public space and urban culture by taking into account the (historical and contemporary) intentions and experiences of designers, planners, developers, and users. We will ask what the terms 'urban culture' and 'public space' mean in different times and cultures, and we will look into the relationship between the intentions and ideals of the ‘makers’ of public space (architects, urban designers, planners, and commissioners) and the perception and ideals of its users, the public.
The course offers a kaleidoscopic journey into the past and present of our everyday living environment, probing into the question what public space can be, how it comes into being and how it is transformed. We will study prevailing writings on urban culture and public space and investigate case studies, both in lectures and on site.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Teaching methods include lectures, seminars, and excursions.
The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English only and assignments should be submitted in English. Students following the Dutch (bilingual) track and having particular reasons for wanting to submit assignments in Dutch also in this course, should discuss this with the course coordinator in the first week of classes.", "Method of Assessment
Midterm exam (40%): learning objectives 1
Group project (20%): learning objectives 2,3,4
Final report (40%): learning objectives 1,2, 3, 4
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,5,8,9", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
The literature will later be announced in the syllabus and on Canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year. It is open to students with backgrounds in History or Planning. For exchange students, the approval of the coordinator of this course is requested", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]

course_name: Bachelor Thesis Media, Art, Design and Architecture
track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Design
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The thesis trajectory consists of two parts:
The thesis colloquium includes group exercises in doing research for and writing theses;
The actual thesis which is supervised by one of the teachers of MKDA.
Ba thesis colloquium:
The student demonstrates that she/he is independently able to develop a work plan that serves as a starting point for the thesis and that meets the guidelines of the program. This work plan addresses research into primary and secondary sources and methodologies relevant to the formulated thesis research, and includes a structured bibliography as the first phase for this thesis research.
The student is able to evaluate work of fellow students orally and in writing ('peer feedback').
Thesis:
The student demonstrates the ability to independently and according to AcVa guidelines compose an academic text based on research methods commonly used in Media, Art, Design and Architecture, and can complete it within a defined period of time;
The student demonstrates an understanding of theories and (subject-related) methodologies in the chosen specialization, and to be able to apply them to one or more cases;
The student demonstrates that she/he is able to independently search relevant and reliable sources and academic literature in relation to the topic;
The student demonstrates that she/he can academically legitimate the text and compile a structured bibliography;
The student demonstrates having obtained academic skills for Bachelor year 3 in terms of the structure of the thesis and use of language, with correct incorporation of literature/bibliography.", "Course Content
The BA thesis is a proof of the achieved skill level for year 3 (300) regarding content and theory in one of the specialisations Media, Art, Design, and Architecture or in an interdisciplinary combination or MKDA general. As completion of the bachelor program Media, Art, Design and Architecture, in the second semester of the third year (period 3,4,5) the student independently writes a thesis of 12 credits (thesis & colloquium).
The thesis should attest to the knowledge accumulated in the program of MKDA, with emphasis on the chosen specialisation (media, art, design or architecture) or an interdisciplinary combination of two directions.
For the BA thesis, these are the ways to determine at a thesis topic:
Selection list: In a plenary information session in fall of the academic year of graduation, the program informs students about themes and possible topics from which to choose within the student's specialisation.
Course from the graduate program: the student takes a research seminar in the bachelor program and can use this course to formulate a thesis topic. The problem / research question is in line with the theme of the course, but clearly differs from that of the assignment completed as part of completing that course.
Own topic: exceptionally and only with the prior approval of the intended thesis supervisor, students may choose their own topic.
The Media, Art, Design and Architecture bachelor thesis is a written paper of 7,000-10,000 words (excluding notes and literature, and appendices) that is largely completed independently under the guidance of a thesis supervisor. The thesis is a text composed on the basis of literature review and/or source research and possibly some archival research. The bachelor thesis may be used for further study of already collected material, or to explore certain themes in more detail. In doing so, the student may also combine more or less concurrent modules from the Media, Art, Design and Architecture study or possibly minors.
The ba thesis colloquium involves reflection on the formal aspects of writing the bachelor thesis during seminar meetings and during which students comment on each other's work ('peer review'). In each meeting one phase of the research and writing process is discussed based on examples.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Individual study and supervision by a docent of the respective specialisation (thesis);
Lectures and seminars (thesis colloquium)", "Method of Assessment
Thesis (100%) / participation, assignments and peer review (thesis colloquium)
Alignment of learning objectives and assessment:
The course format is self-study. The intended learning objectives of the module will be assessed against the written thesis and according to criteria of the thesis assessment form available on VU-net and/or Canvas. This assessment form can also be found in the study manual of the thesis and the criteria for assessment of this form will be discussed in the thesis colloquium. Correlation assessment and learning objective: Thesis (100%): 1 ,2 ,3 ,4 ,5
End terms BA MADA: 1, 2, 3 ,4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 10, 11", "Entry Requirements
In order to begin the thesis process, third-year students must have completed all courses of the first year and the second year (cf. Teaching and Examination Regulations (TER)).", "Literature
Literature for the thesis colloquium will be announced in due course via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
3rd year bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture students who meet the entry requirements.", "Additional Information
Being enrolled in this course does not guarantee that you will actually be allowed to start the final thesis trajectory, as a final (or conditional) decision on this will only be made in January based on the courses passed until then. Students are informed by the end of January whether they will be allowed to proceed.
The thesis track can only be completed if the thesis colloquium has been followed and the thesis has been graded with a minimum of 6.0.", "Custom Course Registration
For this course, you must sign in yourself. The registration and deregistration deadlines are listed on VU.nl. Late registration is not possible for this course!"]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Design
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Acquiring knowledge and insight into discussions and problematic issues with regard to image and visual culture, in particular in terms of iconoclasm and idolatry.
Analytic skills: through text analysis of the course literature and preparation for seminar discussions.
Active processing of the course content in the form of participation in group discussion during the seminars.
Writing skills: demonstrated by coherent answers to the exam questions that reflect knowledge acquired from the lectures, seminars and readings.", "Course Content
After the historical and theoretical study of visual and material culture in years 1 and 2, year 3 of the bachelor of MKDA (Media, Art, Design and Architecture) problematises the concept of visual culture by paying attention to the critique of the image and to iconoclasm.
Attention will be paid to religious and political iconoclasm (e.g. the Iconoclastic Fury of the Reformation); theoretical critique of 'ocular-centrism' and its effects on film theory; the problematisation of the image in modern art; iconisation and iconoclasm in design; and the (imagination of) the city as contested area.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars.", "Method of Assessment
Weekly uploads of questions for the discussions in the seminar, to be submitted on Canvas (course objectives 1,2,3)
Written exam: the assessment of this course takes place through a written exam (closed book) of 1.5 hours duration (course objective 4)
The exam counts for 100% of the final grade, but discussion questions must beforehand have been passed as 'sufficient', in order to be allowed to start with the exam.
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9", "Entry Requirements
See Teaching and Exam Regulations (OER) MKDA.", "Literature
Dario Gamboni, The Destruction of Art: Iconoclasm and Vandalism since the French Revolution. London (Reaktion Books) 1997, pp. 13-30.
Additional articles on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Compulsory for all 3rd year MKDA students (all specializations).
Exchange students: only 3rd-year bachelor students with a background in Cultural Studies, Media Studies, or Art or Design History, within Faculties of Arts or Humanities, and with a good command of the English language.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.
Missing the first lecture (which also serves as an introduction to the course) may result in expulsion from the course.
Written assignments can be submitted in English or Dutch, but students planning an English taught MA are strongly recommended to write in English."]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Design
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The course has the following learning objectives:
Training analytical skills: applying a specific concept (design and time) in academic research into design, architecture, decorative art and/or material culture.
Training research skills: Learning to search and apply historical and contemporary visual and written primary sources in case studies and with regard to design.
Training of writing skills: writing an academic paper of 3000 words, excluding notes and literature.
With the above learning objectives, the course builds on the second-year courses: Graphic Design, Fashion History and Theory, Historiography of Art, Design, Architecture. Skills gained in Academic Skills and Research Techniques are practiced. The primary focus is on formulating workable problems, conducting research, finding relevant primary and/or secondary sources, compiling a suitable bibliography, and presenting the findings in the format of an academic paper according to academic standards.", "Course Content
This working group will study design, applied art and / or material culture from a specific starting point: Design and Time. The history of design is bound up with conceptions of time as it relates to space, the body and impacts the psyche. This course examines how designed objects were shaped by the emergence of clock time, the rhythms of work and leisure, the increasing speed of life and communications as well as ideas of the past and future.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Working group with active participation in discussions, midterm assignment(s), written assignment (approximately 3000 words).
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.", "Method of Assessment
1. Midterm assignment (s): 30% of the final mark;
2. Written paper: 70% of the final mark. This piece of work must score a minimum of 6.0. If the mark is lower than 6.0 on first submission, there is one resit.
The Midterm Assignment consists of a 1000-word draft based on your ideas for the final paper on some aspect of Design and Time. To develop the final paper, you continue to work on this theme towards the completion of a full academic research essay.
Coherence between learning objectives and test forms:
Learning objective 1 (analytical skills). Assessment method: written paper (70%).
Learning objective 2 (research skills). Assessment method: mid-term assignment (s) (30%), written paper (70%).
Learning objective 3 (writing skills). Assessment method: written paper (70%).
The two partial marks together determine the final mark. This must be at least 6.0 to pass the course.
End Terms BA MKDA: 2, 5, 6, 9.", "Entry Requirements
See Education and Examination Regulations BA MKDA.
All courses of MKDA Bachelor year 1 and 2 must have been passed.", "Literature
Will be available on Canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA3 students MKDA with a specialization in Design."]

course_name: Current Debates in Art and Culture
track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Design
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students will gain practice in developing informed opinions on specific issues that they deem relevant, and in defending and substantiating a position, both orally and in writing.
At the end of this course students should be able to:
analyze debates on visual art and material culture in such a way that they are able to contextualize current developments, position them within a discourse that relates to art and culture, and reflect critically upon various positions in relation to them;
apply knowledge of the forces that shape visual and material culture to contemporary cases, take a position, underpin it with relevant arguments, and pose innovative questions for research;
present a position both orally and in writing, offering substantiated arguments and pointing to (scholarly) sources;
contribute to group discussions and provide feedback to fellow students in an informed and constructive way;
revise written arguments based on feedback given by peers and the instructor.", "Course Content
This course considers debates in the field of visual and material culture, centered around a selection of public events (lectures, debates, exhibitions). Through the engagement with selected ‘current’ debates, the students are stimulated to reflect on their own positions and career paths, and apply their knowledge and further develop their expertise to act in the professional field of visual and material culture. The specific course content depends on contemporary discourse, events taking place in the field, and the academic assessment of the instructor.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars, excursions (visits to events)", "Method of Assessment
50% Written assignments (learning objectives 1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
50% Final paper (learning objectives 1, 2)
This course contributes to the BA MKDA final attainment levels 4, 8 and 11", "Literature
Given the focus on current debates, literature is subject to change each year.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Year 3 MKDA students.", "Additional Information
All lectures, class discussions, and about half of the required course readings will be in English. The selection of public events and debates (and additional information) during the course, will be accessible in English, Dutch, or a combination of both. Students who master Dutch, are encouraged to write their assignments in Dutch.
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]

course_name: Early Modern Art: Production and Reception
track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Have acquired knowledge and understanding of the production and reception of the visual arts in Western Europe in the early modern period (1400-1800), understood within a larger visual and cultural-historical context;
Have critically read, compared and analysed recent art historical research, devoted in particular to stylistic and material aspects of art objects in the early modern period;
Know how to apply skills related to the research, analysis, and interpretation of works of art. Skills to be developed include the critical observation of original works of art in museums, the visual determination of the most important painting and printmaking techniques, and the application of the correct terminology for the visual and iconographic analysis of works of art. In addition, students learn to recognize and do research into some important themes within iconography;
Be able to critically observe, describe and research works of art on location in public institutions (such as the Rijksmuseum and the RKD-Netherlands Institute for Art History), to develop an individually chosen research perspective related to the themes of production and/or reception, and to clearly present their findings in a written paper.", "Course Content
The phenomenon of the Western-European visual arts in the early modern period can largely be explained by dynamic processes of production and reception. The creation or production of works of art took place under artistic, intellectual, religious, political, or social conditions that either directly or more subtly influenced the reception of those works of art in later periods. At the same time, new developments such as the scholarly approach to art-historical research, the creation of institutions like public art museums, or the development of techniques of reproduction have added new dimensions to the reception of art in general.
Therefore, understanding the production and reception of art provides the opportunity to connect the history of art works with current debates. Under the theme of production, this course provides lectures on studio practice and art theory, the role of the patron, and on the fragmentary character of early modern art. Under the theme of reception, attention is paid to the (historical) reputation artists, the practice of collecting and displaying art, and recent insights into the global context of early modern art. The content of the course is partly based on the (ongoing) research carried out by the lecturer(s). There are excursions, among others, to the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam, and the RKD – Netherlands Institute for Art History in The Hague.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, and excursion. The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English only. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks).", "Method of Assessment
This course comprises one written assignment (40%) and one written exam (60%). Both components have to be passed with a sufficient grade (6.0 or higher). Only components graded with an insufficient grade can be re-sit.
Connection between learning objectives and assessment:
Learning objective 1: written exam
Learning objective 2: written exam, written assignment
Learning objective 3: written exam, written assignment
Learning objective 4: written assignment
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 12", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
A list of mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas and/or the study manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Art as their specialisation, and for pre-Masters Art & Culture (KMC). It is open as an elective to other MKDA students.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Be familiar with the concept of 'exhibition', historically, theoretically, and practically;
Be acquainted with international landmark exhibitions as well as exemplary Dutch institutions;
Demonstrate an understanding of the networked character of the art system and cultural sector, its various actors, objectives, processes of mediation, and its historic development, as related to diverse forms of exhibits (visual arts, architecture, heritage objects, design, film) and exhibitions (museum exhibition, festival, biennial, expo);
Have practiced their skills in synthesizing information from various sources (lectures, texts, group discussions), critically reviewing such information as well as actual exhibitions, and presenting your results orally and in writing, assisted by means of diverse media.", "Course Content
This course deals with:
The history and theory of exhibiting art and culture, from the curiosity cabinet to museums and world's fairs, and through to contemporary exhibitions, festivals, and biennials;
The function and purpose of exhibitions, which have long been a means of mediating culture and politics, educating society, establishing cultural and national canons and narratives, promoting artists and artifacts, and a vehicle for curatorial statements;
How artists have reflected upon the nature of exhibitions - not always in a positive sense (e.g. so-called "institutional critique").", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
This course is offered in English and assignments should be submitted in English.", "Method of Assessment
Method of Assessment:
Group presentation (30%): learning objectives 3,4
Written exam (70%): learning objectives 1,2,3, 4
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,4,8", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
A list of the mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.", "Recommended background knowledge
Basic knowledge in Art History and/or Cultural History."]

course_name: Historiography of Media, Art, Design and Architecture
track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By the end of the course, we will:
Identify and define key historiographical theories concerning the disciplines of art, media, design, and architecture, in mutual coherence from the early modern period to the present day.
Describe and summarise different perspectives and research foci presented in relevant scientific publications.
Interpret and apply the discussed approaches to the analysis of artefacts belonging to the disciplines of art, media, design, and architecture.
Analyse objects through the historiographic approaches discussed in the course while distinguishing between their relevance and application.
Reflect on the contribution of the discussed historiographic approaches to the ways in which artefacts have been perceived over time", "Course Content
This course offers a comprehensive introduction to the historiography of media, art, design and architecture while tracing its development from the early modern period to the present day. In the lectures and working groups, we will examine a range of historiographic approaches that have shaped the ways in which these disciplines have been conceived and perceived while exploring their theoretical foundations and methodological practices. Focusing on the work of prominent historians, theorists, and authors, we will discuss how the historicization of media, art, design, and architecture was defined, as well as counter perspectives that critically analyse the existing discourse. We will engage in critical discussions, close readings, and analytical exercises to deepen our understanding of how the development of these disciplines has been studied and interpreted over time. By the end of the course, we will gain the tools to critically evaluate existing historiographic frameworks and grasp the development of ongoing", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures; active participation in discussions during tutorials; independent preparation of texts that deal with key authors and historiographic perspectives; group assignments and presentations in class.", "Method of Assessment
Final Assignment (60%): learning objectives 1,2,3,4,5
Interim Assignments (40%): learning objectives 1,2,3,4,5
End terms BA MKDA: 1,3,4,5,6,8", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
A list of mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas and/or the study manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year.
It is not open as an elective.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Have knowledge and insight into developments in the visual arts of the 19th and 20th centuries;
Have knowledge and insight into various theories concerning the course of art and art history in relation to notions of tradition, progress, originality, the end of art (history), etc;
Have acquired a critical approach to various discourses on the progress of art and art history, including that of museum presentation;
Be able to apply the gained insights to an assigned art historical question and to an actual work of art, preferably on location;
Be able to clearly communicate their findings in an oral presentation.", "Course Content
Much of the art of the 19th and 20th century, and especially that of the "avant-garde", was born under the sign of "progress", whether meaning new styles, new materials, new subject matter, or new media. Innovation, however, is always rooted in tradition, and ignoring the latter may lead to a misguided celebration of progress. This course focuses on the permanent tension between looking forward and backward in 19th- and 20th-century visual art, both from the perspective of modernist narratives of progress, and from that of postmodern critiques on this notion and its role in art history (e.g., ideas about the 'end' of (art) history).
By means of capita selecta from both art history and art theory (Gombrich, Greenberg, Bürger, Foster, Doorman), we will critically assess individual works of art, art criticism, various art theories, and Art History as a discipline through the lens of various socio-historical and scientific-philosophical views on progress and tradition, in order to develop a more critical attitude towards art, art history and various of its assumptions.
The course builds on the first-year course History of MKDA: Modern which, among other things, offered a survey of avant-garde movements in art, and on the preceding second-year course Early Modern Art:
Production and Reception. It invites a more problem- and theory-oriented view on modern art, but also aims to provide students with knowledge, insights and tools with which to assess individual art works' qualities in the sense of relating them to the past, present and future.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, and excursion(s). The lectures of this course are offered in English only. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can do oral presentations and submit written assignments in either English or Dutch.", "Method of Assessment
This course comprises two oral presentations, one (1) on an assigned problem in art history (25%), the other (2) on a painting (15%), and a written exam on the literature and lectures (60%). Of these, the written exam has to be passed with a sufficient grade (5.5 or higher) in order to pass the course.
Connection between learning objectives and assessment:
Learning objective 1: written exam, oral presentation 1.
Learning objective 2: written exam, oral presentation 2.
Learning objective 3: written exam, oral presentations 1 and 2.
Learning objectives 4 & 5: oral presentation 1 and 2.
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 12", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
A list of mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas and/or the Study Manual. Please note that the lectures are not a repetition of the literature, but an addition to it.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Art as their specialisation, and for pre-Masters Art & Culture. It is open as an elective to other MKDA students.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.", "Recommended background knowledge
The course builds on the first-year course History of MKDA: Modern. The literature then studied will be assumed familiar; students who did not follow this course are advised to study beforehand: E.H. Gombrich, The Story of Art, London (Phaidon) 1995, pp. 475-506, and Penelope Davies et al., Janson’s History of Art: The Western Tradition (Eight Edition), Upper Saddle River etc. (Prentice Hall) 2011, pp. 859-74, 903-22, 945-61, 964-72, 983-87, 993-99, 1003-7, 1035-40 and 1049-53."]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Communication and Information Studies; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Course goal:
The focus of this course will be on Intercultural Philosophy. You will learn how philosophy helps to reflect on humanity and reality, in culturally differentiated ways.
Learning objectives:
You will get insight into how philosophers/philosophy help(s) to understand one’s own culture and that of others
You will acquire tools to critically question the claims to universal reason of ‘Western’ thinking
You are able to critically reflect on how your own cultural background influences your understanding
You can reflect in a philosophical manner, both collectively (in seminars) and individually (through assignments)", "Course Content
Philosophy is a discipline that focuses more on questions than answers. Examples of philosophical questions are: What is reality? What can human beings know? How do our academic frameworks steer our understanding? How does knowledge inform our practical life, and our morality?
In this course, we will focus on the intercultural aspects of philosophy, which center on the question of understanding. Human thinking is formed and rooted in cultures. These are not fixed, bounded wholes, but we are able to learn another culture from the inside by living in it, and can go back and forth through different cultures. How do we, however, translate between cultures? And how can we understand someone who is formed to think in another language, with different moral rules?
Due to colonialism, often in philosophy, Eurocentric philosophical traditions are centered while other forms of philosophy are neglected. From the end of the 20th century, German and Austrian philosophers have formed a school of Intercultural Philosophy as a way to address this. You will get acquainted with their approach, and with further developments of their thought by other philosophers. Using the intercultural philosophy approach, you will zoom in on the question of ‘Self-hood’ by reflecting on philosophies from African and Asian cultures.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Each week there are two lectures, and one seminar, for a total of 5.25 contact hours per week. In the lectures, students will be introduced to the readings and get an overview of the context they are situated in. In the seminars, they will help each other, under the guidance of an experienced teaching assistant, to read the text material, critically evaluate its contents, and apply them to real world questions.
Attendance of seminars is obligatory. If a student misses a seminar session, s/he has to do an extra assignment. Attendance of lectures is not mandatory but exam will comprise of lecture and seminar material. Complete procedure is described in the course manual.", "Method of Assessment
Personal Study Assignments (PSAs) to prepare for the seminars (pass/fail, assessment of learning objectives 3 and 4)
Take home exam (100% of final grade, assessment of learning objectives 1 and 2).
Final grade has to be at least 5,5.", "Literature
Literature will be announced and/or made available on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Students of CIS, L&S, MADA (2nd year).", "Additional Information
Obligatory 2nd year course."]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Have an overview of key themes in the history and theory of ecological art and design;
Demonstrate understanding of various art and design strategies, as well as their cross-overs, for intervening in or reflecting upon the various ecosystems of our planet.
Be able to conduct research in the field of ecological art and/or design, based on close readings of case-studies and literature, using the appropriate methods and terms;
Be able to communicate their research in written and audiovisual formats.", "Course Content
In this course, we will explore how design and art practices and theories have been engaging with ecological concerns since the 1960s.
The art and design fields have developed various strategies to engage with the ecological challenges of our time. However, these strategies are not completely distinct; indeed, we identify increasing crossovers between these fields, which demonstrates the fruitfulness of considering them in relation. Many of these key strategies are motivated by similar concepts, such as impact and transition, awareness and representation, speculation and fiction, collaboration and community engagement.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, and excursions. The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English only. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are: the midterm exam, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks).", "Method of Assessment
The course comprises one midterm exam (50%, individual grade), and one final audiovisual/written paper (50%, group grade).
Midterm exam (50%): learning objectives 1,2
Final paper (50%): learning objectives 2,3,4
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,4,5,6,8,9", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
A list of mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas and/or the Study Manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Art or Design as their specialisation. It is open as an elective to other MKDA students.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (3); Ancient Studies; History; Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By the end of the course, students will:
Acquire knowledge and understanding of the theoretical foundations of heritage studies and discuss the main (inter)national political and public debates surrounding heritage practices.
Become familiar with the concept of Critical Heritage and apply it to different analytical approaches.
Become familiar with different types of conflicts that can emerge in the practice of World Heritage management: conflicts of appropriation, political conflicts, paradoxes in protecting heritage and managing change, climate and environmental changes.
Analyse (World) Heritage sites and heritage objects, and gain insight into processes of appropriation, canonization, musealization, and possible sources of conflict concerning a World Heritage status.
Be able to compare and reflect critically upon individual case studies.", "Course Content
In this course, students are made familiar with the international political framework that shapes our contemporary interaction with and debates on cultural heritage, with a specific focus on UNESCO World Heritage designations. The meaning of the concept of (World) heritage has radically changed throughout the last decades; whilst initially World Heritage designations were limited to objects and buildings, increasingly sites and (cultural) landscapes are considered as well. There is also increasing attention to immaterial forms of cultural heritage, such as artistic practices, craftsmanship and traditions. Thanks to the contribution of critical heritage studies, it is now acknowledged that, whether objects or landscape, tangible or intangible, heritage values are not intrinsic but constructed by stakeholders and communities. It is also clear that World Heritage is never undisputed and often gives rise to conflicts, ranging from armed crises to disputes relating to the management of heritage, as connected to national identities, historical traumas, tourism and economic developments, or climate and environmental changes.
In this module, we will specifically focus on the relationship between (World) Heritage and such conflicts. By discussing critically recent academic, political, and public debates on individual World Heritage sites, students will reflect upon what is called the ‘heritage paradox’ – the constant tension between the management of future changes and to urge to protect relics of the past. During this course, conflicts will be addressed by discussing case studies, visiting heritage sites, reflecting on the way in which UNESCO seeks to encourage the identification, protection and preservation of cultural and natural heritage of “outstanding value to humanity”, and debating how heritage is co-created in national and local scales.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, excursions.", "Method of Assessment
Group assignment during seminar 1 (15%): learning objectives 2, 3, and 5
Group assignment during seminar 2 (15%): learning objectives 1, 4, and 5
Group assignment during self-guided excursion (15%): learning objectives 3 and 4
Individual essay assignment (in class) (55%) :learning objectives 1, 2, and 4
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,4,5,6,8,12", "Literature
course literature to be announced in Canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA2 students Geschiedenis variant History & Heritage;
BA 2 students History and International Studies; BA2 and BA3 MKDA students;
International humanities students, level 200-300.", "Recommended background knowledge
For international exchange students a basic knowledge of (art or architectural) history or heritage studies. is required (on level 200-300)."]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
have acquired the skills to engage with and analyse various original objects, works of art, architecture, design and media, all in situ and in the contexts of the city or museum collections, in a non-dutch environment of international importance for (the history of) visual and material culture;
be able to lead a discussion on a historical/theoretical idea in relation to an art work in situ;
be able to communicate to peers, orally and on an academic level about the visual analysis of monuments and artefacts and to have gained and shared knowledge and insight about the goals of the excursion, including learning experiences;", "Course Content
In many respects, today's European culture is heir to that of the Italian Renaissance, especially in the fields of architecture and the visual arts. Florence is the Renaissance city par excellence: much of what was achieved in Florence in a relatively short time (14th-16th centuries) and with an exceptionally high quality can still be admired
in situ. This unique situation is also due to the different ways in which later generations have dealt with the material witnesses to the history of this city. In this course, students learn about the most important moments and objects from that history through individual research, and reflect on the scientific culture in which those objects were studied and described.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Preparatory lectures and full-time excursion demanding self-study and active participation.", "Method of Assessment
On-site presentation and discussion (70 + 30 %, incl. preparation, literature study)
Oral Presentation (70%): learning objectives 1, 3
Discussion (30%): learning objectives 1, 2, 3
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 12", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA", "Literature
A list of mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas and/or the Study Manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Art or Architecture as their specialization. It is not open as an elective.", "Additional Information
In period 4 students are invited for a kick-off meeting regarding the practical side of the course. In period 5 students follow several lectures and read the compulsory literature. Based on this literature and the literature they collected by the student, they prepare a presentation to be held in Florence. The excursion takes place in period 6. Presence at all meetings and during the entire excursion is mandatory.
Regarding finances: participants to this excursion are strongly advised to reserve their own financial contribution in time. Savings are recommended. The VU will not cover all the costs, but will offer a small compensation (on condition of the course being completed successfully). Costs to be incurred include travel expenses (both international and local), some accommodation costs, museum entrance fees, meals, etc. The accompanying teachers will do their best to arrange free or reduced entrance fees. The course coordinator will inform the participants in good time whether transport and accommodation will be jointly arranged or not."]

course_name: The Postmedium Condition: Contemporary Art and Media
track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
have knowledge of and insight into major developments in contemporary art and media;
have knowledge of and insight into research methods and the theoretical framework to analyze lens-based, time-based, interactive, and digital art and media;
be able to conduct case studies of lens-based, time-based, interactive, and digital art and media using the appropriate methods and terms, and situate them in (the history of) Western visual and material culture;
be able to write a research paper on an individual topic, based on identifying and synthesizing relevant academic literature.", "Course Content
This course focuses on the development of art and media from the 1960s on. Bringing together insights from both art and media history and theory, we will consider how these operate within, and contribute to, our understanding of the recent past and present. A theoretical focus will be the concept of the post-medium/post-media condition, used in a broad sense to describe a shift in the latter half of the 20th century away from the significance of the specificity of any (mass-)medium, and towards the intentional deployment of media, contingent on the situation at hand. The course will be structured thematically.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, and excursions. The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English only. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks)", "Method of Assessment
This course comprises active participation (formative assessment), presentations (formative assessment), and a final paper (100% of grade). Attendance and course preparation are required.
Connection between learning objectives and assessment:
Active participation: learning objectives 1,2
Written paper (100%): learning objectives 1,2,3,4
Oral presentation: 1,2,3
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,4,5,8", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
A list of mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas and/or the Study Manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Art or Media as their specialization. It is open as an elective for 2nd or 3rd year MKDA students.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Be familiar with the theoretical notions of urban culture and public space, and with the design aspects and the implicit methods of inclusion and exclusion that are connected to these notions;
Know how to actively analyze urban space, the objectives of its designers, and the ways in which citizens put public space to use;
Be able to connect historical, sociological and anthropological concepts with primary sources (e.g., know how to analyze public space through observation);
Have improved their academic skills through individual study, group work, and a final report.", "Course Content
Public space is omnipresent in our daily existence as represented in the streets, squares and public buildings of our cities. Public space is where we meet friends and strangers, encounter new ideas and objects, commemorate and celebrate, discuss our worries or simply enjoy the moment.
This course focuses on the multifaceted relationship between public space and urban culture by taking into account the (historical and contemporary) intentions and experiences of designers, planners, developers, and users. We will ask what the terms 'urban culture' and 'public space' mean in different times and cultures, and we will look into the relationship between the intentions and ideals of the ‘makers’ of public space (architects, urban designers, planners, and commissioners) and the perception and ideals of its users, the public.
The course offers a kaleidoscopic journey into the past and present of our everyday living environment, probing into the question what public space can be, how it comes into being and how it is transformed. We will study prevailing writings on urban culture and public space and investigate case studies, both in lectures and on site.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Teaching methods include lectures, seminars, and excursions.
The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English only and assignments should be submitted in English. Students following the Dutch (bilingual) track and having particular reasons for wanting to submit assignments in Dutch also in this course, should discuss this with the course coordinator in the first week of classes.", "Method of Assessment
Midterm exam (40%): learning objectives 1
Group project (20%): learning objectives 2,3,4
Final report (40%): learning objectives 1,2, 3, 4
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,5,8,9", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
The literature will later be announced in the syllabus and on Canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year. It is open to students with backgrounds in History or Planning. For exchange students, the approval of the coordinator of this course is requested", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]

course_name: Bachelor Thesis Media, Art, Design and Architecture
track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The thesis trajectory consists of two parts:
The thesis colloquium includes group exercises in doing research for and writing theses;
The actual thesis which is supervised by one of the teachers of MKDA.
Ba thesis colloquium:
The student demonstrates that she/he is independently able to develop a work plan that serves as a starting point for the thesis and that meets the guidelines of the program. This work plan addresses research into primary and secondary sources and methodologies relevant to the formulated thesis research, and includes a structured bibliography as the first phase for this thesis research.
The student is able to evaluate work of fellow students orally and in writing ('peer feedback').
Thesis:
The student demonstrates the ability to independently and according to AcVa guidelines compose an academic text based on research methods commonly used in Media, Art, Design and Architecture, and can complete it within a defined period of time;
The student demonstrates an understanding of theories and (subject-related) methodologies in the chosen specialization, and to be able to apply them to one or more cases;
The student demonstrates that she/he is able to independently search relevant and reliable sources and academic literature in relation to the topic;
The student demonstrates that she/he can academically legitimate the text and compile a structured bibliography;
The student demonstrates having obtained academic skills for Bachelor year 3 in terms of the structure of the thesis and use of language, with correct incorporation of literature/bibliography.", "Course Content
The BA thesis is a proof of the achieved skill level for year 3 (300) regarding content and theory in one of the specialisations Media, Art, Design, and Architecture or in an interdisciplinary combination or MKDA general. As completion of the bachelor program Media, Art, Design and Architecture, in the second semester of the third year (period 3,4,5) the student independently writes a thesis of 12 credits (thesis & colloquium).
The thesis should attest to the knowledge accumulated in the program of MKDA, with emphasis on the chosen specialisation (media, art, design or architecture) or an interdisciplinary combination of two directions.
For the BA thesis, these are the ways to determine at a thesis topic:
Selection list: In a plenary information session in fall of the academic year of graduation, the program informs students about themes and possible topics from which to choose within the student's specialisation.
Course from the graduate program: the student takes a research seminar in the bachelor program and can use this course to formulate a thesis topic. The problem / research question is in line with the theme of the course, but clearly differs from that of the assignment completed as part of completing that course.
Own topic: exceptionally and only with the prior approval of the intended thesis supervisor, students may choose their own topic.
The Media, Art, Design and Architecture bachelor thesis is a written paper of 7,000-10,000 words (excluding notes and literature, and appendices) that is largely completed independently under the guidance of a thesis supervisor. The thesis is a text composed on the basis of literature review and/or source research and possibly some archival research. The bachelor thesis may be used for further study of already collected material, or to explore certain themes in more detail. In doing so, the student may also combine more or less concurrent modules from the Media, Art, Design and Architecture study or possibly minors.
The ba thesis colloquium involves reflection on the formal aspects of writing the bachelor thesis during seminar meetings and during which students comment on each other's work ('peer review'). In each meeting one phase of the research and writing process is discussed based on examples.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Individual study and supervision by a docent of the respective specialisation (thesis);
Lectures and seminars (thesis colloquium)", "Method of Assessment
Thesis (100%) / participation, assignments and peer review (thesis colloquium)
Alignment of learning objectives and assessment:
The course format is self-study. The intended learning objectives of the module will be assessed against the written thesis and according to criteria of the thesis assessment form available on VU-net and/or Canvas. This assessment form can also be found in the study manual of the thesis and the criteria for assessment of this form will be discussed in the thesis colloquium. Correlation assessment and learning objective: Thesis (100%): 1 ,2 ,3 ,4 ,5
End terms BA MADA: 1, 2, 3 ,4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 10, 11", "Entry Requirements
In order to begin the thesis process, third-year students must have completed all courses of the first year and the second year (cf. Teaching and Examination Regulations (TER)).", "Literature
Literature for the thesis colloquium will be announced in due course via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
3rd year bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture students who meet the entry requirements.", "Additional Information
Being enrolled in this course does not guarantee that you will actually be allowed to start the final thesis trajectory, as a final (or conditional) decision on this will only be made in January based on the courses passed until then. Students are informed by the end of January whether they will be allowed to proceed.
The thesis track can only be completed if the thesis colloquium has been followed and the thesis has been graded with a minimum of 6.0.", "Custom Course Registration
For this course, you must sign in yourself. The registration and deregistration deadlines are listed on VU.nl. Late registration is not possible for this course!"]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Acquiring knowledge and insight into discussions and problematic issues with regard to image and visual culture, in particular in terms of iconoclasm and idolatry.
Analytic skills: through text analysis of the course literature and preparation for seminar discussions.
Active processing of the course content in the form of participation in group discussion during the seminars.
Writing skills: demonstrated by coherent answers to the exam questions that reflect knowledge acquired from the lectures, seminars and readings.", "Course Content
After the historical and theoretical study of visual and material culture in years 1 and 2, year 3 of the bachelor of MKDA (Media, Art, Design and Architecture) problematises the concept of visual culture by paying attention to the critique of the image and to iconoclasm.
Attention will be paid to religious and political iconoclasm (e.g. the Iconoclastic Fury of the Reformation); theoretical critique of 'ocular-centrism' and its effects on film theory; the problematisation of the image in modern art; iconisation and iconoclasm in design; and the (imagination of) the city as contested area.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars.", "Method of Assessment
Weekly uploads of questions for the discussions in the seminar, to be submitted on Canvas (course objectives 1,2,3)
Written exam: the assessment of this course takes place through a written exam (closed book) of 1.5 hours duration (course objective 4)
The exam counts for 100% of the final grade, but discussion questions must beforehand have been passed as 'sufficient', in order to be allowed to start with the exam.
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9", "Entry Requirements
See Teaching and Exam Regulations (OER) MKDA.", "Literature
Dario Gamboni, The Destruction of Art: Iconoclasm and Vandalism since the French Revolution. London (Reaktion Books) 1997, pp. 13-30.
Additional articles on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Compulsory for all 3rd year MKDA students (all specializations).
Exchange students: only 3rd-year bachelor students with a background in Cultural Studies, Media Studies, or Art or Design History, within Faculties of Arts or Humanities, and with a good command of the English language.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.
Missing the first lecture (which also serves as an introduction to the course) may result in expulsion from the course.
Written assignments can be submitted in English or Dutch, but students planning an English taught MA are strongly recommended to write in English."]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The Research Seminar Art is a seminar with the following learning objectives:
Learning how to formulate an attractive concept for an exhibition based on a scientifically sound and workable art historical research question.
Learning how to elaborate such such/this concept in the form of an exhibition catalogue with an introduction and (five) entries.
Learning how to conduct critical research on both art objects and their cultural-historical context, depending on the chosen research question.
Learning how to work together in collective brainstorming sessions.
Gaining insight into the handling of digital registration systems for museum objects and the conventions for notation.
Learning how to write on an academically sound as well as reader-friendly level.
With the above learning objectives, the course builds on the second-year courses Production and Reception and Progress & Tradition, and on the course Historiography of Media, Art, Design and Architecture, which covered theory of historiography. Skills gained in Academic Skills and Research Techniques are put to practice and extended with an introduction to systems for registration of museum objects. The focus is on formulating workable research questions, conducting research, and writing down the results in the format of an exhibition catalogue.", "Course Content
As museum curators, exhibition planners and/or researchers, art historians are expected to be able to conduct solid research, both on individual art objects and wider art historical questions, as well as to present and develop creative ideas for an intelligent, exciting and art-historically sound presentation of an ensemble of artworks. This course prepares you for all of this by intensively guiding you in formulating and elaborating a concept for a (virtual) exhibition, for which you will write the catalogue. The course includes exercises in various skills (including dBase) to prepare you for the working field, excursions to relevant institutes and guest lectures by researchers experienced in this type of research. For your catalogue, you formulate your own questions, which you elaborate in an introduction and in entries on 5 self-chosen and researched works of art.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar demanding active participation (peer feedback), group tutorials, various interim assignments, guest lecture(s), excursion(s)", "Method of Assessment
Active participation (15%) [learning objectives 1, 4, 5] This component explicitly includes peer feedback on fellow students’ proposals and progress.
Oral presentation (15%) [learning objectives 1, 2, 3] Students will be asked to report several times about their progress, but only the final presentation will be graded.
Final paper (catalogue) (70%) [learning objectives 1, 2, 3, 5, 6] To pass the course, this component will have to be graded with a 6.0 or higher. When lower, there’s one re-sit.
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 12", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their third year who chose Art as their specialisation, and for pre-Masters Art & Culture. It is highly recommended to students aiming for the MA Curating Art and Cultures en de MA specialisation Kunst, Markt en Connaisseurschap. Students without the requisite knowledge of art and art history cannot be admitted.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]

course_name: Current Debates in Art and Culture
track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Art
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students will gain practice in developing informed opinions on specific issues that they deem relevant, and in defending and substantiating a position, both orally and in writing.
At the end of this course students should be able to:
analyze debates on visual art and material culture in such a way that they are able to contextualize current developments, position them within a discourse that relates to art and culture, and reflect critically upon various positions in relation to them;
apply knowledge of the forces that shape visual and material culture to contemporary cases, take a position, underpin it with relevant arguments, and pose innovative questions for research;
present a position both orally and in writing, offering substantiated arguments and pointing to (scholarly) sources;
contribute to group discussions and provide feedback to fellow students in an informed and constructive way;
revise written arguments based on feedback given by peers and the instructor.", "Course Content
This course considers debates in the field of visual and material culture, centered around a selection of public events (lectures, debates, exhibitions). Through the engagement with selected ‘current’ debates, the students are stimulated to reflect on their own positions and career paths, and apply their knowledge and further develop their expertise to act in the professional field of visual and material culture. The specific course content depends on contemporary discourse, events taking place in the field, and the academic assessment of the instructor.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars, excursions (visits to events)", "Method of Assessment
50% Written assignments (learning objectives 1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
50% Final paper (learning objectives 1, 2)
This course contributes to the BA MKDA final attainment levels 4, 8 and 11", "Literature
Given the focus on current debates, literature is subject to change each year.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Year 3 MKDA students.", "Additional Information
All lectures, class discussions, and about half of the required course readings will be in English. The selection of public events and debates (and additional information) during the course, will be accessible in English, Dutch, or a combination of both. Students who master Dutch, are encouraged to write their assignments in Dutch.
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Media
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Be familiar with the concept of 'exhibition', historically, theoretically, and practically;
Be acquainted with international landmark exhibitions as well as exemplary Dutch institutions;
Demonstrate an understanding of the networked character of the art system and cultural sector, its various actors, objectives, processes of mediation, and its historic development, as related to diverse forms of exhibits (visual arts, architecture, heritage objects, design, film) and exhibitions (museum exhibition, festival, biennial, expo);
Have practiced their skills in synthesizing information from various sources (lectures, texts, group discussions), critically reviewing such information as well as actual exhibitions, and presenting your results orally and in writing, assisted by means of diverse media.", "Course Content
This course deals with:
The history and theory of exhibiting art and culture, from the curiosity cabinet to museums and world's fairs, and through to contemporary exhibitions, festivals, and biennials;
The function and purpose of exhibitions, which have long been a means of mediating culture and politics, educating society, establishing cultural and national canons and narratives, promoting artists and artifacts, and a vehicle for curatorial statements;
How artists have reflected upon the nature of exhibitions - not always in a positive sense (e.g. so-called "institutional critique").", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
This course is offered in English and assignments should be submitted in English.", "Method of Assessment
Method of Assessment:

track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Media
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Have acquired basic knowledge of the historical chronology and major developments of visual mass media from the second half of the 19th century to the present day, particularly in Western Europe and the United States, with regard to their contexts of production, distribution, exhibition, and sociocultural aspects.
Have acquired knowledge of the intersections between individual media forms and various constellations of the media landscape.
Be able to historicize the specificity of contemporary social media.
Be able to distinguish between conventional and alternative media historiographies.
Be able to critically reflect on media historiography.
Be able to develop a basic research proposal.", "Course Content
This course addresses three central questions: First, how have particular forms of visual mass media developed over time? Second, how can we situate these media within their (Euro-American) sociocultural contexts of production, distribution, and reception? Third, how can the historical development of these media be related to the recent emergence of social media? We will examine these historical perspectives alongside various theoretical insights into medium specificity and media use. In doing so, the course will lay the groundwork for subsequent studies in media theory, media analysis, and post-media developments. The lectures will be supplemented by related viewings.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, and viewings. The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English only. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks)", "Method of Assessment
This course comprises written assignments (40%) and 1 written exam (60%). All components have to be passed with a sufficient grade.

course_name: Historiography of Media, Art, Design and Architecture
track_from_label: Bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, Specialization Media
course_programmes: Hide full list (1)
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By the end of the course, we will:
Identify and define key historiographical theories concerning the disciplines of art, media, design, and architecture, in mutual coherence from the early modern period to the present day.
Describe and summarise different perspectives and research foci presented in relevant scientific publications.
Interpret and apply the discussed approaches to the analysis of artefacts belonging to the disciplines of art, media, design, and architecture.
Analyse objects through the historiographic approaches discussed in the course while distinguishing between their relevance and application.
Reflect on the contribution of the discussed historiographic approaches to the ways in which artefacts have been perceived over time", "Course Content
This course offers a comprehensive introduction to the historiography of media, art, design and architecture while tracing its development from the early modern period to the present day. In the lectures and working groups, we will examine a range of historiographic approaches that have shaped the ways in which these disciplines have been conceived and perceived while exploring their theoretical foundations and methodological practices. Focusing on the work of prominent historians, theorists, and authors, we will discuss how the historicization of media, art, design, and architecture was defined, as well as counter perspectives that critically analyse the existing discourse. We will engage in critical discussions, close readings, and analytical exercises to deepen our understanding of how the development of these disciplines has been studied and interpreted over time. By the end of the course, we will gain the tools to critically evaluate existing historiographic frameworks and grasp the development of ongoing", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures; active participation in discussions during tutorials; independent preparation of texts that deal with key authors and historiographic perspectives; group assignments and presentations in class.", "Method of Assessment
