course_programmes: Hide full list (8); Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Je kunt een aantal belangrijke stromingen en denkers uit de traditie van de sociale en culturele wijsbegeerte beschrijven en uitleggen.
Je bent in staat om filosofische teksten te lezen op het gebied van de sociale en culturele wijsbegeerte en de daarin ontwikkelde gedachtegang weer te geven en de relatie te leggen met andere disciplines van filosofie en wetenschap.
Je kunt zelfstandig een overzichtswerk bestuderen en op hoofdlijnen samenvatten en overziet de paradoxen van de (post-)moderne samenleving.
Je ben in staat om verscheidene maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen op een filosofische wijze termen te beschrijven en te analyseren.
Je kunt de thematiek van vervreemding relateren aan de Verlichting en de ontwikkelingen die in deze periode in gang zijn gezet.
Je kunt in grote lijnen de geschiedenis van Athene beschrijven in relatie tot het denken de deugdethiek van Plato en Aristoteles.
Je bent in staat om mens- en maatschappij van de oudheid te vergelijken met dat van de moderniteit en uit te leggen wat de 'mechanisering van het wereldbeeld' inhoudt.
Je bent in staat om de samenhang te schetsen tussen Verlichtingsdenken en de moderne Europese cultuur en daarbij de rol van het christendom uit te leggen.
Je bent in staat om aan de hand van uitleg de gedachtegang van Duitse filosofische teksten te volgen en daarna zelfstandig weer te geven.", "Course Content
Beginnend bij de Griekse filosofie wordt duidelijk gemaakt waar de huidige indeling van de filosofie in disciplines vandaan komt, wat de relatie is tussen logica (als methodebegrip), ethica en fysica en welke centrale plaats de metafysica in dat geheel inneemt.
Daarbij wordt tevens aandacht besteed aan de continuïteit, maar ook discontinuïteit in de ontwikkeling van de filosofie van de oudheid en die van de nieuwe tijd - wat ten nauwste samenhangt met het fundamentele verschil in religie en cultuur. Deze uiteenzetting vormt de basis voor een methodisch begrip van de sociale en culturele wijsbegeerte binnen het geheel van de wijsbegeerte. Op die manier krijg je inzicht in de relatie tussen het cultureel bepaalde begrip van de mens en dat van de kosmos, dat omgekeerd weer zijn weerslag heeft op het filosofische begrip van de sociaal- culturele werkelijkheid.
Er wordt stilgestaan bij de mechanisering van het wereldbeeld in de zeventiende eeuw in relatie tot culturele ontwikkelingen in Noordwest-Europa. Van daaruit worden de grondmotieven van de Verlichting verhelderd. Je maakt kennis met invloedrijke sociologen en filosofen als Rousseau, Marx, Durkheim, Weber en Foucault en leert een aantal centrale begrippen kennen zoals individualisering, rationalisering, disciplinering en vervreemding. De problemen die in het denken van de Verlichting schuilgaan worden toegelicht en uitgewerkt aan de hand van teksten uit de syllabus.
Het college wordt afgesloten met Heideggers 'Frage nach der Technik' dat in zijn geheel wordt gelezen en besproken.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Het college bestaat uit drie onderdelen:
Hoor/werkcollege dat mede gebaseerd is op te lezen literatuur voor dit vak.
Je dient zelfstandig het overzichtswerk Paradoxen van Modernisering (Van der Loo en Van Reijen, Coutinho) te bestuderen. Het boek wordt niet behandeld op college, maar studenten hebben wel de mogelijkheid daarover vragen te stellen.
Daarnaast wordt gebruik gemaakt van een syllabus met teksten van Hobbes, Hegel, Marx en Verbrugge. De studenten mogen vertalingen gebruiken bij de teksten, maar op college wordt uitgegaan van de teksten in hun oorspronkelijke taal.", "Method of Assessment
Take home tentamen 35% - (leerdoelen 1, 3, 4, 5, en 8), Schriftelijk tentamen 65% - (leerdoelen 1, 2, 4 en 5-9).", "Literature
Paradoxen van Modernisering, Hans van der Loo en Willem van Reijen, (Coutinho).
Frage nach der Technik uit Technik und die Kehre, Heidegger (Neske).
Syllabus; Verlichting en Vervreemding.", "Additional Information Target Audience
2e jaars BA Filosofie; studenten minor Praktische Filosofie", "Additional Information
Voor dit college geldt een aanwezigheidsplicht van 80%."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of the course is to teach students how to read a philosophical text and how to formulate their own questions after reading it.
After completing this course, you will be able to critically analyze ancient philosophical texts, by
critically reading philosophical texts (in translation),
analysing philosophical arguments,
formulating your own questions,
discussing with peers,
presenting your own response to the text and its arguments in writing.", "Course Content
This course will focus on Plato's Gorgias. This fascinating dialogue contains a broad range of philosophical topics, from the tension between philosophy and sophistry to the nature of political power and justice. We will read the whole text, focus on some of its seminal passages, and critically engage with their arguments. Active participation by the students is required.
Students who complete the course will acquire not only knowledge of the key philosophical themes discussed in the Gorgias, but also a general understanding of 4th century Greek philosophy and its debates.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Introductory lectures; close reading seminars. Attendance is mandatory.", "Method of Assessment
The assessment for this course consists of small individual writing assignments and oral presentations for each class (assessing learning objectives 1–4) and a final paper at the end of the course (determining the final grade, assessing learning objectives 1–3, 5). Passed assignments and presentations together constitute 50% of the grade, the final paper constitutes the other 50%. To pass the course, both have to be marked with 5.5 or higher. Insufficient assignments will be complemented by extra assignments. In case of an insufficient final paper a resit will be required.", "Literature
We will at least all use Plato Gorgias, translated, with Introduction and Notes, by Donald J. Zeyl (Hackett 1987). Additional other translations (in English or in other languages) may be used, provided they use the Stephanus pagination. Required secondary literature will be specified in the course description on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is primarily for philosophy students, but other interested students with a general knowledge of ancient philosophy are welcome to enrol.", "Recommended background knowledge
General knowledge of the history of ancient philosophy (especially Greek) is highly recommended for this course. Those who have not attended a course on the history of Ancient Philosophy and/or are not familiar with its topics are required to acquaint themselves with some key texts in ancient philosophy, in addition to the primary and secondary literature for this course. Please contact the teacher for more information."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students can:
remember and explain main issues and theories in advanced ethics
analyse and evaluate key assumptions and arguments of these theories
develop an original position with regard to recent literature in ethics
produce a research output defending their position", "Course Content
Practical reason
Should I get up early to make the most of the day, or should I stay in bed a bit longer?
Should I eat the cake or the apple?
Should I learn a different language or watch TV?
Practical reason, or reasoning, is supposed to help us settle these questions. But how exactly does such practical deliberation look like? Should we do what's moral, what's rational, or what's in line with our goals? Which standards does practical deliberation have to conform to?
Inspired by these questions, we will look at aspects of practical reason, such as
the difference between practical and theoretical reason (if there is one)
the role that motivation plays in practical reasoning
different conceptions of rationality
normative standards involved in practical reasoning
To investigate these topics, we will mostly look at current research articles, but also look at what our traditional ethical theories, such as Consequentialism and Kantianism, have to say.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
seminars", "Method of Assessment
Students are required to contribute to the course with weekly assignments (e.g. discussion questions, or short summaries) (pass/fail) (1 & 2)
Presentation: students are required to give a research presentation (30%) (1 & 2)
Students are required to submit a research proposal (pass/fail) (3 & 4)
Students submit a final research output (70%) (3 & 4)", "Literature
To be announced on Canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is primarily intended for second and third year Philosophy bachelor students. Other interested students: contact the lecturer before enrolling.", "Recommended background knowledge
Introduction to Ethics (Philosophy Year 1)"]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course, you are able to:
identify and explain philosophical positions and concepts concerning the mind-body problem, distinguishing between dualism, identity theory, functionalism, computationalism, eliminativism, and 4E approaches;
apply philosophical positions and concepts to case studies involving consciousness, intentionality, and free will;
dissect philosophical arguments to examine their logical structure and underlying assumptions;
reflect on the implications of philosophical positions within scientific and social contexts;
develop and present your own view on a philosophical topic in written form", "Course Content
The relationship between the mind and the body has puzzled philosophers for centuries, giving rise to the notorious ‘mind-body problem’. In this introductory course, students will gain insight into the diverse range of philosophical positions proposed to grapple with this enigma, including substance and property dualism, identity theory, functionalism, computationalism, and eliminativism. We will examine the strengths, weaknesses, and implications of each perspective, shedding light on the complexity inherent in understanding the nature of the mind and its relation to the physical world. In addition to traditional approaches, this course will also delve into 4E approaches, focusing on the embodied, embedded, and extended nature of cognition. Finally, students will apply these theories to specific case studies, reflecting on the distinctive challenges they present. What is consciousness and how could we explain it in scientific terms? Where does the intentional content of our beliefs and desires come from? Do we possess a free will, or are our actions always predetermined?", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Interactive lectures", "Method of Assessment
Text-based assignments (pass/fail) (formative assessment)
Exam with open questions (50%) (Objectives 1-3)
Written Assignment (50%) (Objectives 3-5)", "Literature
Mendik, P. (2014) This Is Philosophy of Mind: An Introduction. Wiley-Blackwell.
(full e-book is accessible via the VU library)
Further literature is made accessible to all students via Canvas. Students are expected to read the mandatory literature before the lectures.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Philosophy Bachelor (2nd year)", "Additional Information
See the course guide on Canvas for more course information"]

course_name: Political and Social Philosophy: Recent Developments
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Leerdoelen:
Je kunt duidelijk maken in welke zin de ontvouwing van de moderne techniek en controlemaatschappij verband houdt met de opkomst van de moderne wetenschap en het mensbegrip van de Verlichting.
Je bent in staat om het gedachtegoed van de in dit college behandelde denkers (Heidegger, Spengler, Arendt e.a.) te beschrijven, uit te leggen en toe te passen op onze hedendaagse situatie.
Je kunt de verschillende posities van deze denkers met elkaar vergelijken en kritisch evalueren.
Je bent in staat om de verschillende elementen van het op college behandelde gedachtegoed te combineren en/of te bekritiseren.
Je bent in staat om in correct Nederlands je eigen positie te verwoorden met betrekking tot bepaalde aspecten van de problematiek.", "Course Content
Mede naar aanleiding van de coronacrisis en de daarin getroffen maatregelen willen we in dit college stilstaan bij de vraag hoe in onze (post-)moderne samenleving de elementaire waarde van individuele vrijheid en zelfbepaling zich verhoudt tot de opkomst van de zogenoemde ‘controle-maatschappij’ waarin technische sturing, berekenbaarheid en beheersing van processen een steeds groter stempel drukken op onze leefwereld. Kan het zijn dat we te maken hebben met de opkomst van een nieuwe vorm van ‘totalitarisme’? Aan de hand van teksten van o.a. Heidegger, Ernst en Friedrich Jünger, Spengler, Arendt, Marcuse, Foucault, Agamben, Stiegler, Hillman en Verbrugge wordt deze problematiek nader uitgewerkt en toegepast op hedendaagse ontwikkelingen. Daarbij gaat tevens een bijzondere aandacht uit naar de ‘geestelijke dimensie’ van dit gebeuren.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Interactieve hoorcolleges", "Method of Assessment
Dit college zal worden afgesloten met een schriftelijk tentamen en een paper van 3000 woorden. Schriftelijk tentamen, [leerdoelen 1,2,3,4] paper [leerdoelen 3,4,5]
Voorts dient iedere student een protocol [leerdoel 5] te maken van een (deel van) een college waarvan de beoordeling tevens zal meewegen in het eindcijfer (40/40/20).", "Literature
Voorafgaand aan het college zal de op dit college behandelde literatuur bekend worden gemaakt en deels ook ter beschikking worden gesteld op canvas. In ieder geval zullen teksten worden gebruikt van o.a. Heidegger, Jünger, Spengler, Arendt, Marcuse, Foucault, Agamben, Hillman en Verbrugge.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Tweede en derdejaarsstudenten Bachelor Filosofie"]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The student:
becomes familiarized with various pragmatist authors, from the 19th and 20th centuries as well as contemporary
learns to analyze philosophical arguments and positions
learns to give presentations on philosophical topics
learns to present philosophical arguments in written form by means of an essay
practices skills of philosophical debate in groups, presenting their own positions and engaging with the positions of others", "Course Content
The topic of this course is the philosophical tradition of pragmatism. Pragmatism is a style of philosophical thinking that favors the concrete over the abstract, the practical consequences of ideas rather than their correspondence to reality. Pragmatists adopt a functionalist approach to philosophical concepts and issues, inquiring into the roles (functions) that these concepts play in human lives and practices.
Starting in the 19th century and going all the way to contemporary discussions, we will discuss and read texts by authors such as Anna Julia Cooper, W.E.B. Du Bois, Charles Peirce, William James, John Dewey, Jane Addams, Frank Ramsey, Ludwig Wittgenstein, Richard Rorty, Cornel West, and Cheryl Misak.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Classes will consist in short expository lectures, student presentations, work in groups, and discussions with the whole class.", "Method of Assessment
Student presentation (15%): learning goals 1, 2 and 3
Participation in class discussions (15%): learning goals 1, 2 and 5
Final essay (70%): learning goals 1, 2 and 4", "Literature
All texts will be available online and/or uploaded to the ‘files’ section of Canvas. There are no books to purchase for this course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
The course is primarily for students in the BA philosophy program. Students from other programs can follow the course as long as they have sufficient prior familiarity with philosophical discussions. They must be prepared to perform close reading of philosophical texts and to engage actively in philosophical discussions."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of this course is for students to acquire in depth knowledge and understanding of key notions, practices, and theories of the ancient Stoics, by means of reading and commenting on different texts from that tradition.
After completing this course, students will also have developed their skills of
critical reading of complex philosophical argumentations
historically and theoretically contextualizing philosophical debates
presenting
academic writing
discussing", "Course Content
During this course, we will discuss the origins and development of ancient Stoicism. The course will consist of four elements:
The first and largest part of the course is devoted to reading a selection of texts about the early Stoics, their sources of inspiration, their strict ethics, as well as the underlying physics and epistemology, and the logic they developed.
We will then study the development of Stoic philosophy in the Roman world, with its supposedly more practical approach.
In the context of these first two elements, we will also discuss the criticism leveraged against Stoic philosophy by contemporaries, such as the ancient Sceptics
Finally, we will briefly look into the reception and application of Stoicism in Renaissance and today.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Interactive lectures", "Method of Assessment
There will be preparatory assignments for each class, such as discussion questions and a presentation [assessing learning objectives 1, 2.1-3, 2.5]. These assignments will not be graded, but they are required for completing the course (pass/fail). The final grade is based on one essay [assessing learning objectives 1, 2.1, 2.2, 2.4], and an oral discussion of it in relation to the overall course contents [assessing learning objectives 1, 2.2, 2.5]. The essay constitutes 70% of the grade, and the discussion 30%. Both essay and discussion have to be sufficient. To pass the course, 70% of the preparatory assignments have to be completed, and both essay and discussion have to be sufficient (5.5 or higher). If the essay is not sufficient, a new essay, on a different topic, will have to be written for the official resit period, with a corresponding discussion. If the essay is sufficient, but the discussion is not, the discussion will have to be resat.", "Literature
Details and material will be made available via Canvas before the start of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is primarily intended for second and third year Philosophy bachelor students. Students of classics and ancient studies are also welcome. Other interested students: contact the teacher before enrolling.", "Recommended background knowledge
A completed introduction to Ancient Philosophy is required for participating in this course. If you have attended, but not passed such a course yet, contact the teacher. If you have only completed a general introduction to the history of philosophy, also contact the teacher. You may have to do some additional readings prior to attending the course."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aims of the course are to:
introduce the student into a number of metaphysical terms, theses, and problems
introduce the student into a number of contemporary discussions about these theses and problems, mainly in the broadly ‘analytical’ style.
familiarize the student with a number of classic papers of the contemporary (meta)metaphysical literature", "Course Content
The course will cover central topics in contemporary metaphysics: Quine's criterion of ontological commitment, abstract entities, material objects, natural kinds, time, object persistence, modality, and causation. Moreover, we will deal with metametaphysical themes: social constructionism, antirealism, and cognitive metaphysics.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures on Ney's handbook and selected texts", "Method of Assessment
Written examination", "Literature
Required literature:
Alyssa Ney, Metaphysics (2nd edition)
Selected texts (see Canvas)", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA2-students Philosophy", "Recommended background knowledge
Logic, History of Analytic Philosophy, Epistemology, Argumentation theory, Philosophy of Mind"]

course_name: World Philosophies and the Construction of Traditions II
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This seminar is the follow-up course to World Philosophies and the Construction of Traditions I offered last year. We will continue to engage with recent literature on world philosophies and attempts at developing new, creative, and realistic ways of making academic philosophy more inclusive. This second seminar should enable you to understand the link between a diversified philosophy and what is termed epistemic decolonization better.
Those who have not attended World Philosophies and the Construction of Traditions I are welcome to attend this course. Those who have already attended that seminar last year can particpate in this one too. The syllabus in this course will be new.
On successful completion, you will:
engage with philosophical concepts that have been developed to better understand world-philosophical traditions;
identify mechanisms used to construct these traditions;
recognize the connection between an inclusive academic philosophy and living in an interdependent world;
learn to analyze and critique philosophical texts independently.", "Course Content
In this seminar, we will engage with recent work on world philosophies. In our class discussions, we will (continue to) identify different ways in which this term is used in this body of literature, reflect upon the epistemic practices that this literature seeks to develop to adequately understand world philosophies and work out whether and how this work seeks to contribute to the make of an inclusive academic philosophy.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course will be interactive. Active participation in class discussions, cooperation with peers for group work, and critical writing are necessary for a successful course completion. Attendance is mandatory. Only two unexcused absences are allowed.", "Method of Assessment
Presentation (group activity) (20% of the final grade, assessment of learning objectives 1-2).
The final paper will be developed through the course (80% of the final grade, assessment of learning objectives 1-4). It will consist of three components: project idea, project development, project finalisation.
After the first two weeks, you will submit an abstract with a project idea (10% of your final grade).
In the fifth week of the course, you will develop this idea (30% of your final grade).
In the last three weeks, you will finalize your project idea by developing it into a full-length paper (40% of the final grade, assessment of learning objective 4)."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The goal of this course is to acquire insight into a classical text of the history of philosophy: Kant’s “Kritik der reinen Vernunft”. This text is treated on a textual level but also positioned in the perspective of a broader framework of the history of philosophy, in particular that of metaphysics and empiricism.
After this course,
you can explain basic concepts of Kant’s KrV in your own words;
you have obtained insight into the basic question of the KrV as well as in its argumentation and structure;
you can position Kant’s transcendental philosophy in the history of philosophy;
you can read and analyze texts of Kant by yourself;
you have developed more general academical skills like close reading of texts, discussing them critically, and writing about them.", "Course Content
In his "Kritik der reinen Vernunft" (1781/1787), the first of his three critical works, Kant developed his famous as well as infamous philosophical ‘Copernican turn’ with respect to our knowledge claims. The significance of the KrV for the history of philosophy can hardly be overestimated. Kant's conception of ‘transcendental philosophy’ aims to supply philosophy with a completely new foundation, namely a ‘critical’ foundation. According to Kant, both metaphysics and empiricism are uncritical regarding their own presupposition. Hence, Kant’s KrV not only establishes a new philosophical paradigm but at the same time positions this paradigm within the history of philosophy. For many philosophers, Kant’s transcendental philosophy showed to be a source, a standard, and of course an instance that is in need of criticism itself. The history of philosophy cannot be understood properly without knowledge of Kant’s philosophy. It seems that a philosophy that falls back behind to Kant’s position does not have a long future. In the course, we study in great detail the Einleitung of the KrV (= 2e editie, B 1-30), parts from the Transzendentale Ästhetik and the Transzendentale Logik (Analytik der Begriffe). We start with the Einleitung, following the order of the sections, and hence start with the first section. It is recommended to have read the whole Einleitung before the first meeting. At least, students are supposed to have prepared §§ 1-3 (B 1-10) for the first meeting. For the further meetings too, students have to prepare themselves by studying the relevant text.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar, supplemented by lectures as a part of the seminar. Due to the fact that the goal of this course can only be achieved by means of an active interaction, attendance is mandatory: who misses more than 1 meeting cannot do an examination.", "Method of Assessment
Individual assignments. They constitute 1,5 pt of your grade if you do five or six assignments, 1 pt if you do four assignments. In case you do less than four assignments you do not obtain any points. (learning objectives 1-5)
Open book examination with essay questions (max. 8,5 pt of your grade). (learning objectives 1-5)
The re-examination only consists of an open book test (grades for the assignments are not taken into account). (learning objectives 1-5)", "Literature
Primary literature:
Kant, Immanuel: Kritik der reinen Vernunft. I advise to use the edition of J. Timmermann (Meiner Verlag, Hamburg) or the edition of W. Weischedel (Suhrkamp Verlag, Berlin).
Of course, any Dutch or English translation may be used for the purpose of study, yet, during the meetings we aim work with the German original. I advise to use a translation in your mother language.
Secondary literature:
Allison, Henry E. (2004): Kant's transcendental idealism. Rev. and enl., New Haven.
Cassirer, Ernst (1922): Das Erkenntnisproblem in der Philosophie und Wissenschaft der neueren Zeit. Teil 2 (Darmstadt 1994), 8. Buch: Die kritische Philosophie.
Cassirer, Ernst (1921), Kant’s Life and Thought (1921), New Haven, London 1981), ch. 2-3.
Flach, Werner (2002): Die Idee der Transzendentalphilosophie. Immanuel Kant, Würzburg.
Höffe, Otfried (2003): Kants Kritik der reinen Vernunft. Die Grundlegung der modernen Philosophie. München.
Höffe, Otfried (2010): Kant's Critique of pure reason. The foundation of modern philosophy. Dordrecht, New York.
Guyer, Paul [ed.] (1992): The Cambridge Companion to Kant. Cambridge University Press.
Eisler, Rudolf (1930): Kant-Lexikon, Hildesheim 1994.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA2-students Philosophy", "Recommended background knowledge
W_BA_MOEN Modern Philosophy"]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Het verwerven van vaardigheid in het schriftelijk behandelen en uitwerken van een thema op het gebied van de historische filosofie, de praktische filosofie of de theoretische filosofie.
Leerdoelen:
Je bent in staat een duidelijk verwoordde, goed afgebakende, belangwekkende en filosofische vraagstelling formuleren.
Je kan je scriptie goed structureren, met een hoofdstukindeling die inzichtelijk maakt hoe de vraagstelling wordt beantwoord, en een conclusie waarin de hoofdvraag en eventuele subvragen op volledige wijze worden beantwoord.
Je weet hoe je argumentatie grondig in te bedden in relevante en actuele discussies.
Je bent in staat om literatuur kiezen en gebruiken die van hoog niveau (moeilijkheidsgraad) is, en die correct weer te geven in je eigen woorden.
Je weet duidelijk te markeren wie er aan het woord is en aan welke bron ideeën zijn ontleend. volgens een compleet en consistent verwijzingssysteem.
Je kan je argumentatie goed doordenken, geldig doorvoeren, en aan relevante voorbeelden (in het licht van je vraagstelling) toelichten, zodanig dat het betoog overtuigt.
Je bent in staat een wetenschappelijke, levendige en aansprekende stijl te hanteren, met nauwkeurige, heldere en consistente formuleringen, waarbij relevante filosofische termen worden gedefinieerd.
Je kan zelfstandig je vraagstelling formuleren, de bronnen om de vraag te beantwoorden vinden, en je conclusies beargumenteren.
Je bent in staat volgens een afgesproken schema te werken en eigen gestelde deadlines te halen.
Je weet je eigen gedachtegang te articuleren die iets toevoegt aan bestaande literatuur en die aan het denken zet, terwijl je met een open houding feedback van de begeleider(s) kan opnemen en verwerken.", "Course Content
In overleg met de begeleider(s) wordt een onderwerp gekozen, de probleemstelling, opzet scriptie en tijdsplanning gespecificeerd, en te bestuderen literatuur vastgesteld. Je werkt zoveel mogelijk zelfstandig, volgens de overeengekomen planning, waarbij je op regelmatige momenten feedback vraagt en krijgt van de docent.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
De student neemt voor de begeleiding van de scriptie, in overleg met de coördinator van het Bachelor Scriptie Seminar, contact op met een docent in dienst van de afdeling Filosofie FGW.", "Method of Assessment
De scriptie is een geschreven werkstuk en wordt door de eerste (de begeleider) en tweede lezer beoordeeld aan de hand van het toetsformulier - waarin in ieder geval de genoemde leerdoelen aan de orde komen. Verdere criteria omtrent o.a. omvang, vorm en conventies zijn te vinden in de scriptiehandleiding.", "Entry Requirements
Het gehele 1e jaar en 48 EC uit het 2e jaar dienen te zijn afgerond.
Studenten waarvoor Filosofie de 2e opleiding is, moeten minimaal 78 EC hebben afgerond alvorens te kunnen starten aan de scriptie.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Derdejaars bachelorstudenten Filosofie"]

Participation in class discussions (15%): learning goals 1, 2 and 5
Final essay (70%): learning goals 1, 2 and 4", "Literature
All texts will be available online and/or uploaded to the ‘files’ section of Canvas. There are no books to purchase for this course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
The course is primarily for students in the BA philosophy program. Students from other programs can follow the course as long as they have sufficient prior familiarity with philosophical discussions. They must be prepared to perform close reading of philosophical texts and to engage actively in philosophical discussions."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Cursus doel:
In deze cursus verwerf je de kennis van en het inzicht in de filosofische, academische en retorische vaardigheden die je nodig hebt om een goede bachelor scriptie te schrijven.
Leerdoelen:
je bent in staat om een goede scriptie opzet schrijven als begin van het begeleidingstraject met je eigen scriptiebegeleider
je hebt kennis en vaardigheden betreffende de up to date mogelijkheden om literatuur te zoeken voor je onderzoek
je weet hoe een (filosofische) onderzoeksvraag af te bakenen, te onderscheiden van eventuele sub-vragen, en die als jouw eigen vraag te formuleren
je bent in staat om een helder, goed beargumenteerd en gestructureerd eerste concept hoofdstuk te schrijven.
je kunt peer review (collegiale feedback) geven en ontvangen (als onderdeel van het academisch schrijven)
je weet hoe je these in te zetten voor verdere (publicatie) doelen", "Course Content
In interactieve bijeenkomsten en opdrachten die je zelf doet doe je meer kennis en vaardigheden op over academisch, filosofisch schrijven in het algemeen, en specifiek gericht op het schrijven van de bachelor scriptie. Studenten zijn ook in staat om de maatschappelijke relevantie van hun scriptie te begrijpen en hebben het vermogen om aan wetenschappelijke en publieke debatten deel te nemen.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Er zijn werkgroepen met praktische opdrachten. De bijeenkomsten worden
gespreid over periode 4 en 5", "Method of Assessment
Actieve deelname, waartoe behoort het maken van opdrachten betreffende het opzetten van de scriptie (en het scriptie-voorstel), onderzoek doen, stijl, argumentatie, alsook informatievaardigheden (pass/fail, toets van leerdoelen 1-6)", "Literature
Literatuur wordt via canvas verstrekt.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Derdejaars bachelor studenten"]

course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of this course is for students to acquire in depth knowledge and understanding of key notions, practices, and theories of the ancient Stoics, by means of reading and commenting on different texts from that tradition.
After completing this course, students will also have developed their skills of
critical reading of complex philosophical argumentations
historically and theoretically contextualizing philosophical debates
presenting
academic writing
discussing", "Course Content
During this course, we will discuss the origins and development of ancient Stoicism. The course will consist of four elements:
The first and largest part of the course is devoted to reading a selection of texts about the early Stoics, their sources of inspiration, their strict ethics, as well as the underlying physics and epistemology, and the logic they developed.
We will then study the development of Stoic philosophy in the Roman world, with its supposedly more practical approach.
In the context of these first two elements, we will also discuss the criticism leveraged against Stoic philosophy by contemporaries, such as the ancient Sceptics
Finally, we will briefly look into the reception and application of Stoicism in Renaissance and today.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Interactive lectures", "Method of Assessment
There will be preparatory assignments for each class, such as discussion questions and a presentation [assessing learning objectives 1, 2.1-3, 2.5]. These assignments will not be graded, but they are required for completing the course (pass/fail). The final grade is based on one essay [assessing learning objectives 1, 2.1, 2.2, 2.4], and an oral discussion of it in relation to the overall course contents [assessing learning objectives 1, 2.2, 2.5]. The essay constitutes 70% of the grade, and the discussion 30%. Both essay and discussion have to be sufficient. To pass the course, 70% of the preparatory assignments have to be completed, and both essay and discussion have to be sufficient (5.5 or higher). If the essay is not sufficient, a new essay, on a different topic, will have to be written for the official resit period, with a corresponding discussion. If the essay is sufficient, but the discussion is not, the discussion will have to be resat.", "Literature
Details and material will be made available via Canvas before the start of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is primarily intended for second and third year Philosophy bachelor students. Students of classics and ancient studies are also welcome. Other interested students: contact the teacher before enrolling.", "Recommended background knowledge
A completed introduction to Ancient Philosophy is required for participating in this course. If you have attended, but not passed such a course yet, contact the teacher. If you have only completed a general introduction to the history of philosophy, also contact the teacher. You may have to do some additional readings prior to attending the course."]

course_name: World Philosophies and the Construction of Traditions II
course_programmes: Hide full list (1); Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This seminar is the follow-up course to World Philosophies and the Construction of Traditions I offered last year. We will continue to engage with recent literature on world philosophies and attempts at developing new, creative, and realistic ways of making academic philosophy more inclusive. This second seminar should enable you to understand the link between a diversified philosophy and what is termed epistemic decolonization better.
Those who have not attended World Philosophies and the Construction of Traditions I are welcome to attend this course. Those who have already attended that seminar last year can particpate in this one too. The syllabus in this course will be new.
On successful completion, you will:
engage with philosophical concepts that have been developed to better understand world-philosophical traditions;
identify mechanisms used to construct these traditions;
recognize the connection between an inclusive academic philosophy and living in an interdependent world;
learn to analyze and critique philosophical texts independently.", "Course Content
In this seminar, we will engage with recent work on world philosophies. In our class discussions, we will (continue to) identify different ways in which this term is used in this body of literature, reflect upon the epistemic practices that this literature seeks to develop to adequately understand world philosophies and work out whether and how this work seeks to contribute to the make of an inclusive academic philosophy.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course will be interactive. Active participation in class discussions, cooperation with peers for group work, and critical writing are necessary for a successful course completion. Attendance is mandatory. Only two unexcused absences are allowed.", "Method of Assessment
Presentation (group activity) (20% of the final grade, assessment of learning objectives 1-2).
The final paper will be developed through the course (80% of the final grade, assessment of learning objectives 1-4). It will consist of three components: project idea, project development, project finalisation.
After the first two weeks, you will submit an abstract with a project idea (10% of your final grade).
In the fifth week of the course, you will develop this idea (30% of your final grade).
In the last three weeks, you will finalize your project idea by developing it into a full-length paper (40% of the final grade, assessment of learning objective 4)."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (6); Business Administration; Econometrics and Data Science; Econometrics and Operations Research; Economics and Business Economics; International Business Administration; Philosophy, Politics and Economics

Hide full list (6); Business Administration; Econometrics and Data Science; Econometrics and Operations Research; Economics and Business Economics; International Business Administration; Philosophy, Politics and Economics
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Understanding strategy is an important part of the business acumen for every educated manager. The overarching objective of this course is to develop your understanding of strategy and strategic management. You will engage with the course material through extensive in-class discussions, and team-based analyses of a major public corporation.
After successfully completing this course, you will:
understand the different theoretical perspectives that have informed strategy research (Bridging Theory and Practice - Knowledge)
develop competencies in the critical application of AI-generated material (Academic and Research Skills)
be able to communicate effectively their own informed ideas regarding the focus and purpose of corporate strategy (Academic and Research Skills)
gain confidence in using evidence-based theoretical reasoning to evaluate a modern public corporation (Bridging Theory and Practice - Knowledge & Application)
improve your skills in working with teammates from with diverse background (Academic and Research Skills)
gain competence in allocating tasks among team members under time pressure (Academic and Research Skills)
develop critical thinking and creativity in your approach to problem-solving (Broadening your Horizon)
develop the critical thinking needed to analyze and evaluate complex organizational problems and make well-reasoned decisions (Broadening your Horizon)", "Course Content
Here’s a couple simple questions: why do some organizations outperform others? Why do some organizations prosper and grow, while others in the same industry go out of business and die? It turns out that answering these questions is not so simple ... and has motivated decades of scholarly research on strategic management.
This course will explore the core theoretical perspectives in the research that has examined these questions. We begin from the premise that the organization’s strategy is its approach to achieving success in general, and competitive advantage in particular. We then examine four theoretical perspectives that unpack this premise in very different ways and come to very different conclusions about the role of the manager in formulating and executing an organizational strategy. Developing a critical understanding of these different perspectives is important not only for aspiring managers, but also for anyone who wants to be an informed consumer of the business press and an active participant in today’s fast-paced global economy.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and tutorials.", "Method of Assessment
The final grade will be composed of both individual (50%) and team-based (50%) components:
Individual components: quizzes, class participation and individual reflection paper
Team-based components: corporation analysis and living case studies", "Entry Requirements
A basic understanding and acquaintance with the current world of business and economics (or a great passion and desire to understand and get acquainted) is expected of students in order to allow an in-depth discussion of the selected topics.", "Literature
Whittington, R. (2001). What is Strategy -- and does it matter? (2nd Edition) Hampshire, UK: Cengage Learning EMEA. ISBN: 978-1-86152-377-8.
Other articles and readings will be posted on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Honours Program students: the course can be followed by a broad audience, but requires an interest in business administration in general, and strategic management in particular.", "Explanation Canvas
Canvas will be used as the primary mode of communication outside the classroom."]

course_name: Economics of Globalization: A Transaction Cost Perspective
course_programmes: Hide full list (6); Business Administration; Econometrics and Data Science; Econometrics and Operations Research; Economics and Business Economics; International Business Administration; Philosophy, Politics and Economics
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successfully completing this course, you will:
be familiar with the concept of transaction costs (Bridging Theory and Practice - Knowledge)
be able to show the relevance of transaction costs for understanding several of the empirical phenomena (Bridging Theory and Practice - Application)
be able to apply the insights in a paper on a topic of your own choice that links to the broad topic of transaction costs (Academic and Research Skills)
will be able to present your paper and contribute to discussion on the papers of others (Academic and Research Skills)", "Course Content
Globalization is an important source of welfare, but at the same time heavily contested in modern societies. This course elaborates on the costs and benefits of globalization introducing modern non-mainstream theories that at points challenge the traditional wisdom regarding the benefits of globalization and helps to understand the prevailing sentiments against globalization. We will heavily rely on insights from transaction cost theory which challenges the neglect in traditional neoclassical theory of transaction costs. The (oftentimes implicit) reliance in mainstream trade theory on frictionless trade is surprising for theories in which exchange is at the heart of the matter. This course aims to familiarize you with the concept of transaction costs and to show the relevance of transaction costs for understanding several of the empirical phenomena that are impossible to understand without relying on such costs.
Insights are particularly relevant to appreciate current discussions on the impact of globalization on a small open economy such as the Netherlands. Think, for example, about recent discussions on reshoring and the impact of globalization on wage inequality and unemployment. The course will focus on four main areas of research in which transaction costs are dominant, viz. (i) international trade with a focus on the multiple dimensions of transaction costs distinguishing between transport costs, institutional costs and cultural costs of exchange, (ii) foreign direct investments with a focus on outsourcing and the organization of the firm in a globalizing world, (iii) industrial organization with a focus on the determinants of the boundaries of the firm, and (iv) networks with a focus on the role of social and regional networks, and on standards as institutionalized settings that facilitate exchange of goods, ideas, etc.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Interactive lectures.", "Method of Assessment
Individual paper and presentation, and optional assignments.", "Literature
An extensive reading list is made available at the start of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second and third year participants in the honours program.", "Custom Course Registration
SBE rules and dates apply for this SBE HP course.", "Recommended background knowledge
Basic familiarity with the principles of economics and statistics."]

course_programmes: Hide full list (6); Business Administration; Econometrics and Data Science; Econometrics and Operations Research; Economics and Business Economics; International Business Administration; Philosophy, Politics and Economics
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The goal of the course is to introduce you to economic perspectives on financial asset bubbles and crashes (Bridging Theory and Practice - Knowledge & Application). Additional goals are the development of your discussion skills, presenting an writing in English, and critical thinking (Academic and Research Skills).", "Course Content
The history of financial markets is littered with asset price booms and subsequent busts. In this course, we will explore the underlying drivers of asset price bubbles, examining the psychological and economic factors that contribute to their formation. By analyzing historical and contemporary examples, we will identify common characteristics and patterns that all asset bubbles share. Additionally, the course will address the critical question of how policymakers can respond to these phenomena. We will evaluate various policy responses aimed at preventing, mitigating, and managing the impacts of bubbles and crashes on the economy.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course is structured as a combination of lectures and discussion sessions, for which students have to prepare in advance. In three group assignments, students will engage with historical crashes, policy measures that mitigate the effects of such crashes, and potential future bubbles and crashes. Additionally, three individual assignments will test students' learning progress throughout the course.", "Method of Assessment
The final grade is calculated as a weighted average, with group assignments contributing 70% and individual assignments contributing 30% to the overall result.", "Literature
Relevant literature (links) is provided both in the reading list and as on-slide references.", "Additional Information Target Audience
The intended audience is second and third-year students of Economics and Business Economics, (International) Business Administration, Econometrics or PPE.", "Custom Course Registration
SBE rules and dates apply for this SBE HP course. Registration via VU.nl", "Recommended background knowledge
Rudimentary knowledge of Finance is recommended, for example, having followed Finance I."]
